10xkwCVDYub8SL9fdedrQg.review_text: This place has potential, but it currently still has teething pains. Arrived on time for a Friday 9PM reservation, but the table wasn't ready yet. Instead of giving us a spiel about how it would only be 10-15 minutes, they gave us some free drinks. The drinks arrived fast, but our table was already prepared so they comped us the drinks. Nice!  Out of the deviled eggs from the appetizer list which bummed out the GF since she wanted to try them. Wait, out of deviled eggs? How can you run out of eggs? Anyway, by the time the table next to us ordered, they were out of 2 other appetizers. So yeah, teething pains. The raw halibut was great. The brussel sprouts were tasty, but had way too much lemon. Tell Juan to chill out with the lemon bottle. Appetizers came out quickly and promptly.  It took a while (20-30 minutes after apps cleared) for the main course. After arrival, the food was cold and my pork was undercooked. The GF's scallops were coldish, too. Dunno if this was a kitchen screwup or waitstaff, but I'm guessing kitchen. (The table next to us had similar delays). My pork was undercooked. I'm ok with the new pink-in-the-middle trend, but my pork was cold and red. Not medium, but more on the medium-rare to rare side. That aint cool. Luckily, the waiter came to check on us, I told him, he took it away and fixed it up. Upon returning he said he should have told me that's how they serve it and that it's "brined." I don't care if it's been irradiated. You can't serve pork that rare in a dark restaurant. Everyone will think it's way undercooked (mine was and it was cold). Plus, pork that rare doesn't have the same texture as beef. PT staff if you're reading this, make sure they cook the pork to medium! Food was good, once it was recooked and the GF's scallops were tasty.  Overall the ambiance is weird. It feels like a NYC boisterous alphabet soup lunch spot....yet they're mainly going after the dinner crowd. I can't quite put my finger on it. There are some great restaurants which are loud and dynamic like Galatoire's in NOLA. I just can't say what's off about this place, but something is. GF and I both think that we'll be going to Marlowe instead of PT in the future.  Service was excellent, so keep up the good work there.

RV1wQ7HxI60DkMJPPLa5hg.review_text: Park Tavern is a perfect place for a date where you can sit outside during nice weather. Or just a perfect place for reunion or sex-and-the-city kind of brunch.  Service was good and not overwhelming; parking was tough but there's $10 brunch valet.   Unfortunately it was hard to love the food here. Our crab toast was delicious but there was't sufficient crab. Veal Schnitzel sounded much nicer than how it really tasted. Surely bacon fat eggs that accompanied the veal sounded delicious but there was nothing special with the taste. Perhaps the concept was similar to duck fat french fries but was not good once implemented. Even worse, the schnitzel seemed like something you can fry it yourself at home.   The dessert on the other hand was quite good.  TCHO chocolate creme brulee was not your regular brulee because there wasn't hard sugar to coat the creme. The taste was decent and the salt was a good touch. Panna Cotta with orange was good but also not great - you could possibly find the same dessert at other joint.   All and all, Park Tavern has a warm ambience for intimate dinner. You won't be disappointed if you lower your expectation or if you are here when you are hungry from the mad Mama's line.

GJsRGdnvfGsG3w0becDD2w.review_text: I get what all the fuss is about. Came here with girlfriends mid afternoon on a Sunday. We sat outside, drank wine & creative cocktails and dined on bar bites. The fried brussel sprout leaves were everything I dreamed about...crisp, salty and nice hint of lemon. The girls loved the burger they shared and I thought the fries that accompanied it were solid with a nice horseradish aioli. Also had the delicious deviled eggs, the thinly sliced jalapeño was sweet and spicy & divine. Beautiful interior, welcoming and on point service. Can't wait to go back. Maybe next time it will be with a hot man with a big wallet...a girl can dream.

4G7ZjAKNZInbJdj9YV1CIA.review_text: Our friends made a reservation for 6 of us on a Sunday at 2pm and when we arrived we were promptly checked in and seated. The place is large on the inside with high ceilings and an overall nice decor. We were all vegetarians but we do eat eggs. We shared a baguette with a trio (pistachio, walnut, almond) of nut butters and honey to start -- despite being house-made the texture was not spreadable on the baguette, the nut butters were under salted (it tasted like they used raw, unsalted nuts), and lacked bold nutty flavors. We also tried the avocado toast which was delicious, but the portion was small (1 piece of toast, halved). We ordered the crispy polenta cakes and brioche french toast. The brioche french toast was well executed -- crispy on the outside but soft and eggy on the inside with a delicious blueberry compote. However, the highlight of the meal was the crispy polenta cakes, which were essentially 2 deep friend polenta cakes (crisp outside, soft, creamy inside) with a poached egg and a mushroom-truffle salad. This was one of the best brunch dishes we have had in San Francisco. Our friends ordered french toast as well as the oatmeal pancakes and everyone was happy with their order. One thing to note -- the kitchen closes at 2:30pm so all food orders must be in by then. We were surprised and appreciative of the complimentary coffee cake which we received at the end of the meal -- it was also pretty tasty.  Overall, we enjoyed having brunch here and would highly recommend it. It is close to Mama's but takes reservations which is a huge plus.

Ce8uGOvVqy7p_2djR5MTTw.review_text: I usually make it to SF twice a year and have seen this restaurant a number of times but have never made it in till this year - it did not disappoint.  The food was top notch, wine selection strong and service very good.  Great locale on Washington square and I appreciated staff willingness to meet our request to move to window seats.  I recommend the Tavern to all.

Yi5JKaD1VY4Edeww92PZWA.review_text: Park tavern is such a great place in the neighborhood to get a fancy meal and treat yourself. It's basically impossible to get a reservation, but we decided to go and eat at the bar, which turned out to be a lot of fun. The bartenders are so friendly and helpful, and they sat us almost immediately. I ordered the Mclaren (Hendrick's Gin, cucumber, lemon & ginger beer) which was delish. We decided to try a bunch of things on the menu, which ended up being a great idea. For starters, we ordered the venison carpaccio, the deviled eggs, and the brussels sprout chips. The carpaccio wasn't that great, and there was too much onion on it. The deviled eggs were fantastic though, and the chips were also very good.   For the entree, I ordered the poulet noir and my date ordered the mussels, cockles and clams. The chicken was AMAZING (caps are necessary here). I actually finished the entire chicken, and wow, the truffle flavor! And that stuffing! And that juiciness! Almost too much to handle. Seriously though, if you don't like food really salty, or think that truffles can be overpowering, I would not suggest this dish. It was verrrry flavorful. Thankfully I can't get enough of salt, so it worked out in my favor. The mussel dish was also delicious, especially the broth! And the bread, which is soo good, is the perfect way to sop it all up. When the dish first arrived we noticed that a good number of clams/mussels were still closed, and when we brought it to the bartender's attention, he immediately brought them back to the kitchen and we were given a new bowl. We also ordered a bottle of white wine which was reasonably priced and perfectly complimentary to the meal.  I really appreciated how attentive the servers were. They knew when to step in, and when to give us time. They also knew the menu inside and out. While the meal as a whole might be worth 4 stars, the service and overall ambiance makes it a 5. Will definitely be going back!

4IjzfbO7XKFNWWVufHNhww.review_text: Four enthusiastic stars for a very good meal last night. We arrived at 8:15 for our reservation and were told they were running behind. We went to the bar to grab a cocktail, and were seated 20 minutes later. It was the perfect opportunity to try one of the many specialty cocktails they make.   I went with the Twin Peaks drink which was a Four Roses drink and I actually didn't like it at all. It was way too sweet for my taste. I asked the bartender to add something to take some of the sweetness away, and he graciously made me a totally new drink that had more lemon and I really enjoyed. My husband got the classic manhattan, it was made very well.   Once we were seated we ordered the scallop, shrimp and crab salad since we knew we were going to both get beef for our entrees. I really enjoyed it.  Very light way to start the meal. I then got the Bar Steak, which was served with french fries. It was cooked perfectly rare, just the way I ordered it. The steak was seasoned perfectly. Overall it was very good, I was just wishing the juices form the steak didn't get all over my delicious fries. Maybe the fries in a dish would prevent this.   The It's It dessert was the best. Mint ice cream with crunchy cookie crumbles and a hard shell on top. I highly recommend it! The service was also attentive, friendly and help with suggestions.

Tug19-NVd1kVTTHZXXwicg.review_text: Thoroughly enjoyed our dinner at Park Tavern last night! Everyone we encountered there was warm and friendly. It was an upscale environment without a shred of snobbery. Not always easy to come by!  Here's a run down of what we had:   Deviled eggs. Yum! A crisp and crunchy piece of bacon atop the light whipped yolks, just a touch of heat in the back of your throat from the pickled jalapenos!  Compressed Watermelon and goat cheese salad with olives. Perfect salty and sweet combo. The watermelon was sooooo good!  Brussel sprout chips. A great munchie app. Nice touch of citrus. Not overpowering but just right.   My friend had the seafood special. I tried her scallop and fried oyster. Both very tasty. She cleaned her plate so I imagine the other sea creatures were also delicious.  I had the roast chicken. It was insanely good! I would say better than Zuni! They poured fresh au jus with lemon over the chicken when it was served which sizzled in the skillet and blended beautifully with the spinach. My friend was eating my spinach before I even took a bite!   A-Mazing waiter. So fun. He didn't rush us along and was very helpful in explaining different items on the menu. He gave us a free dessert on top of the dessert we ordered. Chocolate creme brûlée with sea salt and then he brought us chocolate ice cream on cocoa nibs which was light and sweet. They apparently do whipped egg whites with whipping cream. So light and fluffy! Heaven.   Will def be coming back here!

SxWY5j5g71ifCm691q6A0g.review_text: The food is creative and amazing. The service is over the top. Literally over the top. There is such a thing as too much service and I found myself fighting with the staff to keep plates on the table that I had not finished. Otherwise, it's a great spot and much needed in the NB hood.

XBA4XWhYOCiEVH7NnV-cVw.review_text: I've been wanting to try to place for awhile since I'm a fan of Marlowe and have only heard good things about Park Tavern.  The grilled pork chops were heavenly, as were the little pieces of bacon that it came with!   I would say these chops were comparable to Mustards in Napa and that says a lot.  I've driven to the wine country just to go to Mustards.  I'm a sucker for burrata, so we had to start with the lemon chips, mint, burrata, & Shelley's pea tendrils, which did not disappoint.  I was a little hesitant about the lemon chips but they weren't overwhelming and balanced well with the cheese.  Good pre-dinner cocktails and great atmosphere.  Despite the crowd, it was easy to converse with my guest.    It was definitely worth the wait and I plan to return.

nZB33t0RFtq_jTxJJJ6wfA.review_text: Yes, yes, yes! Amazing evening we had a party of five, shared a few starters, let me tell you the reviews for those deviled eggs are true! You must have them, little egg heaven! Same goes for the  brussels sprout chips.  Caramelized onion & wild mushroom soup, oh yes! Full of flavor and so comforting. Entrees at our table were; grilled pork chop, poulet rouge and the burger. I had the burger and it was great, very reasonably priced at $13.00. I tasted each entree finding pleasure in all I would say the most amazing would be the poulet rouge. We were here the day after Thanksgiving so a burger was my craving.  Cocktails are generous in strength, I can recommend the Washington Square, we enjoyed a few bottles of wine found to be fairly priced as well.  This place is sexy and fun, love the bar area, fun spot to eat at with a smaller party. Service was excellent. I will go back. Check it out, Cheers!

-bi3BhmGWkq2UjTjmebj3A.review_text: Review for brunch...  Solid food.  Get the avocado toast.  and the boozy smoothie is amazing.  The polenta and poached egg dish is also very good.  Pretty big portions.  Great service.  I love the communal table.

Np_DkxOEORey8KsuYWRydw.review_text: great, bustling atmosphere: love big restaurants, reminds me of new york!  hard to get a resi, but really easy to grab a spot at the communal table or chef's corner.  obsessed with the lemon chips and burrata.  i am also a fan of the polenta (ask for extra cabbage), deviled eggs, and brussel sprout chips.  great cocktails and boozy shakes.  my one complaint is that the food is very heaaaaavy.

F6c50ZDlCgaMC4-cPl3oEg.review_text: I'd heard nothing but great things about this place and was prepared to love it but, meh.  The brussels sprouts chips are ok. The lemon chips are amazing as are the fried sunchokes. Butter lettuce wedge was swimming in a puddle of sweet watery dressing (couldn't taste anything but sweet).  Chicken was tasty but the stuffing was completely burned...stuck to the skillet and not in a good crispy way, just completely burned on.  The service was GREAT. Not sure I'd bother to make the trek to N.Beach to give it another go.

NpU44ANnUUNQWY4U0eUGvA.review_text: we came here on a sunday night and the place was full!  from the bar and communal table to the dining room.  people were drinking, sunday night? eating and having a good time.  it was a bit hard to hear in there.  looks like they have acoustic soundboard on the ceiling but the noise was quite loud.  we started with the melon salad which we split.  but they split it for us and it looked kind of sad split.  some slices on melon and greens on a place.  with pickled grapes.  also tried the duck liver pate and it was very liver-y.  warm bread and softened butter.    for main, i had the seafood special which was octopus, calamari, scallops with carrots and potatoes. i didnt like the octopus. but i think its an acquired taste.  they did the bay scallops in two little soy sauce dishes which was weird for presentation.  they were overcooked and i didnt like them.  an uni nage covered all the seafood and i couldve licked the plate clean of the sauce if we had not been with company.  also im not a huge fan or uni but the sauce was rich and tasty.  to finish we had the peach cobbler which came out piping hot. yum!  service was good. they kept our water glasses full.  stabilized our teetering table and started to get our car for us from valet when we got the bill.  this place is bigger and better than marlowe.  they have the full bar. an extensive menu and less of the salt.

CLFknBpbWbvvfaZ00Be7uw.review_text: What can I say, I was seriously impressed. The ambience, the vibe, the people. It was really not typical of San Francisco. I loved that everyone was dressed to impressed. We had the truffle fries, chicken, deviled eggs and Brussel sprout chips. Everything was amazing with an honorable mention to the truffle fries and deviled eggs. The ladies I was dining with were truffle fanatics and they could not stop raving about the fries...they even wanted to order a 2nd round. I highly recommend this restaurant. We will definitely be coming back!!!!!

Rx7DNBmPPShVjlcQidGuTw.review_text: came here again on fri night and ate like a little pig.  the PT fries and brussels sprout chips were AMAZING.  we also tried the duck liver mousse, which wasn't my fave.  the pork chop and trout dip were also good, but the fries and brussels sprout chips were the biggest hit.

8QcN3SvXmxvGDFSgvv_Ccw.review_text: Park Tavern exceeded my already high expectations for it. I went here for my grandma's 80th birthday brunch and was truly impressed. The ambiance and service at the place are spectacular. The food is original and quite delicious. My only hope is that they might add a few more items to the menu. I was also unimpressed by the brunch drinks. Their Bloody Mary was way too spicy and I am still not sure what they were trying to accomplish with their Tequila Based Bloody Mary as it came out in an odd green color and had a rather odd flavor to it.  Ordering Advice: I see that people have been writing about the toast below. I actually found the toast to be quite delicious. It is a little bit expensive and rather basic, but there is something quite original and truly delicious in the toast creations that they have made. If you are in a large group, they are a great starter.  For main courses I would recommend the duck pate sandwich and the polenta. Both were so delicious.  I will definitely be frequently attending brunch at park tavern in the future.

94Qb_VgoIcYPeKCvYEqC9w.review_text: I was taken here for my bday, and let me first just say that this isn't a place I'd normally walk into. Let's just say the crowd lacks diversity.  With that said, just about everything we ordered was tasty. The starters were great. In fact, we were considering ordering nothing but starters, since their menu descriptions were quite appetizing.  My entree was the pork chop. A thick, double cut, pork chop. Let me tell you... I was reluctant to order it, not because I dislike pork (quite the contrary, as pork is my favorite protein when done right), but because pork is all too often done poorly at nouveau American joints. I'm not sure what prompted me to actually order it this time, but I'm sooooo glad I did. This was one of the best pork chops I ever had. It was cooked perfectly medium rare, the flavor was full and smokey, it was fatty but not excessively so, and it was quite juicy.  I will end it right there before I drool on my keyboard.

uI_FghQZvL2xaHjAoar3lA.review_text: A yummy brunch place that takes reservations! Hooray!  I've been here twice now (both times for their brunch) and I think this is a great place to grab brunch with a friend or a group of friends, since they take reservations. This place is a little bit nicer than the average brunch place. I think it's decorated in a really clean and cute style.  For brunch, Park Tavern serves an assortment of little bites (toast with various toppings, pastries, fruit, etc.) as well as larger entrees and cocktails.   We had (see photos!):  POMELO & AVOCADO (8) - cottage cheese & cracked black pepper. This appetizer was very light, refreshing, and healthy. I thought it was a good start to our meal, but something I could definitely prepare at home.  PAN-FRIED CORNED BEEF HASH (16) - crispy potato, poached egg, arugula & red wine jus. This was super delicious. Last time, I had a chicken hash, but I thought the beef hash with the red wine jus made this dish taste even better! I loved how savory and flavorful the sauce was, and I liked the crispy texture of the potato and hash, along with the soft poached egg. It was a tad bit on the salty side, but I would most definitely order this again. Highly recommended!  WARM OPEN-FACED DEVILED EGG SANDWICH (14) - pickled jalapeño, chicken breast, bacon & provolone cheese (served with skinny fries). I wasn't the biggest fan of this dish. I thought it tasted more like a chicken sandwich and couldn't really detect the deviled egg component. The fries were really good though!And just a tip, we got some hot sauce on the side to add some bite.   Next time, I really want to give their brioche french toast and crispy polenta cakes a try! :]

73OCy2bC-8eAisYX9p5C_w.review_text: Try the deviled eggs. You will think "really? deviled eggs at dinner?" - yes, yes to deviled eggs at dinner. They are absolutely the greatest things ever and I don't think that was the wine talking.  Here's the rest of the breakdown:  Food - amazing. just flat out delicious. we had a steak tartare app, the deviled eggs, scallops, brussel sprouts, and the fish of the day, everything was just melt in your mouth good.  Wine - expensive, but well paired.  Service - on point.  Wait - if you don't make reservations well in advance you can still show up and wait for a cancellation. We got lucky doing that but you can't count on it and you have to be with a group (or date) who's good natured enough to be willing to waste an hour or so hanging out in the bar. If you keep good company this shouldn't be a problem.  Price - it's expensive. but it's worth it so just be prepared for it. Decide before hand wether you can afford it so once you get there you can forget about it. This isn't a place to go if you have to worry over every little item. But if you decide you can treat yourself then do it! Enjoy yourself, check the diet and the budget at the door, you can pick them up on your way out.  I would love love love to go to this place again!

3rBc0Y1AB3lmnbhxnTH88g.review_text: Great ambiance and really well prepared food here. It's a nice and lively which makes it great for brunch either at a table or at the bar. I got the chorizo and eggs and it was fantastic. Love how it was one big scramble with everything mixed in! Eat here and walk it off on Coit Tower.

1oP2XOTnPnTzo47PFlTNUg.review_text: This is a brunch review.   And I could not be more satisfied with my experience. What a fabulous restaurant and I can't believe it's taken me 2 years since its birth to get here.   The venue is fantastic - high ceilings, lots of space, outside seating (the sun, when out, always hits north beach nicely), and modern-rustic decor. This would be a good place to take your out-of-town family for brunch rather than a girls mimosa thing.   The service...wonderful! Given the older, more serious, and well-dressed demographic, I was expecting some attitude when my friends and I rolled in our in Sperry's and t shirts. It wasn't so. Not only that, we had about a 3 hour brunch discussing important things like yoga class logistics, breakups, and pedis (I know, #marinagirlproblems) and not once were we given looks or hints to leave...as a matter of fact, the server who didn't even have our area refilled our water as we gossiped and figured out our early-twenties lives.   The food - very, very good. I recommend:   1. Open-faced deviled egg sandwich with chicken and jalapeno. The jalapeno adds a great kick to the entree.   2. Crispy polenta cakes. Interesting mix of poached eggs on top of lightly fried polenta. I really appreciated the contrast in textures of these two. And mushrooms came with this dish. They were fantastic.   3. Marlowe burger. I don't eat beef, but my friend was very satisfied.   This is not one of those absurd wait-time brunch places, but they do take reservations, so call ahead.

29snpxOsSJtFbcgmMIX1FA.review_text: Had dinner here with work associates after a long day. They had a wait, but easily accomdated us outside. Thanks to stellar California weather, it was perfectly comfortable easting on their patio at 8 pm. The food was exceptional, and I found myself wishing I wasn't watching calories. We shared a variety of appetizers, and I could have eaten an entire plate of any of them. I had a pork chop, which was enormous, cooked perfectly, and was really tasty. Might be the best pork chop of the year. I've walked past this place several times over the years, and always wondered what it was like. Now that I know..I'll not walk past it again.

nlOrTEl5JQ5gEdjLI27XGg.review_text: Just an overall excellent meal!! We both had the filet of beef and it was deeelish!!! Served on a bed of these amazing potatoes with crispy skins and yummy creamy greens. And the prawns w pork fat app was equally excellent. We will certainly be back!!

czJjUvuzfil0agvji1C6qA.review_text: Sunday brunch here was quite good.  We were seated promptly for our reservation at a nice table looking out onto the park.  Their pastries are delicious, the butter cake was described as five flaky croissants reduced into one yummy treat, and that was a very good description!  I had the crispy polenta cakes with mushrooms.  It was very good, although the polenta was more soft like cornbread than crispy.  But very tasty.  Service was excellent and friendly.  Would definitely like to come and try dinner at some point.

ZQybH2ne7Y1zTnswJeNMBQ.review_text: Make sure to make reservations! This place was crackin as late as 10pm on a sat night!  Service was fantastic and the ambience was delightful. Very lively, crowded and drinks flowin everywhere!   Food was fantastic as well. To start the bread was warm and the butter was room temp! Major points in my book! For my meal I got the deviled eggs and the smoked buratta, fig and prosciutto salad. Both are highly recommended!  My bf got the Marlowe Burger which was cooked to perfection and the flavors were so well balanced with the caramelized onions and the crispy bacon!  We split the twice baked potatoes which were to die!   We went here for date night but it would also be fun for a small get together!  Pretty reasonably priced as well! Will definitely come back here!!  Yummy!!

YLfyhDaQBs_2bfJBNLBt_w.review_text: I think they should call this place "Salt Tavern." The roasted game hen was good for the first few bites, then it was nearly inedible because it was so salty (and I LIKE salty food!). The deviled egg appetizer was really good though...I could eat a dozen of them.

DI55uTeTXj0kphBfu-3fNQ.review_text: The location is wonderful, we sat outside on a rare warm night in SF. As the hostess sat us down and gave us our menus I realized it was really hard to read the menu...oh bc the lights weren't on. After about 15 mins, no one had come out to take our drink order or turn the lights on. So I went to ask about the lights, they went on, then after 10 mins, they went off again...this happened all night.  When we finally ordered, the appetizers came out fast and the waiter was polite but we never got the warm rolls everyone keeps raving about. The ikura and fish dip, mushroom soup, and arugula salad were decent, but nothing stood out. (much like Marlowe, their other restaurant, that we live 2 mins from)  We waited another 20 mins after we were done with our apps, and watched our waiter help other tables, and our main course still hadn't come out. There was no apology, no explanation, no acknowledgement that there was a very long wait between courses.   The steak was was a little tough, not too flavorful, and just disappointing. I thought about giving them two stars but the apps were good and the ambiance is great, they could work on their service a bit as well.

AkPkijB6Pv9YH1pDxeU98g.review_text: We had a delicious brunch here recently. The ambiance is great, even if the tables are a bit close together. Every dish we had was wonderful and the service was excellent. The avocado toast was definitely the highlight! Parking in this neighborhood is, of course, a challenge but they offer valet parking if you need it.

hR38WUHHvXH32mDo21vVpA.review_text: Excellent service, excellent food, excellent drinks.  I especially would recommend the deviled eggs, brussels sprouts, and the poulet. I've dined here three times in the last 6 months and it is now firmly one of my favorite SF restaurants.

cQCNoZnQWQ_Lz8uojk9EXQ.review_text: I adore this plAce!!   Super cool vibe inside - nice ambiance and great service  The menu is unique and delicious. Makes it hard to choose but I don't think you can go wrong with anything here.   Loved grabbing drinks and some bites to eat at the bar. It was comfortable, fast and delicious. Great cocktail menu too! The Kentucky mule was my favorite.   Brussels sprout chips - lemony & crispy  PT fries - oeuf a la coque topped w caviar... Paired with truffle sauce. Ya must order.  Prawns - smokey jumbo deliciousness  Yum.   So many more dishes to try! The burgers from the couple next to us looked awesome.   Gets pretty busy but were able to grab a couple seats at the bar with out any problem Wednesday around 7p.

1qcq_VTO9fYIslCUwudlOA.review_text: In all honestly for this place to be the restaurant that once was Moose's it has not comparison in my eyes.  It also no place for a vegetarian.  Our server recommended I order the gnocchi which was an appetizer dish but he told me I could have it as an entree.  So I ordered the gnocchi and I was not all that impress.  The gnocchi tasted like greasy potatoes.  Our party also had desert, three different ones for all of us to share.  I wasn't impressed.  I love my sweets but the desert here was no comparison to my dad's homemade cobblers, pies and cakes.  It is also very expensive here.  I'm grateful that our dinner was a paid for by a very well known local Franciscan but if I knew that the food was just eh, then I would not have dined here.  I will not be back again.  Sorry but we're all entitled to our opinions and I enjoy a great dinner, where the food is delicious and the service is super duper awesome.

htDbBgZQWUwgMz04kkreQA.review_text: Had dinner (again) here on Saturday night. Great vibe and energy. Bar was packed. Can't get enough of the deviled eggs. It's always hard to get newbies to believe that they can be that good!

iI8VJGANZEyvkQ5iWyAZkA.review_text: Came here for brunch on a sat. after waiting to get in to Mama's for 40 minutes.  Glad we did too.  Great food and service with very little wait. Thomas our waiter was fantastic.  Gave us a great recommendation and was super knowledgeable of the menu.  My friend and I had the salmon benedict,oatmeal walnut pancakes and the crispy polenta cakes (all spectacular).  Also Thomas allowed us to modify our pancake order because it was going to be too much food.  So we got one pancake instead of the three that come with the dish. Love restaurants that give you some flexibility.  They also have a great craft beer menu.  If you like IPAs, get the Ninkasi from OR.  In closing, great friendly staff and a fabulous vibe and atmosphere.  Been here twice now and had a fantastic experience both times.

AapN-h9AsaLrlIQqkNx9nQ.review_text: My family came in on a packed night, we made reservations for 9pm (that was the soonest we could get in). Hard to park so we used their valet. Once we sat down we had an amazing meal with amazing service from Patrick. Although busy there was no lack in service at all. Every dish was unique and balanced. It was hard to choose from their menu because everything looked amazing. The decor was subtle and sophisticated. Very up and coming. I'd recommend this place to anyone and will be going again when I visit San Francisco. I will also request Patrick as a server because he was as excited about the menu as we were and made amazing sincere recommendations.

Vloi1tpDf7vNjpjzy1bSiw.review_text: Great service and food. Meat portions were big. I used to live up the street and miss it...

dGy6LmfgfJyftpcHVkPtEw.review_text: For Tom's "Choose your own adventure night' or whatever the hell he decided to try and brand it (the name's changed hourly and I still believe they all sucked) started here at the Park.  Okay so it is like Park Place tries to be a Tavern. This place is the exact opposite of anything dark or dank. It is very much bright and trendy and not tavern like in any way shape or form. For starters you don't bring kids to a tavern, there was no dartboard, and they have waaaaay too many kinds of wine to be a real tavern.  That being said it was a nice place with good service. I really liked the menu options but still settled on the well named Marlowe burger. It was a nice piece of beef with bacon and caramelized onions. Fries on the side with a beer up top and I was ready to praise this place as a great new stop. Prices were in the middle of the road but it was a nice place so the $14 for a burger didn't seem too out of line. They did have Speakeasy and IPA on tap after all...  Onward boys!

uswU6iDxsvyNpL1_OnhZ2w.review_text: Went here with a large group and rented out the 2nd floor. The meal was served "Family Style" which I thought might be awkward, but it was really fun.   We started with the Wagyu Beef Jerky - I love Jerky - but this was the I have EVER HAD! And then we had the AMAZING Deviled Eggs - OMG!   The fried brussels sprouts, the burrata and lemon chips, pea puree crostini. Okay, now we're nearly full - and they bring more. The PT Fries... I believe I saw two people empty the containers into their purses. WOW.. they are GREAT!   The baby lettuce salad was wonderful. So many fun things added to it, grapes, fennel, radish, avocado and the dressing had just the right touch of tarragon.   The main dishes were the cod, chicken and ribeye. All were wonderful - but the twice baked potatoes.. creamy, cheesy, comfort in a bowl.   The service is warm and professional - from the hostess to the bartenders to the wait staff - all at the top of their game.   Circle this place on the map; bookmark it right now;  come here, eat, drink, enjoy!

ZKWWW5JVW-_g_hwDif7sFg.review_text: Sat at the bar for brunch on Saturday afternoon and the food was quite delicious.   CON:  the bartender rushed us the entire time, must have wanted to end his shift or something. He said that the kicthen only had 5 minutes left for brunch and then stood there tapping his pen while we tried to peruse the menu. Five minutes after we placed our order the bartender came to inform me they had ran out of it so I had to pick something else.  Again, he stood there, breathing down my neck,  rudely impatient while I re-decided what to eat.   PRO: ambiance and some of the best challah I've ever had

3a9ixGz9rFogtlCz2sREYg.review_text: I don't know how many times I've eaten here, trying to make myself like it. The menu and ingredients are promising, and it's in a gorgeous space -- and it serves beautiful food to beautiful people.  Service can be disjointed, though always friendly. But the food is uneven.  Some dishes in the same section of the menu are very small, some are pretty big, most are rather oily, and quality varies between visits.  And it's all a tad pricy for being often less than stellar.  I've had one perfect Marlowe Burger here. Other times, the bun has been stale (even after sending it back -- though, I got it, I was there on Stale Bun Day), the patty mis-prepared, or it was too salty.  Loved the spiciness and juiciness of the Poulet Rouge, but I only had it once and its vegetables were so salty and oily that I can't quite bring myself to order it again.  The deviled eggs, with pickled jalapeno and bacon, have always been perfect, and the build-your-own Fried Caesar Salad is fun and tasty.  The Grilled Sea Scallops dish has a cool combination of flavors, but the scallops were overcooked.  The brunch dish with kiwi and strawberry w/ whipped coconut milk is refreshing, and the avocado toast is, as well, as long as too much oil isn't poured onto it. Many of their main brunch dishes seem to involve lots of eggs on top.  Drinks are consistent and the wine always at the perfect temp, though the brunch Boozie Smoothie really should be served in something larger than a coupe martini glass.  I love the idea of the Birthday Cake dessert, and it's always superbly airy, but sometimes bland.  I'll probably still come here -- it's really the only modern SF restaurant of its kind in North Beach -- but I still hope that it lives up to what it wants to be.  If I didn't live close by, I would never go out of my way to go here.

zwoVXacABm07kYYkqub7eQ.review_text: Went to Park Tavern last night (Sunday) after wandering around North Beach a bit trying to avoid all the tourist traps. It is a long weekend and the area wa very busy. Had not checked out this location since the venerable Moose's closed and so wasnt sure what to expect. The place was packed and so we sat at the communal table - fantastic experience and fantastic meal! The menu isn't extensive but very well-rounded and everything sounded great. The recommendations from the people sitting around us made the decisions even more difficult as everyone was raving about what they were eating. I finally decided on the Halibut with fennal and potatoes but was still debating on the sides - either Dungenss Crab Salad or Smoked Pumpkin Soup. The waiter recommended the soup, which I ordered and it was truly spectacular; it had a very smoky flavor, toasted pumpkin seeds and fried sage - outstanding! The Halibut was perfectly seared and roasted and was served with fennel with an excellent creamy-type sauce on it - very nice combination and something I'm going to try to recreate at home. My friend had the short ribs, which were extremely tender and flavorful. I had no expectations of having dessert, but I succumbed to  the "White Russian" Affogato - fabulous! Homemade white russian ice cream with an espresso and rum sauce and homemade marshmallow and cocoa nibs. Really spectacular and not overly large, which for me is actually a good thing in a dessert. My friend had the Almond Joy and raved about it as well.   The service was very good, although perhaps a tad slow, but really nothing to complain about. The other diners at the communal table were all very social and we had a great time talking with everyone so any slowness really wasn't an issue. The atmosphere is excellent - upscale and a bit trendy, but restrained and tasteful at the same time. Overall a very diverse crowd with a very healthy sampling of the young and beautiful.   Park Tavern is a great addition to the North Beach dining scene and I will definitely return. I strongly recommend it!

USB-WW1Y4-N5vVz-89D9TQ.review_text: Beautiful place with great service and carefully prepared season food. The restrained playful bent makes it perfect for delighting parents and elders more than ruckus reunion with foodie friends.  Great brunch menu means it will be packed on Mother's Days, Father's Days, Graduation weekend, et al.

pZZw7NqDFUxIg0YT0vls8g.review_text: I may have had the best meal I've eaten in a long time last night at Park Tavern. The food and drinks were outstanding but what really put it over the top was the opportunity to sit in the best seats of the house- the chef's table.   Coming in on a Saturday night without reservations can be risky, but luck was on our side! We could have sat at the communal table at the bar, or at the chef's table- which is on the side toward the restrooms...but you get to see all the chefs working their magic and creating magnificent looking dishes. They work very efficiently and the plates they're carefully assembling look mouthwatering and absolutely beautiful. It made dining at Park Tavern dinner and a show. When I come back I only want to sit here!   The food didn't disappoint either. Some of the chefs were laughing at us because we were outright enjoying our food so much! We started with the brussel sprout chips which were AMAZING! I could seriously eat these all day, everyday. They were nicely seasoned and fried for just the right amount of time. Next, we got the duck liver mousse which was smooth and flavorful. (Note: different from foie gras, but a perfect alternative now after the state ban). The plate comes with two generous spoonfuls of the mousse, cherries, pistachios and grilled bread. Finally, we got the burger. Mmmm...from the first bite you can immediately tell all the ingredients are high quality and it just melts in your mouth! There are fries with a horseradish dip that accompany the burger which also were perfection.   From there, there wasn't much more room for dessert and we really wanted to try the Birthday Cake- so I'll be back soon for the brussel sprout chips and a slice of cake!

_OCVA417JevjE1ifcftgIA.review_text: I picked this location because it's right across the park with out door seating for my dog. I use to live in north beach and didn't get a chance to try out this restaurant. The location seems great, the food is ok. We got one of the fish dishes and it was super salty that day. I think the portions could be a bit bigger and less saltier. I don't think I would come again.

LwGSs72xqvFt0hOBZsyF1A.review_text: From start to finish this place is tops in my book!  I made a reservation to celebrate my sister in law's 30th birthday and the entire process was seamless.  We were greeted at the host stand and my SIL was wished a happy birthday right away.  That's a nice touch!  We grabbed some drinks at the bar and waited for our table and got to visually explore the mix of modern and classic style of the restaurant.  Upon being seated my SIL was again wished a happy birthday by the server!  We started off with the smoked deviled eggs, waygu beef jerky and PT fries.  Now I really need to make a strong recommendation before I continue....ORDER THE PT FRIES!!! They were amazing, I couldn't get enough!  The fries were seasoned and hot and accompanied by a soft cooked egg to one side and the egg was topped with caviar, it was the perfect dipper!  ON the other side was a truffle aioli.  We ate every single fry.  The waygu jerky was exactly as described, beef jerky....kind of an interesting app.  The deviled eggs were fine, but not something I"d explore again unless I had a craving although the jalapeno being pickled did add an interesting flavor that I was not expecting.  I ordered the scallops as did the other gentleman at our table and he loved them.  I found them salty and didn't care at all for the way the mushrooms were prepared.  I talked to the server and told him honestly, this dish was not for me.  It may just be my personal taste, but I'd prefer to have pretty much anything on the menu.  He was completely understanding and offered the pork chop.  What at great suggestion, this was one of the juiciest pork chops I have ever tried.  I almost cleaned my plate.  My sister in law got a steak that was perfectly cooked and the twice baked potato, she was really pleased.  Between the drinks, apps and entrees we were pretty stuffed, but I always look at the desert menu.  They surprised us again with a slice of their coconut birthday cake that my sister in law really loved!  I don't leave many 5 star reviews, but I'd come back in a heartbeat and recommend it to friends and anyone that asked me for a recommendation in San Francisco.

MhVGeE4WtrTHMizA89Pccg.review_text: 4 1/2 stars.  Cut down on the salt and add some desserts and it'd be 5 stars.  Great interior--adding it to my list of man restaurants.    Started with the burrata with fried lemon chips--incredibly unique, fresh and delicious.  Followed by brussels sprouts chips--soooo good! They should serve those in every bar!  Burger was okay--a little heavy on the horseradish.  Fries were a little salty.  Roast chicken was one of the best chicken I've had (probably tied with Zuni).  Crispy, spicy skin.  Served with kale.  Mixed drinks were good.  Only two dishes on the dessert menu--neither appealed to us.  Sad.  Had to go around the corner for some gelato (so not that big of a loss).  Looking forward to going back.

K5EDoSIgKJBmDLyoZdKLdg.review_text: This place has really great food. I was so excited when this opened just a block away from my house. So why the low rating?   Because every single time I've gone here, the prices have gone up. They've been open for less than a year.  Two examples off the top of my head: deviled eggs - from $1.50 each to $2 after they were featured in 7x7's 100 list. That might not sound like a lot, but it comes out to about a 33% increase. Next: the PT fries. I can't remember exactly what they used to be, but it was under $15 (probably more like $12). They're now $20!!! They're just potatoes with some truffle oil and caviar that you can't even taste.  I understand that you have to pay for quality food in San Francisco, but could the owners be any more money grubbing? I guess this is what happens when restaurant owners care more about money than loyal customers. I'm not sure if they think that the locals won't notice the large increases or if they're banking on a tourist crowd that will never know they're getting screwed, but they've definitely turned this local away for good. There are plenty of other great restaurants in North Beach that aren't money gougers.

OQhR8-T_2PZxh4Orzzof_g.review_text: I ate and drank at Park Tavern, and I'm seeing stars. Lots of 'em. The service gets stars, the cocktails get stars, the not-overwhelming, cherry-picked best-of wine list gets stars and- most importantly- the food: stars. The fried pork-belly bites with horseradish aioli are not to be missed. The whole chicken with greens was stellar (albeit a scooch salty for my taste). The yummy, cheesy twice-baked potato topped off our American Heart Association recommended meal.   I also give extra star power to the lively, lovely space the new proprietors have created. Also of particular note: these folks seem to be making a point to pay attention to the neighborhood, it's long-standing businesses, those who live here. They "bring it", but do so with a complete lack of hubris and they seem very sweetly inclined to honor North Beach's true character and long history.  Go here. You won't be disappointed.

gi3VkcISbUpd0BQ68FerAQ.review_text: Went to Park Tavern with a group of 4.  Ordered a number of appetizers and entrees.  Everything was very good and the servers were extremely friendly.  Fried lemon slices and burrata stood out to me.  I wasn't as big a fan of the burger but it was mainly due to personal taste

epgLFdVaL--qAXyRJDs1XQ.review_text: New favorite restaurant in sf. We've been trying to get to park tavern for a while now but unsurprisingly it took forever to get a saturday reservation. Annoying. Worth the wait though as park tavern lived up to the hype. One of the coolest atmospheres I've seen in a while, a great bar area and scene to have a cocktail before dinner. The vibe of the whole restaurant is lively but cozy and classy, hard to explain but pretty much exactly what I'm looking for. The hostess was very friendly and even offered us a few choices as to which table we wanted.  As for the food, top notch! Everything we tried was absolutely amazing, the only exception being the burrata which was a bit strange and not very good. Deviled eggs, amazing but I actually like wayfare's better but these are awesome as well. Demons on horseback were also a pleasant surprise that I would order again. For entrees we ordered the mussels and pork. Mussels were good and the cream sauce was something different that you usually don't see mussels in. The pork was some of the best I've tasted in a while. So tender and flavorful!! Amazing. We also shared the twice baked potato and brussel sprout chips. Both I'd consider must haves. I would say the dessert was a little bit of a letdown but by this point we were so full I didn't care that much.   Bartender, hostess, waitress were all very nice and accommodating. Prices aren't cheap but fairly standard for sf dining. Parking is tough but they  have valet if needed for 10$ or cab it. Will definitely be back ASAP had a fabulous time!!

dkkMQorZE0EF-F5wOiqA7w.review_text: I had the most delicious meal at Park Tavern last night. Great ambiance, great food, and great service. Since our meal was last minute, we weren't able to get a reservation and ate at the communal table. This was a perfect solution and was great.   Favorite food item: For sure, for me it was the venison carpaccio. Slices venison, small bite size deep friend bone marrow, and a nice portion of steak tartare made this wonderful. Lots of hidden little flavors that popped out along the way.   Gnocchi was another win. Delicious and light.   We also had the scallops and the sole. I am not sure in the future I would have ordered both of them. The sole was a little heavy and I was hoping for something lighter. By the end of that meal, I was a bit over salted, and I love salt. I think I would have ordered one or two more appetizers.   The waiter picked our dessert. (We like surprises!) When it came and I had a bite, I immediately was transported to my Bay Area childhood days- a restaurant version of an Its It. Combined with a pot of french pressed coffee and some good conversation, it was a really good night and very delicious.   I can't wait to go back.

UGf-Tcbtn12i_6XakqfTSA.review_text: Awesome service, great food, no reservations, ate at the bar, had the poulet rouge, pork chop, brussel sprout chips, bur rata with lemon chips and basil, and pork belly bites.

i8YV4FKTZ74wC3KN98XY2w.review_text: I love this spot. Great bar, great brunch, all around favorite.

6EgCpWZFRZH1MeaeeUwbag.review_text: Great dinner and, yes, the sprout chips were Super!

8fSaLfemE1G403PMJzfATw.review_text: Have been looking forward to trying out this neighborhood restaurant for a while. Finally had the opportunity to check it out for Sunday brunch with a group of friends. One great plus is that they do accept reservations and you can find them on OpenTable.  The restaurant itself is beautifully done, classic and modern which matches the food being served. They have a great selection of dishes for brunch that covers everything from vegetarian options to great American breakfasts. The wife had the Crispy Polenta Cakes that she describes as "delish." I had the Cast-Iron Baked Farm Eggs which was also an awesome dish. The food is heavy, but the portion is reasonable. The quality is very high which allows them to charge the premium prices that they do.  So why only 3 stars, you're asking yourself. Well, when we were first sat and our waiter came to take our drink order, he was obviously disappointed that we were not ordering alcoholic drinks. The whole backside of the menu is dedicated to cocktails, beer, wine, etc. But, you know, not everyone is looking to get shwasty pants in the middle of the day on a Sunday. That should not change the way that the waiter treats you. Plus, technically and for etiquette you're not required to tip on alcohol anyways, so y'know.   Anyways, we enjoyed our time and one of the other members of our party had her diet coke refilled a few times throughout the meal. When we received our bill at the end she was charged full price (somewhere around $3) each time they refilled her drink. What place does that? I understand if they're coming out with a small bottle/can each time that they would charge you. But when they're filling it at the fountain? You definitely do not expect it to be charged. If you are going to charge, at least say that when you're offering a refill and not make it seem like it's a complimentary service.  Regardless, we brought this to our waiter's attention and he did take the additional charges off of the bill. Again acting slightly disappointed with us. I will definitely be back to give them another chance, perhaps at dinner when I will be ordering a cocktail, but when you're already paying a premium price it's annoying to leave feeling like they were trying to nickel and dime you.

6LRjWUFh2va745wCJUR_CQ.review_text: Great atmosphere, beautiful design, amazing menu.  BUT...the food was not at the same level of the space or even the printed menu.  We ordered the brussel sprout chips- excellent, but they are served in a bowl, which makes eating them with others a little unsanitary and messy (it should have been served on a long rectangle plate with no recycling of licked fingers on my soon to be eaten brussel's).  We also had the mushroom soup which was delicious.  We ordered the game hen, and the presentation was fantastic, but the bird was heavily over salted which translated into extremely salty spinach at the base of the bird.  The thing is I am a salt lover, so if it was too salty for me, it must have been totally unbearable for the average diner.  We also had the pork chop and the Marlowe burger.  The chop was a healthy size, but it was cooked unevenly.  Some parts of the chop were cooked through and others boarder too rare (and not along the bone which was the strange part).  Overall this is a great addition to the dining scene in SF, with just a few tweaks, this could be my new favorite place.

_o5uRLP4wAreyGym4syR-Q.review_text: This place was so not worth it. The only good thing going for this place is the ambience, provided you have a good table.  For starters, we got stuck at a 2 person table up against a wall and squished up against another table. I can understand that table for a walk-in but with a reservation - I expect better. Then the service was totally slow. I am in no rush but don't take my drink order and walk away for 25 minutes to come back for an appetizer order. If these guys consider themselves upscale then they should offer those services. My husband and I decided to share the soup of the day. To serve us the soup, she brings a large bowl with two spoons and expects us to share that way. Come one...split the soup into 2 bowls like every other "upscale" restaurant. I had to ask them to do this. The wild arugula mushroom salad was incredibly salty so don't get that. Lastly, my husband's entree which was the steak was COLD. This place is OVERRATED.

w5H3c7rBwt0f8aftEgzqXw.review_text: Really enjoyed the avocado toast and the pancakes. Great location across from the park. Ideal brunch spot.

GCuDiPUKYxhgFHP5LqJa2Q.review_text: Two must have items for me here:  Deviled eggs, bacon, pickled jalepeño & chives - $2 ea  NY Steak crudo, horseradish, arugula & parmesan - $11  It's that good and I am happy to sit at the bar just to have these two apps with a glass of wine.  We have also tried on another visit:  Kampachi, kaffir, grapefruit & finger lime - $13 - if you like sashimi, you'll like this  Hawaiian tombo tuna, crispy sunchokes, white anchovies, baby artichokes & salsa rustica - $26 - this is SO GOOD.  Enjoy it while they have on the menu - it's such a perfect combo of everything.  LEMON CHEESECAKE PARFAIT - $8 - Huckleberries & smoked salt - not bad.  One extra app we tried last time:   Demons on horseback - $13 - large shrimp wrapped in lardo, lightly pan seared - YUM!  The Cabinet Franc under Rose - $12 - is quite good.

4zPKRBAHBOFpsqO-t3w6zg.review_text: Had dinner at the bar a few nights ago and was served by Brian - a cracker for Jeremy Piven. The place was super busy, but he was more than happy to have a chat a share a few laughs - though not suer that just because I am grey I look like Taylor Hicks. Met a lovely bloke who runs a bar down the road and the fella who owns Toast in Noe Valley. Great food, lovely beer on tap and a good crowd. Can't wait to go back, and push this rating up to a 5.

f2vy2XFVSLn60rVyuU0Aqg.review_text: Standouts include their wine (love they have glasses or carafes to order) and the appetizers - brussel sprout chips had fresh lemon taste, demons on horseback good but a little salty. Best dinner item I sampled was the chicken, which I would recommend getting versus the fish dishes (ok). Really liked the ambiance - beautiful interior, very noisy at the bar but the restaurant area is less so.

YmtwupgUhGYWZFaG4VkxCg.review_text: I just had a burger, but WOW it came out really fast and was very tasty.

TSM3dbsY9l641ICksMTlvQ.review_text: Absolutely loved Park Tavern.  The vibe is energetic and very unique with a mix of ages throughout the room.  Very cutting edge culinary creations but with tastes that everyone can enjoy.    We had an amazing waiter that gave us some wonderful recommendations.  We told him we wanted a sampling of the best small plates/appetizers they serve and just said "yes" to whatever he suggested.    Here is what we ended up getting:  *Smoked Deviled Eggs - best deviled egg I've tried, and I LOVE deviled eggs.  Comes with bacon and a pickled jalapeño slice on top.  *PT Fries covered in garlic and served with two dips - a soft cooked egg topped with caviar and truffle aioli - there also must be crack in this because I could not stop myself.  The flavors are so unique and I recommend dipping the fry in aioli, followed by the soft cooked egg before eating.  Warning - your breath will be offensive for a few days.  *Crispy Lemon Chips with burrata cheese - another unique taste that I could not get enough of.  The lemons are thinly sliced, dipped in rice flower and flash fried.  Then you have the soft and salty burrata cheese to spread on top.... oh my goodness.  Please order this.  *Demons on Horseback - prawns wrapped in lardo and covered with a creamy remoulade sauce.  Another OMG dish.  *Brussels Sprout Chips - these were OK but a little too oily.   I highly, HIGHLY recommend this restaurant. Everything we tried was delicious and the entire experience was enjoyable.

ZMocFA2lNMJeiKjguUKu7g.review_text: "YOU'RE SO HOT!" Those were the words my buddy James dared me to write on the check as we left, for our gorgeous waitress.   And when someone says "I dare you," I'm all in since I feel that my honor is at stake.  Came here for lunch and had the banana-coconut fritters, crab toast, corned beef hash, and burger.  The fritters were undercooked and James said they were "burnt," so we sent them back. I was hesitant though since I didn't want to draw more attention to use, since both of us couldn't help but notice that our waitress was stunning.  And you know me, around stunning women, I turn into a mime. Silent. Nervous. Stumbling around. Can't find my way out of an invisible box....  After we told her about the terrible fritters, she was great and took it off our bill, as James, who has enough confidence and swagger to fill the whole restaurant got her name.  She had no interest in me whatsoever, and honestly, I could have been wearing a chicken outfit and clucking and she still wouldn't have noticed I was there.  The crab toast was soggy, and had more water than mayonnaise. It also tasted like canned crab, though I'm sure it's not (or at least I hope it's not for $16).  The corned beef hash was hearty and flavorful, but I would have liked less arugula. It's not a salad after all. And the burger was surprisingly good too. James couldn't stop raving about the aioli. He could have cared less about the burger, he just wanted the aioli with fries. He's easy to please that way.  The waitress (who I won't embarrass by writing her name) was a good waitress and split the burger and fries for us so that we could share the dishes.  My only complaint was the crab toast, fritters, and 53 minute wait to get our burger and hash. Luckily, she was so gorgeous that I almost forgot the time (notice I said almost), cause it took forever to get our food. Hence the 4 stars.  We also tried the TCHO creme brûlée because she recommend it. And in my eyes, she could have recommended anchovy creme brûlée and I would have bought it.  Anyways, after James dared me, I wrote the note on the bill gave her a 23% tip, and ran like a track star out of the restaurant as James walked out casually, laughing behind me.  P.S I didn't leave my # because knowing my luck she would have called me and asked for James LOL

Jg-dWKV9juyEPNfO20zP5g.review_text: Great to meet with a small group of friends for dinner and drinks.  This place gets crowded, but the food and ambience are well worth it.  I definitely recommend the deviled eggs, as other yelp reviews have stated.  Since the menu changes a bit, it's hard to focus on select entrees.  I've had a couple of items and each were great.  Get there early to eat at the bar or communal areas next to it.  Otherwise, make a reservation.  You won't be disappointed.

ItmMMTHwCDBwLbX7Vt4T0A.review_text: wonderful restaurant and great service! The staff was great, which was surprising with how busy they were. the food was delicious and atmosphere was perfect. I would recommend this place, however the parking was somewhat of an issue and valet was not complimentary.

swmrfBnaqU0nyJ3pFBfNgQ.review_text: 3.5 stars. Jr. Yelpers say, "Not a value meal".  The place was rocking because of the massive soccer fans who crowded their way into the bar area after the World Cup soccer game.  The noise was deafening and the dining area is right next to all the noise. I witnessed a senior coming in with his group and he showed his buddy how he was handling the noise - he took out his bilateral hearing aids!  We started off with the fried sprout chips, $9.  A small bowl of green and browned sprout leaves. I've made this at home and the frying process is tedious because you have to pull each of the leaves off and quickly fry them or they burn.  It was OK.  The carrot soup was bland, $11. The butter lettuce was not remarkable.  The Marlowe burgers were the stand out and the fries were very good - crispy.  I'm not a big fan of burgers but this burger was moist and had good flavor with onions and lean crunchy bacon, $15.  The bar steak also accompanied by fries was disappointing. Jr.Yelper said the steak was chewy.  The Tcho chocolate creme brulee' was not what I expected. It had a light caramelized crust but the brulee texture was thicker and had a caramel-like flavor.    If you like burgers and fries, then come for the Marlowe burger. I didn't like the other items we tried 'tho.  Our waiter, Phil, was very professional.

buq2WXRpx2fn2NUb82h8QA.review_text: Sound level - 2 stars - Wow, what is it about these folks from down under?  All three of their places (The Cavalier, Marlow AND Park Tavern) in SF are way loud!  Could hardly have a conversation with the person standing right next to me.  Wine selection - 3 stars.  Good variety but they need to provide richer flavor whites.  Deviled Eggs - 4 stars - delicious and not greasy.  Love it  Lamb Tongue - 4 stars - yummm! Loved the balance between the acid and richness of the tongue  Bass Main course - 2 stars - over cooked and dry.  ARGH! can't stand it when restaurants overcookd their fish so it's dry and flavorless  Pork Chop - 3 stars - very flavorful but again a bit overcooked.  Tone it down boys - the meat should be flavorful in itself.  No need to go crazy  Orange Birthday cake - 3 stars - descent - cake part was airy and flavorful but it would have been more interesting if they could have balanced out the sweet with some bitter flavors.  All in all, a decent place.

WmTsrCuR3CuTCB-PlMCh0g.review_text: Park Tavern is in a prime location overlooking Washington Square Park, itself a crown jewel in the charming neighborhood of North Beach.  The difficulty in getting to the restaurant is eased by their valet parking, which is all but a necessity in North Beach. Easily worth the eleven dollar fee plus tip to not put yourself through trying to find parking anywhere in that vicinity.  We began the evening by sipping on a PT Old Fashioned and an Ed's Negroni while perusing the menu. These drinks were strong and gave us the impression that Park Tavern is going for an old school, no-nonsense approach to their cocktails. While the bartenders could certainly whip up one, don't count on seeing anything featuring egg whites on the drink menu. It also made me realize how firmly ensconced I am in new school cocktail culture. Guess I'm a wuss.  For food, we started with the NY Steak crudo, horseradish, arugula & parmesan, and the PT fries, shaved black truffle & parmesan, truffle aioli, soft boiled egg & Osetra caviar. The presentation of each was great, the fries arriving in a small urn and the crudo plate sparsely yet artfully decorated with steak, arugula and parmesan. We would have preferred that the dish arrive with a third more steak than it did, but the quality was high. Those fries were *really* good. Every bit worth the twenty dollar price. With the shaved truffles on top, dipping the fries in that egg and caviar was pretty darn divine.  We followed those nice starters with the Petit "Poulet Rouge", Bloomsdale spinach & Peewee potatoes, and the Angus Filet Mignon, twice-cooked potatoes, creamed greens & black turnip mushrooms. The standup chicken ended up requiring a lot of work to consume, but it was moist and flavorful. The filet mignon was marvelous. A generous portion that was soft and juicy, with a wonderful flavor. The juice alone elicited several 'MMmmmms' from yours truly. Both chicken and steak lay in a bed of spinach and potatoes that was tasty and complimentary.  We washed down the entrees with glasses of the Fisticuffs Cabernet Sauvignon and the Segromigno Sangiovese. I hemmed and hawed between the Cab and the Tierra Secreta Malbec. Should have gotten the latter, as I felt the Cab was a bit sweet for the steak. The tannic Malbec would have made a better pairing.  We finished up with Lemon Cheesecake Parfait and one of those boozy floats. The French 125 featured Prosecco, lemon sorbet and maybe a splash of bourbon. The parfait tasted every bit as good as it looked. Marvy.  The waiter was fairly friendly and certainly knowledgeable. The wait staff overall was attentive without being ever-present.  The noise level here is lively, encouraging you lean in a bit to hear each other. It's not however so loud that you can't hear yourself think.  The bill plus tip had us shelling out just over two bills. Not surprising given the environs and quality of the food, but also not something that we could do very often. I'd give Park Tavern five stars if the bill was 15% less.  We did like the decor and the ambiance of the place, and the wall of windows were great to take in the beauty and charm of Washington Square Park.  I'm sure that we'll be back, provided that they don't lose that valet parking...

_5uZ9Ur33MnFvpjeryyKMQ.review_text: Get the Boozy Smoothie!!!  Nice atmosphere, tasty drinks, decent food, acceptable service.  Went with a group of 12 for Easter brunch, and was lucky to snag seats at the communal table at opening.  Now I know it was Easter Sunday and we had a large group but I still think it took a somewhat unreasonable amount of time to get our food. At least some status updates from the staff would have been appreciated. Perhaps its because we were seated at opening and all the orders went in at once.   Nearly every person in my party ordered the crispy polenta cakes, veal schnitzel, or shrimp and grits and the ranking from best to worst was grits, polenta, schnitzel. It was all about the sauces here, with well executed dishes but nothing too mind blowing. Someone actually sad, "if I had all the ingredients I could definitely cook all this at home," and I agree. With all that said, I am still dreaming about the Boozy Smoothie and plan to dedicate my weekend to recreating it.

rz1NORkHaN4EdTMongud_Q.review_text: My friends took me to this new hotspot for my bday.  It was previously Mooses and is now a Chicago/New York styled Contemporary American bistro.  The decor is pretty standard East Coast fare, art deco ceilings, open kitchen etc.  We were seated at the kitchen bar, sitting next to the grill.  It was a very high traffice spot, which actually worked out nicely.  It gave us, a bunch of guys, a great vantage point to check out all the eye-candy at the bar and lots of opportunities to flirt with the babes that walked past us en route to the restrooms.    If you go to this place, take your time and order a ton of appetizers.  Their brussel sprout chips are pretty amazing.  The uni was a bit salty, in fact, everything was a bit salty.  I can't remember all the stuff we ordered but I just remembered everything was overly salty or spicely.  The steak was a bit tough and yes, salty and over cooked.  The food was just ok.  Of course, you will be stuffed when you leave because of the appetizers and bread and drinks and dessert even if you don't wolf down the main course.  The eye-candy will also fill you up!  It is a very loud and rowdy place.  My throat was sore after dinner from the shouting during conversations.  Overall, a fun place to try out once.  Not sure I would go again, but I would not deter someone from checking it out.  Having said that, there are probably other fun rowdy places with eye-candy that has better food.

sdnjNnQNpGB9OsX9fyJ0FQ.review_text: Pros: -Upscale, modern decor. Think black-and-white color spectrum, moose antlers, wooden frames, and succulents.  -Excellent customer service. Waiter was extremely attentive and accommodating. Busboys ensured that water was never less than hall empty. Hostesses were polite and waitresses cleared our plates immediately.  -Clientele was mostly upper middle class to upper class yuppies. Well dressed, and I presume well educated. An interestingly far cry from the usually SF restaurant.  -Food was spot on. Waiter's suggestion of the deviled egg single toast with pickled jalapeños, cheese, chicken, and bacon did not disappoint. Not gonna lie either, the fries on the side kind of made my day. I was less impressed with the Brussels sprouts chips, perhaps because it was overhyped on Yelp. In reality, $6 for a bowl of mini Brussels leaves seemed anticlimactic.   Cons: -Only major major major disappointment was the price to portion ratio. My friend and I were not ravenous or anything. In fact, we were mildly, or normally hungry. However, we were still noticeably hungry after $15 individual brunch plates and a shared side of Brussels chips. A tall and husky guy seated next to us ordered drinks, appetizers, two brunch entrées, and ate part of someone's burger! Definitely not enough for a normal appetite; you will either over order at Park Tavern, or continue eating your way through the city. Personally, I suggest the later potentially cheaper option!

XAjaha84plEmYX-C_BBZ7w.review_text: between the food and atmosphere this place is great

zigzaCWeF8ooSeRsksmn0g.review_text: Love the food, atmosphere and service.  First, the food is creative and delicious - we love the brussel sprout chips and deviled eggs.  The cocktails are also yummy.  The place is always buzzing - not a place for an quiet, intimate dinner.  And the wait staff is friendly.  Be prepared - the bill will put a dent in your wallet.

fGn_rT9ntIEgAyJjfQ-Vsg.review_text: love the Brussels sprout chips!! So much so I recreated them at home... Though nothing beats park's!

1ThNnn7D4cADna1g3AlvYA.review_text: Was here for my birthday dinner on Friday night and enjoyed it very much.  Loved their cocktails and all the appetizers were phenomal.  I tried the delived eggs (excellent) and truffled fried, and veal carpaccio.  There's a nice twist to all their dishes which makes it different and unique and very tasty.  Definitely will be coming back the next time I'm in town.

hMx3UP_m8PMtnOFoT1h2YQ.review_text: I don't get over to North Beach often, as it's a pain from my neighborhood (read: not served by the subway), but when I do, it's for brunch at Park Tavern. With it's black and white decor, old fashioned feel and throwback service, it's as close as I come to a white linen tablecloth brunch. The egg dishes are absolutely divine, and the french toast (which I prefer to split with a tablemate) is not to be missed. Oh, and as an added bonus for those of us who care, the crowd tends to be better dressed than at your typical SF brunch establishment (see white linen tablecloth comment above).

pohhs186WHSPKRGS_xAWAw.review_text: This appears to be the happenin' place in San Fran. Sadly, there are only twenty or so tables and most are squished very close together. Unsurprisingly, the bar was packed with yuppies and middle-aged business partners and their loud reverie carried into the main dining room. Bottom line: don't come here expecting a quiet, romantic dining experience.   The menu is short and simple, as is the main kitchen with only about six chefs prepping, cooking, and dishing food. I had the pickled carrot appetizer and hanger steak entree. Both dishes were good, but not exceptional. Our server was fantastic and extremely knowledgable about every aspect of the menu and restaurant. Everyone seemed to be having a good time.

r-8eQ28RhnQPJdZXHcTXrw.review_text: Everything we had was good - deviled eggs, lobster bisque, and Marlowe burger. It's good enough to be the go-to spot for those items.   Eggs were smokey and the pickled jalapeno gave it the bit of acidity it needed to cut into the bacon on top. The bottom of the egg has been shaped flat and sits on the plate like a bateau of smokey yolky bacon cargo.   I was actually taken aback by the punch of flavor from the bisque. The cognac (or dry sherry?) was dominant but in a good way. I couldn't quite taste crab as much as lobster but it added another layer of flavor.   The Marlowe burger tasted even better than I remembered from Marlowe. And it's worth mentioning that another amazing burger is just around the corner at Don Pisto's!  This place was poppin' at 10 pm on a Thursday night. If you make good food, people will come. When was the last new place you tried where everything was surprisingly good, when you already had expectations? If it has been too long, come to Park Tavern.   Definitely going back.

cSNER_qF_bb1t7kN0kZ44Q.review_text: I came here with a friend from out of town. I didn't want to deal with waiting 1.5 - 2 hours to eat brunch, so I decided to come here on a recommendation of a friend. Plus for having lots of open reservations on OpenTable, beautiful ambiance and decor. The food was solid, a bit on the pricier side, and didn't exactly knock my socks off.  Whole wheat toast with avocado, lemon, chili, and salt ($7) - We ordered this to share. It was good, but tastes like what you'd imagine it would taste like. Toast with avocado and a hint of lemon and spice. You can make this at home. I'd save your $7.  Confit chicken & potato hash, wild arugula & poached egg ($16) - The waitress said this was the best thing on the menu, so I had to try it (my friend and I split this and the polenta cakes). I didn't think it was the best thing on the menu. It's basically rotisserie chicken with potatoes, very little arugula and egg. It was not bad, but I was underwhelmed.  Crispy polenta cakes, wild mushrooms, poached eggs, wild arugula, truffle salsa verde & shaved parmesan ($15) - I thought this was the best - the polenta cakes were delicious, the truffle oil was abundant and all the flavors meshed together well. The yolk from the poached egg was delicious when mixed with the polenta cake.  All in all, it was a nice brunch with a great decor, and I was happy I didn't have to wait for an absurd time in line. It isn't the best brunch in the city, but the food is still great and a nice place to take guests. I was laughing at the people (or rather, tourists) waiting in line at Mama's - I was in and out of this place in one hour.

b9Q74D4XvFjJHKvLBLSaEA.review_text: My guy friend told me this place was absolutely amazing and the food was the best he ever had, so I had very high expectations when we arrived. The place itself reminded me of a few restaurants I had been in Chicago, very 50s-60s feel, trendy, young ambiance. We were seated right away and I started with a Cruel Summer cocktail, which was tasty. More so a summer drink then anything else, but still good.   Since I arrived late, as soon as I sat,  smoked deviled eggs were placed on the table. I don't eat them, but as far as deviled eggs go. they did look pretty tasty. We also ordered the PT fries, which were truffle fries and came with 2 dipping sauces, truffle & soft cooked egg with caviar. It was an interesting combination of flavors. The fries were pretty tasty. The demons on horseback app was interesting, the shrimp was good, I just didn't love how they added a ton of meat and fat onto everything we ordered. I honestly felt gross after leaving this place, too many super fatty foods and so much meat!   Anyway, I ordered the scallops for dinner and was told they ran out. That really annoyed me because they have all of 8 entree items, 4 of them non-meat, and I don't eat meat, so I was left with 3 options. and the other options didn't really excite me. I ended up with the wild atlantic cod, which in my opinion, was lackluster at best. The cod itself was okay, nothing special, and it was paired with a ton of vegetables including mushrooms, onions, fennel, and some other greens. The sauce itself was kinda bland, and overall the dish did nothing for me, I barely ate it. As a side dish I got the brown butter brussel sprouts which were tasty. I also tried a bit of my friend's butternut squash made 'au gratin', like everything else on the menu...super heavy and fattening. Not really my style.   For dessert, we got the birthday cake, which came with a candle, that was a little little touch. The cake was okay, white cake with white icing. Nothing out of the ordinary there. We also ordered the ice cream sandwiches, which I really liked. The gingersnap cookies gave it a unique touch and the caramel ice cream was delicious.  Maybe since I came in with such high expectations, I left feeling disappointed. I thought the  menu was very limited, the food was okay at best, the service was decent and the ambiance was nice, but I've been to a lot better. The meat dishes looked pretty good. Maybe if you're a huge meat eater, you'll enjoy this place more than I did.

51p6NYvYdMEVZpt2opPtQA.review_text: We had a party of six and had a wonderful experience.  Our server did an excellent job and the food was excellent.  We had "Demons on Horseback" - bacon wrapped prawns - awesome! , Pork Chop - multiple people raved about this dish, Black Cod , Steak & Halibut.  Everyone loved their meal!  We'll  be back!

Ag7IhUykVH_b3re6F-9o5w.review_text: Fabulous food! Everything we had was wonderful. You must try the brussel sprout chips! Service in the restaurant was great but the gentleman who serves drinks in the upstairs lounge is not very motivated. You are better off getting a drink in the bar while you wait, if you can get a seat. You definitely need reservations but it is worth it! I will go back and highly recommend the restaurant.

Ncr6ad2KuMhA0va0pIqGNw.review_text: Absolutely delicious! My friend and I started with the banana and coconut fritters that came with raspberry and chocolate sauce for dipping. AMAZING! They were so good and crispy and the sauces were fantastic. I had the burger with fries with horseradish aioli on the side - extremely yummy. My friend had the corned beef hash which was also good. We finished with the bread buddying which was probably the best I've ever had...Pretty affordable, great location, and good service! Only problem was finding a place to park but the food was totally worth it. I will be back!

oxvWiDWnecOrVHOeXu3Bkg.review_text: We came here for brunch on a Sunday. we thought the menu was pretty creative. We got cast iron baked farm egg with Gruyere and crispy polenta. Both were really good but we were especially pleased with the polenta. The mushrooms that came with the polenta was amazing. Open the for service was great. One of the waiters took note of the water table that we had and was kind enough to fixed it for us.
