-NY steak crudo - probably skipable as a simple beef carpaccio would have been better imo and the pieces didn't come out in nice large thin slices, rather they were kind of scattered around in small pockets of the plate. -Fried Oysters - comes in 4 and came with romaine lettuce and a sort of thousand island sauce.  Surprisingly good -Chicken Sweetbread - if you didn't know what it was, you probably still wouldn't have figured it out at the end, because this thing is rich and pretty damn amazing.  Deep fried yet retaining a moist rich center. -Deviled Eggs - needless to say, each person should get one of these  -Demons on Horseback - but not everyone should get this.  its ok, but that bacon drags on the saltiness.  The prawns are delicious but again, nothing to rave home about. -Brussel Sprout chips - still on top  Main -Poulet Rouge - excellent over a bed of kale and potatoes but indeed salty -Pork Chop - very tasty and moist -Mussels - probably better as an appetizer for many to share because this monstrosity is so damn rich I my appetite can't afford it  Sides -Creamed veggies - tasty creamed spinach -Polenta w/ seville orange and red cabbage relish - very good -Twice baked potato - kind of too much, but you should anticipate that -Brussel Sprout hearts - I see where the rest of the brussel sprouts have gone now.  hah, but nothing too great.  My new favorite spot in North Beach.  It's settled.

fD-yrOkuxnpzeVBzUVO1Jw.review_text: One tasty brunch joint (and good for dinner as well, but this review is just for brunch).  Came here on a Sunday morning about 30 minutes before our reservation time and grabbed a few seats at the bar to start off on some libations (orange juice mimosas, grapefruit juice mimosas, and a bloody mary made with beef stock.. super hearty) and avocado toasts while we waited. The toast was delicious, don't get me wrong, but not worth the $10 in my opinion. We also nibbled on some banana coconut fritters before our meals, but they were a little too fried-tasting for me and not really a light bite before the main event.  The brunch entrees, however, were divine. I ordered the cast-iron baked eggs (without the ham), two of us ordered the smoked salmon benedict, and another went for the Marlowe Burger. My eggs were cooked to perfection and were topped with just the right amount of gruyère to give them a nice bite without being over-indulgent. My fellow brunchers all gobbled up their dishes with high praises, though I didn't happen to try any of them (other than a couple of those golden, crispy, delicious fries).  On top of good food, the service was really impressive. Our waiter and his shadower were charming, friendly, attentive, and perfect on their timing and offerings.  I'd come back here for brunch again in a heartbeat.

FBAj193JsAYPcgtZyQGxyQ.review_text: Reserved a large table for a family wedding celebration.  I was able to use the private dining room upstair with not only a private bar but also a "living room" like setting next to the table with couches and chairs.  The bartender was very helpful and creative in drink and wine orders and service.   AAAAA+++.  Good variety in the menu and the management was so very accommodating.  The restaurant is obviously very popular and we had a great time.

rtNeSfIpF3U20n8kaDFM_Q.review_text: North Beach has plenty of great restaurants, bars and nightlife, but what I like about Park Tavern is that it feels like it is a little separated from all the craziness of the crowds in that area yet still close enough. Now granted, this may have been just the time we were there, so take that into consideration. I'm sure it gets plenty busy BC the smells wafting out of the kitchen were amazing. We already ate just came for a night cap before bed but none the less still and I still had a peak at the menu. The PT fries were calling to me so that will have to be saved for next time.   I think PT has a comfortable some what old timey feel. It's semi casual to the point where I thought, I'm glad I'm wearing a dress, though I'm sure you would be ok in jeans.  The staff were in more formal serving attire than your average dive bar and the atmosphere has a more upscale feel.   This is on my list to come back and try again!

xly_XuPxPPGSHk2PP3Nqnw.review_text: The food was not impressive.  We tried Park Tavern based on a recommendation from friends (dinner, walk-in, no wait). The service was good, the ambiance was good, but the food was disappointing. We had appetizers, entrees, desserts and drinks and not one thing we tried was great or even very good. The best thing we had were the drinks and they were pretty standard. Personally I would avoid the lobster bisque, it was extremely salty and not at all what you would expect.  No real complaints but I would expect much better food from a high end SF restaurant with a good reputation.

tTmeC4Gle4F5HIFMLULt6A.review_text: I came here twice in the same week - one time with my girlfriends and one time with a guy.  This place is awesome because it can cater to both.    Food - burratta on chips delicious, deviled eggs were also really good.  the steak was also delicious.  strawberry rhubarb crisp o.m.g.  Service - just wonderful.  knowledgeable and friendly staff.  Drinks - AWESOME. i love whisky and their old fashioned and sazerac hit the spot.  I'm from NYC and this place totally has the feel of a nice chic NYC lounge.

NnCB5zvAG-N9b8F43Qxp0g.review_text: Oh My Lovely Park Tavern, more than 12 visits and counting!!!    For dinner, the lobster bisque, deviled eggs, wild nettle soup, pork chop, burratta with friend lemon chips, and PT fries are deeeeeeelicious.    For brunch, the buttermilk pancakes, crispy polenta cakes w/ poached eggs/mushrooms/parmesan, the grapefruit brulee, and veal schnitzel w/ poached eggs are purrrrrrrfect.   SERVICE = OUTSTANDING BAR SCENE = AWESOME  MANY THANKS to owner/proprietress EXTRAORDINAIRE ANNA WEINBERG and chef JENN PUCCIO for bringing their outstanding restaurant scene to Washington Square Park.  (BTW - Park Tavern + Tony's Pizza + Original Joes = HOLY TRINITY!!!!!)

VdOTg5a-NbQyXcrvKjwxLw.review_text: Top notch place for a weekend brunch.  The only challenge is finding parking (especially on the weekends)!!!!  It took me about a good 20 minutes to find parking and it was a few blocks away.  The restaurant is beautifully located in North Beach so if you're seated near the window, it's a beautiful view while in good company.  I ordered the polenta cakes and the very first bite as an OMG melt-in-your-mouth moment.  Not only were they cooked to near perfection, but the mushrooms and arugula were a perfect complement.  Other hits at the table got the smoked salmon benedict, deviled egg sandwich, and the corn beef hash.  You can't go wrong with anything you order!!  Just a great dining experience here, you don't want to miss out!

-cq-v7o0sCNIqEjZKpyknA.review_text: How did they not get rated 5 stars?! As a local who lives 2.5 blocks away, I go here all the time- it's PHENOMENAL! We love great food, and this one is on my top 5 I go to of all restaurants- the best for its price range IMO.  Whenever we have friends/fm family in town we bring them to Park Tavern for an amazing meal.   Service is always attentive and informative- no matter who may serve us! I can't help but resist the creme brûlée- the salted TCHO is my favorite. Sophisticated flavors, and always leave satiated and happy.   If you haven't tried yet, GO! Delicious every time.

IyXjm7euGJOcjiZm0XbVEQ.review_text: Had brunch here with some friends and while all the food I had was good, I'm not sure I would go back on my own suggestion. There are plenty of amazing brunch places and I'm not certain the food with that price tag brings it to a higher tier for me. The service we had wasn't the best - she looked pretty annoyed the entire time and for me, a smile goes a long way.

4fNRE0uUBbso5WQiA6fu7Q.review_text: North Beach has a slew of new restaurants and this is by far my new favorite in the hood. Amazing cocktails, great wine selection and delicious food. It's also got a great vibe that fills a niche NB was lacking. Welcome Park Tavern!

frFgM9DQbewbeMznT8FofA.review_text: The TL;DR Version: AssHat Bartender. Mediocre Fare. The End.  The Full Story (It's a long one):  Early arrival calls for a trip to the bar, where we sit and peruse the house specialties. I inquire with the bartender: "Tell me about this Crème de Violette in the [cocktail_name]" to which I receive a response in the tone of someone speaking to a toddler: "It's a lavender liquor." Really? Wow. Thanks for that enlightening description.  We review the menu some more but opt for traditional drinks. My fiancée opts for her favorite, which she likes to compare across the various venues of the city, and asks: "Do you do a brandy Sidecar?"...and the reply: "Of course, this is San Francisco. Here you can get all sorts of complicated drinks."  What? Are you kidding me? You fucking *AssHat  Allow me instruct you on a few things:  1) I was inquiring about the flavor of the lavender and maybe how it impacts the overall cocktail...as a **mixologist you might want to look into it. It's on YOUR menu and you are serving it to people.  2) The Sidecar cocktail is served in a variety of forms...often with either Brandy or Cognac. Since yours is the ***second worst example I've had the displeasure to experience, you might want to take the time to visit other venues such as Zero Zero, AQ, Lark Creek Steakhouse, Top of the Mark, et. al. where there are bartenders with talent. You have none. Your lemon juice with a twist might pass on a child's roadside lemonade stand, but that's really about it.  3) For some reason you pegged us as tourists. I am personally offended to think that you go about mis-representing our fair city so rudely.   For the management: It was the big guy...the one who likes to wear watches about the size of his head.  Moments after receiving our fresh squeezed juiceboxes, we are informed our table is ready.   This bit is extra fun. So it appears that someone is very anxious to pack in as many people as humanly possible into this space. Because that is what top-dollar restaurant goers are looking for, right? And our table? Shoved into the corner where the frame for the restaurant's front sliding doors intrudes fully into the right side of where I'm sitting on the booth. For extra fun I have to sqeeze ever so carefully between the table next to us and ours, so as to not knock over anything on their table (I'm sure they *loved* my ass sliding by over their entrées) and then yoga myself into position...it was...odd. I then re-realized that I was not indeed an amputee, and still have a right arm I typically use to lift my hand so I can eat. Not here. Apparently I'm only permitted to eat left-handed. In order to use my right hand I'd have to sit in the lap of the gentleman at the next table. Awesome.  I brought this to the attention of our server, and indicated that it really wasn't acceptable and that we'd like a different table. She went and spoke to the hostess...and a few minutes later we were moved to a table by the kitchen. Much better. Nice even.  After introductions to our new server, we made our selections and started receiving our food...which is pretty much the punchline: SAUCY.  Yep. Saucy. That is how I would describe the fare. Shrimp with remoulade? (Demons on Horseback) There is more remoulade than shrimp, and they are buried in it. Blech. Something akin to what one would expect at Outback Steakhouse. My fiancée ordered the Herb Crusted Petrale Sole. It should be named "LAKE OF VELOUTE" with fish in it. I'd never seen a veloute fish soup before. She didn't eat it. As for my main dish? I've forgotten what I had. Enough said.  To the credit of the staff and manager, they did inquire about our experience...and I was earnest in my response. The manager offered to give us a gift certificate for a future visit...to which I declined. Yes, our experience was so poor I would not come back and eat here for free. My time and palate deserve better.  To really hammer the point home, we left here and grabbed a quick Uber to Hillstone for dessert and cocktails to try and wash away the crap experience.   As a final shocking side note: Upon hearing some of the highlights of our evening, do you know what Hillstone did? They comped us a round of drinks. You heard that right. HILLSTONE comped us to make up for PARK TAVERN ruining our evening.   Wow.  In S.F. we have a huge selection of amazing fare. The differentiators are the overall experience. Sorry Park Tavern, but you are far below par. I think you know where we'll be recommending friends and visitors go.  * I should note that everyone else was quite friendly, in a North Beach sortof way. (This will only make sense to locals)  ** I am using the term mixologist ironically here, in case you (the muscle-brained barback-posing-as-a-bartender) happen to be reading this. Clearly your communication skills are lacking and I want to be clear.  *** The worst sidecar I've had came with a salted rim by accident. Yes, your drink made it over this spectacular hurdle.

4go2H9Os9mJ8_mfpnnFI0A.review_text: honestly i was a little disappointed with the food here.. my cousin recommended this restaurant to me, and read the yelp reviews so i expected a lot more than i got..  Brussels Sprout Chips -- were good, very greasy Pork belly bites, horseradish aioli- tasty however, some of them were just battered deep fried chunks of fat with no meat Deviled Eggs, bacon, pickled jalepeño & chives-- one of the best things.. maybe we should have listened to the waitress and gotten more than just 2  Seared scallops, roasted cauliflower, braised baby fennel & grapefruit --meh nothing special.. didn't finish them  my friend got the pork chops-- all he said about it was that he's had better somewhere else...  maybe the food was just too rich, or maybe we just ordered fatty foods, or maybe we didn't order the right dishes, but i didn't finish my food, and i left hungry

_2LP_5bMK1MLW3nCn4CsEg.review_text: One of my new favorite spots in the City. Take a date, take your wife or just go get a drink. Food is great and it won't dent your wallet.

9FGBx0Dti-cPsbzduoMRzw.review_text: There isn't too much to say about this place other than it's a must try. 5's all around from service, atmosphere to food and the food is as good as it gets.   I have been for dinner and brunch, both are amazing.   Tip: If you go for brunch you have to check our their selection of "toasts", our table only ordered two and wished we had tried them all!

ra3OzaxpILytSjHRRKoT8g.review_text: The deviled eggs and a burger for a late night meal pretty much hit the spot.  A good add to NB from the Marlowe folks.

n-llq13RHyMuEwjdvGZHhg.review_text: There's good food everywhere in the city, so comparatively speaking, I would give Park Tavern 3 stars. It's located right by Washington Square Park in North Beach, so it's super convenient and popular.   I will say that the service here is great. Our party had a reservation, but we had to wait an additional 10 minutes for the waiters to clean the table. In return, we got free brussels sprout chips. Our waiter was also super effusive and happy to explain everything on the menu and make recommendations. He actually recommended one dessert we didn't end up liking, so he comp-ed that. Um, amazing.   As for the food, I really liked the pork chop. However, the poulet noir was a little underwhelming. The chicken was dry, and for $28, I'd expect something a little bit more special. They also have an amazing dessert menu, so definitely check that out.

OFPNE_TTnl9TAEQxrTK23w.review_text: SF is a city of brunch. Mama's is right nearby and you get to see the hype that envelops SF brunch. In come Park Tavern. Same people behind Cavalier and Marlowe (my favorites) ... and it shows. Again, brunch is ubiquitous in SF so I'm hard pressed to find a favorite amongst it all, but here's my story:  Mama's had nearly a two hour line. Unless I poop golden eggs after eating there I decide to bail and head over to Park Tavern. I get a table for two within five minutes. Finish my meal of a great mimosa and poached eggs (try anything on the menu, it all seems great, even the famed burger for brunch).  I'm very pleased and leave only to see the same people still waiting outside of Mama's and clearly starving, cold, and from out of town with another 15 minute wait. Is the choice hard? Not at all. Check it out here. Make a reservation, it's easy. Done.

gnKBZLBXrajrJ2-WB0vvtA.review_text: I can't say enough great things about this place. I adore Park Tavern. Love the location, love the interior, love the vibe, the service, the food, the drinks... everything. The Poulet Rouge - a MUST. The mussels are fantastic. The cocktails are great. I can't wait to go back again.

f7GHfM9noxPt2u90hpUQoA.review_text: The waiters here are very nice and attentive. Overall, the food is amazing and although it is a bit pricey it is worth it! Here is a list of the items my friends and I tried in order of my most favorite. 1. PT Fries- Freaken amazing with the truffle oil aioli and soft egg with caviar.  Order this whether or not you are hungry. You will regret it if you walk out without trying it! 2. Crispy Lemon chips- Perfect bite of sourness and crunch to be eaten with a side of buratta. 3. Venison carpaccio and crispy bone marrow- just a small bite is enough. 4. The Bar Steak- I only liked the edge of the steak. 5. Seared Scallop- the scallops were delicious but small and not worth the price. 6. Grilled Pork Chop- I'm not a fan of pork chops so this dish was ok. 7.Banana Bread Pudding- a hybrid of banana bread and a s'more. 8. July's Birthday Cake- I really liked just the cake I could pass on the compote as it made it mushy.

de2YMVs3tPEm_5a0XUQHRw.review_text: The food is great, but the music doesn't fit. Maybe you shoud hire the company I use- mixtemotions.com

4-el2XeaLCVp1wFMhSk5yQ.review_text: I love this place. The staff is friendly and professional and the food and drinks never disappoints. The brussel sprout chips are a must. My favorite is the bar steak, and my husband always order the pork, but the deviled eggs, demons on horseback and burger are all lovely too. Let the bar staff mix you a Moscow Mule and just enjoy.

vhb3c8RMTN76kqVMKi534Q.review_text: Great waiter and lemon chips; the only positives about our experience.  Unfriendly hostess after we requested a different table than the one she tried to squeeze us into for our reservation.  A snotty, impatient, female bartender who turned us off to ordering drinks while we waited for our new table.  Ahi tuna that consisted of tuna "nuggets" and greasy vegetables, and a dry burger and cold fries.  It was also a rainy night and we didn't get much help when we needed a taxi back to our hotel.  We had to call and wait outside in the rain for 10 minutes.  Never again.

UvmKLvE5_OCRrzFcuCFJYg.review_text: One of the best meals I've had in a long time. Impressed by everything:  country lawyer, deviled eggs, brussel sprouts chips, tuna and poulet. Love.

2n3WLa-YgmunK5JEOBgkXQ.review_text: Went here for brunch. Definitely make a reservation for this place on the weekend to avoid a wait.  I booked the day before and was able to get the time I wanted.  The inside is open and spacious and they have outdoor seating for a warm day.  The polenta and poached eggs is the go to item.  And the chalah cinnamon & sugar toast is delicious.  They have fun, creative twists on cocktails.  I usually get the burger which is good, but this time was a little on the salty side.  Our server, without me asking, immediately took it off and offered up something else.  Awesome customer service!

7cOOloHqCWovDAcpBJUatg.review_text: This is my new favorite place!  With a gorgeous classic with a twist brasserie design, overlooking Washington Square, it's an easy walk from my office downtown.  I arrived a bit early for my reservation, but the host kindly seated me in a prime spot, where I had a lovely, if slightly sweet drink, while waiting for my husband.  Just as he arrived, our waitress brought the drink that I had requested for him--perfect timing!  Do have the deviled eggs--two halves for each of us made a great appetizer, full of creamy-crunchy-spicy (with the jalapeno) flavors and textures.  We also had the lemon chips (yum!) with green hummus (pretty darn good), steak tartare (really good and generous portion) and NY strip steak with fries.  The sommelier was very engaging and helpful, and we ended up ordering a wine that I had thought about earlier in the evening, by coincidence.  All in all, a wonderful experience.

sAqu1ueoTR-eK8rQiFkO0w.review_text: Pt fries- uh mazing. loved the truffle fries and the egg and cavies dipping 5/5. Pork chop- best I've had. Better than nopas and  portion was huge. Duck - fancy, well made. 4/5 Marlowe burger- great truffle flavor and juicy meat. Bun was a little soggy 4/5. Brussels chips- nicely fried and tasteful 4/5. Deviled eggs- absolutely gourmet. Loved the oil infused egg with the bacon topping. Best I've had 5/5. Chocolate brûlée - delish. Nom nom. Not too sweet. Just right. 4/5

KLBjY4ZNrQlpFfWe58xPHQ.review_text: I came here for brunch with the boyfriend, he ordered the avocado toast, grapefruit brulee, and I got the crispy polenta cakes. All of them were unique and tasty - if I had a second stomach or had classy sweatpants on I would've tried the Marlowe burger and the fried duck egg sandwich because those just sound amazeballs!   The avocado toast is a simple concept but it was executed well, the grapefruit brulee was a light addition to what would typically be a heavy brunch meal ,ad the crispy polenta cakes were filling enough to make my belly happy.   Parking was rather difficult, we ended up parking in a garage because we didn't want to stalk nice people in hopes of taking their parking space. It is also a more classy venue that is beautifully decorated inside.

v5W0Sr1pG_n2bg7-ECL89A.review_text: Great new restaurant!  Location off the park is charming, the decor inside was really cool...very well done...and there are a number of sidewalk tables for outdoor dining...if the SF summer ever ends...the food was excellent...top items from our table were the lamb, NY steak, Marlowe burger and polenta.  We will go back.

x2UTV2QvCiClAnkYPegQuA.review_text: My first time here was great!  We had reserved a table for two at around 7:30pm on a Wednesday night, however it didn't seem like we needed one because there were a few tables still open.  The restaurant is fairly loud due to the popularity of the bar, and it happened that we caught the tail end of happy hour.  Decor and set up were great!  It has a very rustic feel, and the best seat in the house (in my opinion) is the two counter seats near the open kitchen where you can enjoy the chefs hard at work!  Now onto the food!  Since me and my girlfriend are lightweight foodies, we generally like to sample a variety of things on the menu.  We started off with the deviled eggs.  We ordered one each because we had a lot of food coming, but it was so good we ordered another round!  I could have easily eaten 20 of these.  It is definitely the best I've had in a while.  We also ordered the Uni, brussel sprout chips, demons on horseback, and the lobster bisque.  The uni was very fresh, and up there with some of the best Japanese restaurants.  The bussel sprout chips were alright, and it's something that I'd probably never order again.  However, the demons on horseback was delicious!!!  It's basically 4 huge pieces of prawns wrapped in bacon, and their oh so delicious sauce.    The lobster bisque was a something we added in the middle of our appetizers because there was a party of 15 people behind us, and they each ordered it.  So we thought why not order one too to share?  And it turns out that party did us justice.  The bisque was savory, sweet, and rich.  A little too rich when you kept eating it.  If you order this, make sure to share because I think it definitely tampered with the rest of my meal.  Although it was delicious, the flavor kinda coated my palette and made everything thereafter too salty.  For our entrees we ordered the Cod, and the grilled pork chop.  The Cod was very average, and it didn't really possess any flavor to me.  Again, this could be due to the bisque.  My grilled pork chop was definitely too damn salty due to the bisque.  I only managed to eat a quarter of it because I started to get full, and the saltiness was a turn off.  However, I did bring it home and ate it the next day, in which it definitely held up very well.  It also tasted much better the next day, but I'm sure it tasted great the first time they made it!  So ultimately, the bisque is really good.  Just don't eat too much of it because it's heavy, or pair it with a burger.  Deviled eggs, and demons on horsebacks are both winners!  Definitely coming back!

Jbz_fg5qxAc5iGHyQKwsdg.review_text: Went here on a Saturday w/ my boyfriend when he was in town. I tried to get a reservation through Opentable for 2 for a 7:30-8:30 timeslot and that was impossible. The only time slots they had open were for a 6 pm slot and then something around 9ish. Yep. They are THAT busy. I ended up calling in and we were able to get a seat at the chef's counter at 7:45 for 2. So, if you have a small party (1-4 people) and don't care TOO much about where you sit, try calling in and seeing if they have any space at the chef's counter.  When we went here, the restaurant was REALLY busy so service was only okay. Our server did come in and check in on us and apologize for not being super attentive. Water was consistently refilled though. We got: lobster & crab bisque, deviled eggs, pork chop, and the petit chicken. The appetizers were AMAZING. As was the pork chop but the petit chicken was only okay. It was cooked well but was sort of bland. The spinach and potatoes at the bottom was also oily and meh. Cool concept though. Honestly, I'm super excited to go back again and will go soon!

4lPsxyR8W73pbebQnFW-lw.review_text: I was able to get a reservation for brunch very easily. Dinner reservations are a bit harder to get.  The hummingbird cocktail is delicious. I love sweet fruity champagne cocktails. The food was pretty good. The smoked salmon on toast was excellent. The crab crostinis were good too.  Hard to find parking in the area. Took the 30 bus and just crossed the park to the restaurant. Our server was a bit standoffish. Forgot to get her name.  But overall a good brunch place.

AsaiS-Sw3_cgDYv73FJ-4w.review_text: Just stumbled on this place when we were walking around North Beach. Went in for lunch after we saw the line at Tony's. Food was very, very good. Pretty place too and just across from Washington Square Park. Definitely would go back next time we are in S.F. to try their dinner fare.

zO9Z4y6JbyiMYDplbmUc8Q.review_text: Food: 4 Stars Service: 3 Stars  Finally some good food in North Beach with a full bar and foodie worthy menu.  The atmosphere is casual yet upscale and trendy.  The acoustics are not great, it's very loud with the walls, tables, tile floor, it is hard to hear each other and the tables are very small, too small for the food you get, which makes eating a juggling act.    We had a glass of wine and beer to start.  The food, we had the fried oyster Caesar, excellent flavor combination, the oysters were like butter and the Caesar was fresh and bright that balanced the richness of the oysters.  Then came the soup, my husband loved it but I thought it was just OK, a bit too salty but nice on a cold night.  The steak tartar was more like carpacio and I didn't taste the horse radish at all, even though the dish came highly recommended.  We finished with the steak and peppers, again both excellent, and great for splitting.  The espresso was not great, too sour for my taste.    The service was not great, they dishes were never cleared in time, new silverware was not served and dishes were not switched out when clearly we should have had a clean plate for the next course.  The waitress was nice but not around much.  I would definitely come back for the food, there is lots more to try on the menu and bar.

AIItwMHenH6w3tqwJVIBDA.review_text: Great meal.    The lemon chips and burrata are great.  I'm sure you look at them on the menu and think "what's a lemon chip?"  Don't worry about that and just order it.   The deviled eggs are also good, but the lemon chips are where it's at.  My GF had the scallops and I had the Poulet Vert.  She said the scallops were great and the woman at the table next to us was coveting her scallops.  At one point, after hearing the woman continue to talk about the scallops said "why don't you pick up your fork and ask her for some..."  So, if a scallop dish can make your neighbor drool and continue to talk about them, it's probably worth a try.  The poulet vert is good too.  It's a little awkward to eat since it's impaled on the pan (roasted vertically as if it is was on a beer can) but it's really good.  At first, I was like "baked chicken (cornish hen)" that's not really exciting.  But I figured I'd give it try.  (I asked the server what she thought about it, and she said it was as good as Zuni's which I was unimpressed by).  But, I'm glad I tried it.  It was juicy, and definitely a generous serving (I only ate half of it).    Do yourself a favor, make a reservation and go all out.  I don't think you'll regret it

PxH2Ibb3hq7wwW_gJxQmGg.review_text: Went in for brunch, had the michelada (great spicy and saltiness for a drink) and the oatmeal pancakes. Had to ask for extra syrup, other then that it was spot on (three huge pancakes!).  My partner had the polenta which also was great.   Service was awesome.

KLklNBuBa5Xp2t0ffihMMA.review_text: Awesome food!  Parking here is a huge pain but the experience was worth it.  Friendly hostess willing to seat when entire party isn't there yet (cuz of parking nightmare).  Having valet is good.  Fries with soft cooked egg w caviar is great!  Impressed the head chef did quality control on dishes and actually sent some back that didn't meet her quality standards.  Dessert was creative and tasty.  Drinks were good but expensive.  Brussels chips are delicious and just like Marlowes, though I'm a bit turned off by the doubling up on Brussel sprouts where we pay for the chips and again for the sides.. For essentially the same Brussel Sprouts :p.   Summary:  yummy food with great service and I would return.

6-wQM1i5a5IYhqxF7MWcGQ.review_text: I am a big fan of Marlowe so was looking forward to checking out Park Tavern. This last weekend, I went here with a friend. The valet parking is perfect since as most of you know this neighborhood is almost impossible to park in after 7 PM. The space is really nice and we scored a corner table where we were able to see the entire dining room and also the open kitchen. Our server seemed very green - he had a difficult time telling us what the specials were for the evening. He wasn't able to remember what they were exactly. Seemed a bit odd, but not a big deal. He took our drink order and then came back a few minutes later saying they would be right up and took our order. We of course ordered the much talked about deviled eggs which deserve all of the praise that they get! But strangely these came to our table first, then a few minutes later, our drinks arrived. After we polished off the eggs, then the bread arrived. Just a very strange order of things. For starters, I ordered a salad with white asparagus, hearts of palm and avocado - it was delicious and had a nice refreshing taste. Exactly what I was looking for. My friend had the warm chicories which was also very tasty. Then our mains arrived - this is sadly where our meal took a turn. I ordered the petite poulet rouge. The presentation was impressive but I noticed that the bird looked a bit burned and the vegetables also were overcooked as well. The dish was a bit bland and needless to say, I was disappointed. My friend ordered the "Marlowe" burger and it was also unimpressive. Not bad or anything but nothing really special either. We ordered the lemon cheesecake parfait to share for dessert. There was barely any lemon flavor to the dessert. I have to say that I probably won't  be rushing back here anytime soon. But if I do go, I might just stick to their starters!

1Cb9fUiWlYzE9v5OP2jcvA.review_text: It has taken me awhile to write this. I had two good experiences at this establishment within a week.   First was breakfast. The line at Mama's was ridiculous and we had walked from PH and did not want to wait. We did eventually eat there, as well, check out the review if you want (not good).  Our breakfast was excellent. We shared the Pomelo & Avocado w/cottage cheese & cracked black pepper. After a couple of mimosa's, I ordered the Crispy Polenta Cakes (wild mushrooms, poached eggs, arugula, truffle salsa verde & shaved parmesan) and J ordered the Pan-Fried Corned Beef Hash (crispy potato, poached egg, arugula & red wine jus). Excellent brunch.  A few days later, J and I returned with N for dinner. We intended to go to Tony's , but forgot they he's closed on Tuesday. Since we had such a nice brunch at Park Tavern, and it was just a block away, we stepped into the bar. There were not any seats available at the communal bar table so we waited. It was a great opportunity to sample a cocktail and peek at the orders as the servers passed by. Wait was about 10 min.  Our order, which the three of us shared:  FRIED SUNCHOKES creamy harissa & lemon zest BROWN BUTTER BRUSSELS SPROUTS parmesan & chili flakes  STORYBOOK MOUNTAIN VINEYARDS "Anteaus," Napa Valley, 2009  "MARLOWE" BURGER caramelized onion, cheddar, bacon, horseradish aïoli & fries  THE BAR STEAK  12oz c.a.b. hanger french fries & buttered red wine jus  All were tasty, but our favorites were the brussels sprouts and the bar steak. The Storybrook was a good value. Our sunchokes were overcooked and we did not eat them, nor did we complain, but our server noticed, and offered to take them off the bill.  Much appreciated!  Overall, great service and great food. Wanting to go back now!

USHuirBWMj-UTiRZ1rpXsQ.review_text: I heard about Park Tavern in an edition of Man's World that I purchased in Paris.  Being from SF, I was surprised that I didn't know about this place, and it was great that I learned and went to it.    It was a nice change of scenary for me, since its located in the heart of Little Italy.  You'll find locals and tourists.  Locals will be dressed up; tourists...the usual attire for them (very casusal).  The service was excellent, but it was pretty noisey.   The food was excellent.  If you want steak and pork, this is the place for you.  I had the pork, which was amazing with a great portion.  The starters are a good size too.    The cocktail list is pretty broad and they have a wide selection of wine.  The desserts were amazing.  We had the cake of the month (celebrating my partner's birthday) and we had a Captain Crunch ice cream sundae.  I'm not a big dessert person, but I'll admit that these were amazing!  We'll definitely go again.

c4bNOJ5XnKKoHJoQE4zrcQ.review_text: Always a neighborhood favorite! Their cocktails are phenomenal, and the food never disappoints. My husband had the chicken and we were fighting over half o it! I had gnocchi and the twice baked potato, nothing was greasy and the flavors were great. If you are looking for a nice dinner that won't necessarily break the bank this is it!

g_1Rr2ufemX54uWAkn0ysw.review_text: I loved this restaurant from the ambiance to the service to the food.   Our waitress and waiter (she switched out halfway through) were both the perfect balance of hands off and speedy service.   the food: i LOVED the heirloom tomato tart for starters - it was covered with creamy buratta and the dough was a puff pastry - what more could you want?   my main dish was a delightful mahi mahi and we tried BOTH brussel sprouts (the started chips and the "side").  The starter is basically the outside leaves of brussels fried up into "chips" and the side is the remainder of those brussels cooked to perfection. I took half of them home, the portions were hardy.

iu70nwr37uHgwpob-yscxw.review_text: Lovely, for brunch and dinner. The venue is gorgeous with amazing woodwork and staff. Beautiful bar. Enjoyed a great brunch here with a friend, had reservations and I was absolutely delighted with not only how delicious the food was bud how friendly the staff was as well! Right by the park--when my family comes to town I plan on bringing them here for a treat of a meal. Prices are on the higher end, but well worth it. I'm excited to come back here for a fancy dinner with my girlfriends soon!

5Z5KUZ15rwWCM0ItYh4mXw.review_text: Park Tavern is excellent. Bravo!  Definitely a gem in North Beach.  Excellent space, great bar and cocktails.  How do you make ordinary fries extraordinary?  You add a soft boiled egg with caviar as a dip. Duh !  Gnocchi was different than any gnocchi I've had.  Great  Deviled eggs. Yum  Steak.  Cooked perfectly and leaves a nice char taste in your mouth.  I shall be back here.

IprKHet03baoU8heBOYuwQ.review_text: Came here for Friday Lunch:  Location: Parking is difficult (unless you get lucky) but there is valet or a parking structure down the street. Park Tavern is right by Washington Park.  The space: Decor & ambiance is nice and I loved the classy with a hint of rustic feel.   The food: - CRISPY LEMON CHIPS: (4 stars): Thin fried lemon chips... surprisingly, it wasn't sour and you can taste just a hint of lemon. I liked the dip that came with it. For the price ($15) I expected more chips... serving size was way too small.   - HEIRLOOM TOMATO & BURRATA TART: (3 stars): Tomatoes & cheese cover this crispy thin bread. You must really like caramelized onions to order this because the flavors really overwhelm this dish.

DUCVhBH9quiMZo5phvNzIw.review_text: So few are the times I go to a restaurant I have never heard of, have no expectations for and are completely blown away! Park tavern did just that. Before the service even started I immediately felt at home in the warm ambiance of this large, yet intimate dining area. I wish I remember our servers name but suffice to say she was impeccable. Extremely friendly and when we had some questions on wine she gladly sent over the sommelier who was great as well. We tried the deviled eggs, duck pate, twice baked potato, burrata and tomatoes, and the steak. All the food was prepared very well. I loved the twice baked potatoes! The combinations were very inventive and I was impressed when each order came out. Another thanks to our waitress who was very conscious to stagger when our orders came out providing a perfectly seamless dining experience.         Never did I think that a dish lacked a certain "somthin".  Do yourself a favor and take your next date night to park tavern!

_enOJvG4pYCF4L3GKmA1xA.review_text: I came here with my roommate on the recommendation from a local friend (I'm from NY).  Overall a great meal and certainly was busy on a Tuesday night.  Here's the rundown:  We started off with their Deviled Egg's, Dungeness Crab dip, Wagyu beef jerky, Kampachi, Devils on Horseback and Rabit, Duck & Foie Gras Terrine (yes we eat a lot and exercise to make up for it).  Everything was delicious.  The Terrine was really really rich and for the amount of food we ordered, might have been a little overkill, but it was still delicious.  I was a huge fan of the kampachi and probably my favorite from the app's.  We ended up splitting our entree's.  I got the tuna while he got the pork chops.  The tuna was cooked perfectly and presentation was nice.  The pork chops were good, but a little too salty for my taste.  I also had their Old Fashioned and something similar to the Old Fashion (can't remember the name).  The Old Fashioned was really smooth and probably not for my own good!  Atmosphere is definitely loud and they were playing modern rock (Black Keys, White Stripes, etc).  I would definitely recommend this place!

Uh6zrk0v1v9kFVPNdBLR6w.review_text: Came here around noon after a wedding at St. Peter and Paul's on a Saturday.We were seated at a booth right away. Hubby and I got the cast iron skillet eggs and the crispy polenta cakes with poached eggs and mushrooms topped with Parmesan. Mushrooms smelled strongly of truffle oil but the taste wasn't overpowering. Went perfectly as a bite altogether especially with the yolk from the perfectly poached eggs. I wish they had a side menu to add extra protein as hubby only had a slim slice of ham on top. Hubby's plate looked pretty but the flavors weren't strong enough for me. Kind of pricey for the size of the dishes at $12-$18/plate but it was tasty and the service was excellent. I recommend but don't come starving. Or go get some gelato around the corner.

9Y0nDI1K97QReyQjHUQxWw.review_text: Pretty surprised to see such positive reviews for this place. Went in for late dinner last night and was underwhelmed. With tip, we spent 90 bucks for two entrees, one appetizer, and one glass of wine, which I felt was steep.  The good first - service was friendly, and reasonably together for such a new place. It's beautiful in there - I loved being in Moose's, and they have lightened up the decor and made it even better. My friend ordered the mussels which were a very generous serving, and had a great flavor.  The bad - the watermelon/prosciutto appetizer that everyone is cooing about did not work for me - the flavors with the truffle and the lemon zest were too disjointed. I also was not crazy about the scallops (which, by the way, set us back 27 bucks).   I will definitely go back to enjoy the decor with drinks, but (big) if I ate it would be some of the "safer" options (the Marlowe signatures like the burger and the brussels).

mrXim_3tiYt3FuIf3lSRYA.review_text: Lotsa reviewers telling you the highlights...just adding a couple of helpful hints if you're going.   Super friendly, superfast parking valet right out front is a must have in North Beach if you've got $12. At first was taken to a table near the kitchen.  Place is noisy enough already so asked for different table.  Absolutely no problem. Halibut was great. Asked for a wine recommendation and the waiter brought four glasses with tastes.  That's service worth 20%

Mcy_SkMnb8HXo7JRVcl02A.review_text: I really enjoyed my dinner at Park Tavern.  They serve one of the best pork chops I've had, and delicious deviled eggs.  The wine list is ample (but not cumbersome) and reasonably priced, and the service was solid.  My only complaint is the noise level.  I really had to struggle to have a conversation.

NBpFrGASLnxaypa3PZL_9w.review_text: Sometimes the kids table is the most fun place to be at a gathering.  We were a last-minute party of six and ended up at the "short table" in the bar. When you go, you'll know the one we were at. It turned out to be a great spot for people watching, drinking and dining. I would not have changed a thing.  Upon arriving, we were greeted with champagne and the restaurant's signature deviled eggs. These are not your Aunt Myrtle's deviled eggs. These flavorful deviled eggs benefit from the picked jalapeno and piece of thick smoky bacon on top. They were terrific and I could easily see us going back just to have a pint of Anchor Steam and those eggs. But, last night we forged on.  The next course was porcini mushroom soup. As you know, mushroom soups are usually cream flavored with mushroom. Not at Park Tavern, this was a dense, flavorful, all mushroom cup of soup served with a garlicky piece of sourdough with parmesan on top. Very earthy and perfect for a chilly evening.  Then came prawns wrapped in lardo, which is of course thin petals of fat. The fat actually cooks off so all you are left with is the smoky essence of the lardo on the very fresh, perfectly cooked prawns. This was a winner. The lemon chips with burrata were good, though not earth shattering. The signature brussel sprout chips were not available, because it's not like you can just go down the street and buy brussel sprouts at any market at this time of year. Oh, wait, you can.  For our entrees, we tried a little of everything. The steak is actually a New York served with braised Kobe beef on the side. I was wondering why a chef would braise Kobe and drain all the fat out of it since Kobe beef is all about the fat, but the plate was one of the first to be cleaned completely. The first member of the clean plate club was the pork chop, which is served on ribs that must be picked up to be fully appreciated.   Two of us had the seared scallops served on greens with these amazing beans served pieces of pork belly. I loved mine while the other diner found her's to be too salty. If you like salty pork belly, then this is probably a great dish for you. If you are looking for a light seafood dish, then this may be too hearty and salty for you.  For sides, we had twice baked potatoes, which are not for people shy about flavor and fat, and wild mushrooms. I personally thought the wild mushrooms were the winner. They were oven roasted with thyme and rosemary and had a simple, earthy flavor I really enjoyed. They went great with the beans and pork belly that came with the scallops.   For drinks, a couple of us enjoyed the Southern Lawyer, which is little more serious Knobb Creek take on sweet vermouth and bitters than your standard Manhattan. The fresh orange peel in the drink just makes it. You need two of these.  The service was professional, responsive, always there when you wanted them to be, yet laid back and unpretentious. We never felt rushed and our server was happy to guide us to his favorites without sounding condescending.   The atmosphere, as advertised on Yelp, is indeed trendy and casual at the same time.   The wine list is not for bargain hunters. Plan on spending $70+ for a mid-range bottle of wine.   So, if you are one of the cool ones, or, like myself, aspire to be surrounded by people cooler than yourself, I'd recommend Park Tavern for a romantic evening or a fun place to bring your group of friends.

TLdtuZm6Ms0V22I6htXBaQ.review_text: Delicious!  We really loved the appetizers.  You must try the:  Crab dip Deviled eggs Liver mousse Brussels sprout chips  The Poulet Rouge was moist and delicious-- worth the wait.  The lobster bisque was probably my favorite item on the menu.  It was rich, creamy and you can actually taste the lobster.  And the Washington Square was great with just the right amount of alcohol so it's strong, yet tasty.  We loved the ambiance.  It was dark, but felt lively.  A perfect spot for a date or group dinner as they have a number of larger tables.  I cannot wait to go back!

ejwapyrOBwNBdJ1ebnGOjw.review_text: Holy crap, I'm so bad w/ names. My friend and I came here after grabbing brunch at Mama's. We wanted a place to relax and have a drink and this was definitely a good choice.  We were immediately seated at the bar. Although I can't tell you the bartender's name or the drink(s) I ordered, I can tell you that he was very nice and the drinks were super good. We told the bartender what kind of drinks we liked and he made us something delicious! He was super nice and friendly.  I saw the food people around me ordered and it all looked so good.  Note: the toilet in the second stall in the women's bathroom is super crooked. I thought I was drunk at first!

ezl7zdH20iGFmM8Uv8tT7A.review_text: Yelpers high-remarks disappoint again.  Great atmosphere BUT NOT WORTH THE MONTH+ reservation wait NOT WORTH the tough parking NOT WORTH emptying my wallet on food that's not impressive  What are you ppl thinking?!!!

cCPjASKs5YpMB4BmN2oSZg.review_text: Finally I'm reviewing Park Tavern. I felt like ordering half of the new season's menu. My friend had just worked out and couldn't help me indulge my wandering food eye.  While the burger, my main motivator, wasn't the best in the city as friends had told me, it certainly was very good. Candidly, ordering it in such a nice setting concerned me by perhaps passing up on more adventurous items.  Pro move: Consider limiting your prior meals to build the hunger. You'll enjoy the additional time, and of course the food and drink, at Park Tavern.  Demons on Horseback? Yes, of course. Fried sunchokes? Most definitely. Smoked deviled eggs? No, but only because I've eaten them so often at Marlowe. Seared scallops? Oh, they were excellent. Grilled pork chop. Nom nom.   Yes, the burger was not my only entree. Sigh.

ETftGvDC7MVbN9pkPPSV2g.review_text: Park Tavern has my favorite brunch in the entire city. There are so many delicious carb-laden delights too choose from that I always have trouble deciding what to get. I wish I could eat three brunches in a day just to try everything. Five stars for the brunch!  For dinner, the menu has some solid items and they are executed professionally, though for me they do not have the same allure as the brunch items. Service is always top notch and the space itself is pretty neat with the high ceilings with exposed wood beams. The location across the street from the park is quite pleasant for outdoor seating on nice days.

-g3XIcCb2b-BD0QBCcq2Sw.review_text: Greg and I had been wanting to try out Park Tavern for awhile, especially since the American restaurants have been a huge success in San Francisco (namely Wayfare Tavern, Bix, and Baker & Banker) in our opinions.  I took Greg here for an early birthday celebration last Friday night, and I was surprised with how amazing and vibrant the crowd was there.  Usually when I think of North Beach, I think of late night pizza, King of Thai, and cheesy Italian restaurants.  Park Tavern, however, is a total gem right by Washington Square Park.  We showed up to our reservation just about 20 minutes early, so we were prepared to sit until our 9:15pm reservation was ready.  Just as we were getting comfortable at the bar, we got seated!  The whole restaurant is a little on the noisy side, and while normally sitting in the back corner is a bad thing, I actually think that this made the whole experience that much better.  We were shielded away from the noise, and got our own private nook right by the kitchen.  I had done some research on the place (thanks Yelpers!) leading up to this, so once we sat down, I knew almost exactly what I was ordering.  And the decision went as follows: -Twin Peaks and Panhandle cocktails.  Personally, I thought my drink (the Twin Peaks) was better than the Panhandle.  But the bourbon and lavender combination in the cocktail was unique and definitely tasty.   -One deviled egg. Yes. Just one.  Isn't it awesome that you can order things that way?  Now, Prospect has exactly the same style of deviled egg, and while this one tiny appetizer was amazing, I have to say that the deviled egg battle goes to Prospect.  Still, it was an impressive take on something that is usually meant for Super Bowl finger food. -Brussel sprout chips.  It's true Yelpers, this is exactly as awesome as everyone proclaims them to be.  Greg typically doesn't like brussel sprouts (I'm just coming around to them), but the one word we both used to describe these are "addicting".  You couldn't just have one without wanting to dig back in and have more.  I would definitely say that this is one of those things where I attempted to clean the bowl without licking it. -Classic Angus steak tartare, quail egg, wild arugula & grilled baguette.  In comparing to our previous experiences with steak tartare, this was definitely good appetizer, and I would definitely encourage people to get this, but this comes in second in comparison to Bix's version.  Like I said, the arugula and baguette that comes with the dish is a nice pairing together. -Both of us ordered the Marlowe burger and enjoyed every bite of it.  I was tempted to order the Poulet Rouge, except cutting through a chicken that size seemed a little intimidating.  We ate everything on our plate.  And I mean, everything.  For something under $20, I thought this was a complete steal. -Earlier on we had ordered the artisanal cheese sampler and asked for it to come out after our dinner.  By that point, I was reaching maximum capacity in terms of stomach space, so I only got to sample a small tasting of each one.  The soft cheese, which was probably goat cheese was my favorite. -Normally I stop here and discuss how great of a meal it was, but being that it was Greg's birthday, we couldn't have dinner without a small slice of this month's Birthday Cake.  Yep, they change the birthday cake each month!  This month's sampling was of Doolin's Gingerbread Cake with quince compote & cream cheese frosting.  And really, when you see cream cheese frosting, all of a sudden your stomach has just created a little bit more space for you to try it.    Our waitress was great, and always made sure we had our glasses full.  I really enjoyed our whole experience there, and thought that it was a great place to take someone for their birthday.  Overall, it doesn't quite overtake Bix or Wayfare Tavern, but this is definitely a solid four star meal.  A big restaurant, a great crowd, delicious food, a wonderful date, and good service.  You really can't ask for more than that on a Friday night!

J26rLFEmURqUVADQYYxqBQ.review_text: it's cold by the windows and even though it's packed they find space by the kitchen. a place to watch them create. the place feels busy and fast, action and excitement. will not forget the bird, came out like a sacrifice and a warning and it tasted great.

LnBKb2ZhIgBH0o1K_y073w.review_text: I came here with some friends on a Friday night and it was jam packed! We waited around for some bar seats to open up but someone always got there before us! Oh well, we got drinks anyways. The bartenders took a really long time to make our drinks. I got the Washington Square and this drink made my face pucker so hard that the creases on my face overlapped, I looked like a Chinese shar pei. I love me some sour patch kids but this drink was too sour for me. My next drink was the Mclaren. That was a nice change. I really enjoyed this drink, it was refreshing.   For appetizers, we ordered the local halibut and brussels sprouts chip. The halibut had a party in my mouth, there were so many different flavors but it all tasted really good together. For $12, you only get 4 pieces. This dish is overpriced but it's a must try item. The brussels sprouts chip was very addicting. Once you start eating it, you can't stop. One small complaint, the salt and oil were unevenly distributed, I had a few chips that were either really oily or extremely salty. I had the steamed mussels for dinner and it was incredible! I ate every single mussel, finished the grilled bread, and even ate more by dipping the house bread in the sauce.

9t6y61-tWRJ0UxZNsEtWhg.review_text: If your house burger is mediocre in a "Tavern" you have a problem. Poor service and a very limited menu. Stay away and save some money.

60bNThWegNO0YphAIG2oew.review_text: Great service! No wait! Brunch items were incredible. We had the deviled egg open face chicken sandwich and the poached egg on polenta cakes. The open face sandwich was good, but the polenta cakes were amazing! We also started out with the avocado toast which was delicious but a bit pricy for what you get. Overall, definitely a repeat!!!

JNpCyCPJOJoiVjJK2CIONA.review_text: First time visit. Got the corned beef hash. It was pretty good but it left me wanting more. The portion was quite small for what what you pay.

y_Lb-WvBhmU5ez0gNKUFrQ.review_text: Park Tavern is one of the best restaurants to open in Northbeach in a very long time. Anna Weinberg's exquisite taste in selecting a menu is unrivaled. I've been there several times since she's opened and can't wait to go back again and again.  The food is incredible and the service is fabulous. Anna makes a personal effort to reach out to all her guests while you're dining, whether she knows you or not. The elegance and class of this restaurant drives in a wide variety of guests from the average foodie to the San Francisco elite.   Reservations are definitely helpful, but not a must - Because dining at the bar area is just as fun.  Make sure you at least go once a month because the "Birthday Cake" of the month (based on Anna's friends and family) is delicious!  Appetizers to try: Deviled eggs and  fried green tomatoes!  Delish!

Xf5KPJimu8cLFndTL8WPJQ.review_text: A group of us had brunch at Park Tavern recently to check out the brunch menu that was unveiled in March. A fairly new restaurant in the North Beach neighborhood, Park Tavern is spacious and modern, while maintaining a rustic appeal seen in distressed wood ceiling columns. It is restaurant decor that I could easily see Bobby Flay or Tyler Florence embracing.  While having a beautiful interior, I have slightly mixed emotions about the food. I sampled a decent selection...some was good and some was easily skippable:  - banana and coconut fritters with raspberry compote: A huge fan of banana served in sweetened preparations, and of coconut in general, I had high hopes for this starter we ordered to share. However, apart from the banana flavor, I tasted nothing but oil from the deep frying process. Coconut was unfortunately absent. Yea it was cool that it was served on a piece of black slate. But for $9? Don't bother with this dish.  - brioche french toast with blackberries and vanilla-maple syrup: I'm not sure why this dsh doesn't have better reviews on Yelp, but it was actually decent french toast (yes, I've had much better, but I could've easily been pleased with this dish). The portion size was ridiculous with two monstruous pieces of brioche. Consider sharing with a friend, else this dish can, and will, overwhelm you with its sweetness.  - cast iron baked farm eggs with baby spinach, gruyere, and prosciutto: Nice menu description, but unless you're Popeye or an extreme spinach-lover, skip it. The spinach is lightly sauteed and very much in its raw form, so its flavor overwhelms the other components of the dish. While an egg dish to begin with, you forget egg is even involved.  - crispy polenta cake with wild mushrooms, poached egg, arugula, truffle salsa verde, and shaved parmesan: Hands down the best dish on the table. Also a large portion size with two large squares of polenta each topped with a poached egg, I actually could've eaten the entire dish had I not been sharing. The tuffle flavor complemented the egg, polenta, arugula, and mushrooms perfectly! I really enjoyed the various components of this dish.

qJLf4-6qFQ8XWINWCDiGRg.review_text: We sat up at the bar and ate. The food was great. The bartender was awesome and gave us some great recommendations. I would have given a 5 star rating however I had a bad experience with the valet and management wasn't very helpful. Valet service seemed very friendly. I even gave the guy an extra big tip. Unfortunately when I got home and remove items from my trunk I noticed a huge gash in my brand new car. I contacted the the restaurant the next day and spoke with Peter. He was very apologetic and said that he would contact the valet company. The Murat from the valet company told me that he would not pay for any damages unless it was reported before I left and told me "This is why you have insurance". Peter offered to send me gift certificates to make amens for my bad experience however he never came through with it.

twsy_Dv0uKPzRoTSl4ZC6g.review_text: The decor that was once Moose's was comfortable and appealing. If you're dropping in just for a drink, good luck since the whole bar area was filled with diners and this is not the watering hole like Moose's or Washington Square Bar & Grill was.    As for the food, the deviled egg was simple and delicious ($2 each for a small egg) and the brussell sprout chips were good. Since we were pressed for time we ordered the Marlowe burger which was good, but I've had better gourmet burgers for less than $14.   Overall the food was good and the service was excellent, making for a nice dining experience. I will have to come back to try their pork chops, other appetizers, and sample some of their unique cocktails.   FYI...reservations are hard to come by on a short notice so plan ahead.

DFENl5W4GgwGshWSgP3vbA.review_text: Not the best food, but great service.  I arrived and the valet was super nice.  My friends were at the bar and we were seated right away.  The waiter was able to share which items were gluten-free easily and was happy to do so.  I ordered the burrata w/ lemon chips and that was delicious.  The burrata was incredibly creamy and I liked the lemon chips served with them instead of bread.  The tangy lemon complimented the rich and creamy burrata.  I ordered the scallops for my entree and was less than thrilled.  The scallops were overcooked.  They were served with roasted cauliflower in a creamy curry-like sauce.  The flavors were decent, but the overcooked scallops ruined the dish. The atmosphere was lively and the space was pretty nice too.  When I left the valet again was super nice and efficient.  I really wish the food had been better.  I'll try this place again, because I think it has potential.

tbizy4X3Pna4edEPuwfPiA.review_text: Went to Park Tavern for the second time last night.  My first visit was about a month ago and both dinners were excellent!  For our first dinner, we shared the brussel sprout chips, the pork belly bites, the deviled eggs, the steak crudo, and the burger.  Even split, that was WAY too much food for 2 people!  Everything was very good.  Although, if you're going to order the pork belly bites, be sure you're a party of more than 2.  They are so rich and you can only have one or two.  The brussel sprout chips were thin and crispy, with just the right amount of salt.  The deviled eggs were to die for...the pickled jalapeno and crispy bacon marry very well with the egg.  The steak crudo was nice, but nothing to rave about.  And the burger was fantastic!  They ask if you want it medium rare, and they mean it.  It's very pink inside, so if you don't like it that way, be sure to have them cook it longer.  I am a fan of medium rare and it was just perfect for me.  You can't beat a burger with crispy bacon and melty cheese.  The fries were perfectly crispy and salted as well.  Last night we enjoyed the beef jerky, the deviled eggs (seriously so good!), the halibut crudo, the porcini salad, the clam chowder, and the burger again.  If you are a fan of beef jerky, you must order this.  It's got fantastic flavor and texture.  The halibut crudo was just lovely...small bites of raw halibut, jalapeno, avocado, sweet corn and chive.  Yum!  And the porcini salad was fabulous...the mushrooms were to die for.  We ordered the clam chowder based on the rave reviews it's gotten and it was delicious!  Be forewarned, it is very rich and I think it would be difficult for one person to finish by him/herself.  And just as it was last time, the burger was fantastic.  My one gripe is that I felt rushed...both times.  The bus boys came around 3-4 times asking if we were done, when I clearly wasn't.  I hate the feeling of being rushed at a restaurant.  Other than that, Park Tavern is quickly becoming one of my favorite places to go to!

ANIHEYbREdtMo84FsDm7MA.review_text: Love it, the brussels and the burger are the best. My one and only complaint is the dessert- they suck. Tell me why in a chocolate cake would you ever, EVER, put raisins, that's just cruel.  They always sound great and never fail to disappoint me entirely.  Jack the bartender is the MAN!

HhWcLRxroa0oj87_Su1KSg.review_text: Reservations were made weeks in advance for a friend's birthday dinner. Staff were a half hour late seating us and then to a round that would comfortably seat five set up for six (which was tight) until we reminded them we were seven. They reset the table for seven--it was ridiculous. I got nowhere with the host staff "if you want to wait another hour we'll have something". Are you kidding me? Finally the floor manager came and offered that we could start our night at the round and once the two fours behind us finished dessert, we could move. We agreed. She sent over a couple of appetizers, which was a much appreciated gesture, and had the rest of the evening gone well, that and switching tables would have been enough to save the evening. As it was, the service at the round was poor and /beyond/ slow, but at least we got to move before the main course came (over an hour after we ordered it). I will admit some of the food was delicious (Brussels sprout chips! Pumpkin soup!) but my salad was meh and awfully small for twelve bucks, my NY steak was tough as shoe leather, but at that point I had to just eat it and go because the birthday girl was late getting to her party because we spent three hours at the fricken restaurant! I couldn't wait to leave anyway. The place was /so/ loud and crammed.  I felt bad for our second server. I give her top marks. She was no-nonsense, efficient, and did her best to recover the evening for us. I wish I had gotten her name. Management if you read these? Hang on  for dear life to the 40ish bleach blond with the glasses and ponytail who worked the dinner shift on Friday the 25th.   Note: after we were moved they crammed /another/ party of seven into that small round. It was a bunch of very young women who were clearly cramped but either too timid or otherwise unable to manage to get their party moved. We watched them elbow each other and constantly shift in their chairs as staff tried to move around them and thought, "well, at least we got to eat our dinner without getting hit in the teeth".  Will not go back.

lj7z6TKkOAG4pE0aVqnvjA.review_text: Reliably awesome yummy food, modern rustic atmosphere and great bar area. Highly recommend having brunch or dinner here if you haven't already.

w1JjL9b9fQRVl44d6UlhLQ.review_text: Went for dinner on Saturday night with a friend - we were 30 minutes late for our reservation but I called ahead to let them know. The hostess was very gracious and said they would seat us when we arrive, chich they did. No waiting and she thanked me for calling. I had the pork chop, my friend had the scallops and I tried a deviled egg - it was really good. The food was delicious and our service was excellent. Our server was great, he was very engaging and attentive.   The vibe is contemporary and comfortable with tiled floors and rustic textures. It felt refined, welcoming and relaxing. Prime people-watching with Washington Square across the street.

WXu1PNbPKV-84BQtg69Liw.review_text: Had breakfast here because Mama's line was too long...thank goodness!  Service was good and the food was awesome!  If you like deviled eggs...best ever!  Had the smoked salmon benedict  and it was DELISH!  Highly recommended. The place has cool vibe to boot!

BwTPj8XS_iqdSTLPBVMs1w.review_text: I randomly came across the reviews for Park Tavern. It was date night so I decided to book a reservation. When we arrived we were seated immediately. The décor is beautiful and the lay out really made the place upscale. We were seated a corner booth near the kitchen. We were ordered the Yellow Doll watermelon & Mangalitsa prosciutto, truffle & mustard greens, the Pork belly bites and horseradish aioli, the house made beef jerky, the pork and the burger. I rarely ever say this, but everything is amazing. However, the dessert lacked. There were only 2 choices and they were both slices of cake. We chose the Yellow Birthday Cake and it was decent. I could have made a better cake myself. I suspect they do not have a pastry chef yet but the food made up for that. Highly recommend.

ft1Qzy7-09gH4F9nZI21Fg.review_text: So many things delicious things to try! Finally, a great reason to visit North Beach for dinner.  I attended the friends and family dinner and can't wait to become a regular. Similar to sister restaurant Marlowe, the newly opened Park Tavern understands the needs of the neighborhood and delivers.  The menu offers diversity depending on whether you want small bar bites, apps and salads or sides and entrees. It's a large and enticing menu (especially all the apps and starters), and I can't wait to try it all from a perch at the bar. My favorites from the meal- oysters caeser (fried oysters in lettuce wraps with caeser dressing- unique and so delicious), beef carpaccio with fried horseradish, and the pork belly.   One of my favorite things about the restaurant is how they make the beautiful grand surroundings feel intimate by the delicious food from the same award-winning chef at Marlowe. There's a beautiful sit-down dining room for the impress-your-date-or-out-of-towners meal, a gorgeous bar and communal table for locals that want to drop in for tasty food and a full bar, and cafe-type seating by the windows overlooking washington square park for a more informal bite with a glass of wine. To me, this type of ambiance is part of what makes San Francisco restaurants so special, and Park Tavern nails it.       Plus, there's valet parking. Yay!   Welcome to the neighborhood, Park Tavern!

4eR6hYFJcBHoAqhuOS07ww.review_text: ----------BRUNCH ONLY----------- Since Marlowe is my favorite restaurant, it was a no-brainer to try this place out. GREAT setting for brunch, pretty big restaurant, and such a great menu. You know it's a good restaurant when you want to come back just to try the rest of the menu (the rest of the brunch menu, the lunch menu, the dinner menu!)  Avocado Toast with chile, lemon & sea salt - Simple concept executed so well. It's exactly what it says it is but it tastes way better than I imagined it.  Warm Baguette with 3 nut butters - The baguette is a little bit on the way harder side (but some people might like that) but the nut butters were really great flavors. We even had a bet going on at our table as to what was what. Good for sharing with the group.  Cast Iron Farm Eggs with spinach and prosciutto - What a solid meal. It's not too much and it's not too little, it's just right. Very savory but doesn't leave you feeling like you want to throw up  Veal Schnitzel with bacon fat-basted eggs, spinach and anchovies - How can you say no to anything that is "bacon fat-basted"?! It's definitely a heavier dish so it's a good share with the table but the savory dish is definitely worth getting.  Parking is terrible but if you're not driving, then that's irrelevant for you to know!   Definitely want to come back and try the rest of the menus.

grQfs3DN2CHgzphRXssgCA.review_text: How can you not give this place a 5 star. Amazing food, service and ambiance.   Bar Steak and Rib Eye are my favorite choices for Dinner. And don' forget the brussels sprouts!

vj-71bWcddq5l-FEkThVbw.review_text: Came to Park Tavern past Saturday with a group of friends. We arrived and I was immediately impressed with how large the dining area is inside.  Dark colors, white tiled floors, nice touches of greenery (cute topiaries) and just an overall warmth in the  restaurant.  We were seated promptly and served with warm bread and butter. Yum! We decided to try a variety of appetizers - beef jerky, uni, raw salmon, and the deviled eggs.  The clear standout appetizer is the deviled eggs (much better than Wayfare I must say).  For my main I had the filet which was super yummy. How could you go wrong with steak? Our table also shared the $20 fries and those were immediately gone after it hit the table.  Our group also tried the pork chop, poulet, and the fish dish (I think cod).    Overall the food was okay, no clear standouts then the fries and the eggs. As the night continued on the bar area was getting more and more crowded and it was definitely loud. We were yelling across the table to each other.

lTAyk_Qf_Sb013jYcbPdww.review_text: Came in today for brunch.  I had made a reservation for 12:45 at 10am this morning and it was worth it as there was definitely a wait.  The establishment is really big and open on the inside and has a nice bar and open kitchen.  The service was professional and very nice.  Our waitress was beautiful and friendly, she asked for our drink order and the manager came over and took our food order after.  It was refreshing to have the manager on the floor asking how our experience was going.  I ordered the Smoked Salmon Benedict.  It came out in more of a lox layout, with a large piece of toast with a healthy amount of salmon on top and a poached egg.  It was amazing.  I only had orange juice, so I can't comment on the drink menu but it looked legit.  Great spot for brunch with friends.

BLj-sgh4vuYt-vsGWpXyag.review_text: The food here is so good!  There were so many interesting things on the menu and I had a hard time picking without ordering way too much food.   Meal Recap:  smoked deviled eggs: DELISH cornmeal crusted oyster "caesar"  - interesting play on a ceasar salad, was very good PT fries - this is where its at!! summer squash/5 minute egg/burrata/prosciutto vinaigrette - pretty good "poulet rouge" - It was good, its hard to ignore this dish because it looks amazing  Overall, I'm looking forward to going back.  The service was great and the drinks were well made.

w-yJbFwpnEFGw4ochl2XKg.review_text: This was my second time to Park Tavern. We went again last night for my birthday dinner. I had very high expectations given my first dinner at Park Tavern.  Dinner last night exceeded my expections. The very finest dining in San Francisco in every respect.   Bravo, Park Tavern!

2cipAOp0EKyMhT5a4ty3pg.review_text: This is a "sister" location to Marlowe's in South Mission.   Similar lay out and food menu and just as good.   Prices are reasonable for nice clean food. Strong drink menu and service does it justice as well.   I had the Marlowe's burger with carmalized onions. Absolutely amazing, juicy and not heavy.   Highly recommend this place for lunch.

HorQ90eiUPfnesQlIraaJA.review_text: I was hoping for a 5 star and this is 4.5 stars - there we a few glitches so it gets 4.  My sister had given me a gift cert for my birthday a while back - and since I live on a tight budget I save these extraordinary splurges for special occasions. This was my sweet bf's birthday dinner.  I had poured over the menu for days trying to work out the best was to attack the menu.  We decided to go with a bottle of wine (a rare splurge), a few apps, split an entree and split a dessert, we had: -Brussels sprout chips - FANTASTIC wish I could make these at home - forget Kale chips, these are where it is at. -Parisenne Gnocchi - this was our least favorite -Burrata with lemon chips - this was 2nd our favorite -We spilt the roasted Poulet Noir  - Our waitress recommended the Pork Chop over the chicken and maybe we should have gotten that - it was very good (and a interesting  presentation, but I can make a good roast chicken at home and I rarely make pork, I was hoping for more truffle flavor. -Carrot cake - delish!  Service/food oddities:  -We had to ask twice for bread and the butter that came with it was hard and cold (bummer).  -The water is served without ice - I had to ask 2x for a glass if ice the chicken is supposed to come with spinach and some small potatoes (it only had one potato - when I flagged our server down and asked if that was normal - she said no and about 8 minutes later brought out about 5 small potatoes as a side -Great oddity - they comped the dessert, and it had a candle. - Over at Marlow they serve a cauliflower gratin that is like the best mac and cheese you ever had, I wish they offered it here

kLTIfsRKR42fMpb84G3cWg.review_text: Very High Recommendation for this delicious new spot in town! Everything on the menu looks absolutely delicious and I was impressed with the items I ordered a month ago.  Just some reasons why I rate this spot one of the top in SF:  1. perfect wine menu 2. incorporate raw, fried and smoked in their menu - can they spoil you anymore? 3. beautiful decor (including the pretty wall decor in the Women's bathroom, which believe it or not, the style and cleanliness of a bathroom can tell a lot about the upkeep of a restaurant) 4. serve a melt in your mouth bread and butter - which is not what you will expect, but so much more  Highly recommend: - steamed mussels & fennel sausage Entree - their ever so popular Marlowe Burger - Fried oyster caesar  - have heard great things about the sea scallop entree, and the clam chowder sounds yum! Do yourself a favor and check out this scrumptious establishment! classy, GORGEOUS and most importantly friendly to your palette.

QMEqnkZYnl7Jn4fOTV5SvQ.review_text: Tast, greasy, expensive. Good for any time of the day cuz of the location. Short menu,  friendly staff.

OHAb92B1-ZXkh1oDtzFyDA.review_text: A friend and I had an awesome breakfast here. The food was excellent and our waiter was very attentive, friendly and funny. We did order 2 deviled eggs just because we saw them serving it a lot. It was so good, I highly recommend getting one to try it, even if you're having something else. Will be back.

_3g-wdD3Fo3hoqyHZiFpKw.review_text: Food was average. Very loud place at night.

f_oX7IKhaeZCTe_LnhKJCw.review_text: Cute atmosphere.  Everything is delicious.  Especially loved the fried pork belly bits and the chicken!

dd9MyrpH_aDaWl700pgxhw.review_text: Great atmosphere for a nice weekend brunch! On a sunny day like today, the outdoor seating out front is perfect.   I had the burger and we ordered pancakes for the table, all was delicious. The cocktails were also great, had the Paloma and the Bloody Mary =)

h-dvAKFbr3K1UVNpyh4zjg.review_text: Finally made it to Park Tavern this past Saturday for my sister's b-day.  We arrived about 30 mins early hoping to grab a drink at the bar before we sat down to eat.  The lovely hostess, Adrianne, told us our table was ready anytime and that we could either sit immediately or have a drink.  We opted to have a drink first.  The friendly bartender poured a couple of delicious drinks including an Old Fashioned and a Makers Manhattan.  $12 a pop, but that's pretty standard pricing for this type of restaurant. Soon after we were seated at our table our server came over and poured the champagne that we had brought with us.  I called beforehand to ask about the corkage fee and they said they would waive it if we purchased of their bottles.  Our server recommended a fantastic Spanish white (Albariño Legado del Conde).  He also suggested a few apps that would go well with it including the Demons on Horseback and one of their raw apps.  Both were amazing.  We also ordered the Brussels sprout chips which were equally as good.  for mains we had the steamed mussels, pork cop, and the burger.  My mom said it was the best burger she's ever had and my pork chop was pretty amazing as well.  For dessert we had the apple crisp and the chocolate creme brulee.  Both were very good.   Service throughout the meal was excellent which included a friendly, attentive, and knowledgeable server and bussers who came to fill water and clear plates at just the right times. After dinner we had friends meet us at the bar where we stayed the rest of the evening.  The bar area was crowded but not so much that we couldn't find a spot to lean up against.   The bar area also has a long communal (I think) table for drinks and apps.  Not sure if they serve the full menu there, but it's a great spot to wait for your table with a drink if there's no room at the bar.
