Inside, the restaurant had a modern decor and it is well designed. However, our siting was in the front half and the tables were somewhat small for the plates / appetizers to fit at the same time.  Service: great service, although it got less attentive as the night progressed and the space filled up.

OuuIm31C6aKyZhUr0HRA2A.review_text: One of the best restaurants in #San Francisco! Perfect with friends, clients or date night!  Its a great hang out place or a fun place to grab a drink with a friend.  Staff is always welcoming and Adrianne at the front always makes you feel special! Must try the Deviled Eggs!

iLjMdZi0Tm7DQxX1C1_2dg.review_text: I think those stinky trust fund kids who continue to occupy the world are talking about places like Park Tavern and the folks that inhibit their four walls when crying foul about the 1%. I don't think I've ever found myself situated around so many well-to-do older men and their diamond-studded escorts in my 29 years on this planet before a recent stop into PT. Sitting at the bar alone (it's how I roll at times) and overhearing some of the conversations that only wealthy people could ever relate to made me feel so bad for less-fortunate members of our society, I actually seeked out the nearest panhandler and gave him a $5 bill upon exit. It made me feel roughly 99% better than I did before I left the bustling traditional American juggernaut across the street from Washington Square Park.  Aside from a pretty stuffy hang and an hour-long wait just for a single seat at the bar (it's not their fault they make delicious food that many, many people want to eat), Park Tavern is worth its weight in gold. Being a fan of Marlowe since they opened in SOMA, I knew right off the bat I'd be a fan of their latest project taking over the old Moose's space in North Beach.   If I were on a deserted island and you were to ask what five foods I'd want around me at all times, you'd find deviled eggs somewhere towards the very top of that list. And when I heard rave reviews from friends and colleagues alike about their version of the classic comfort food item, I just had to get in there and try them at any cost. Sure enough, while not as good as the deviled eggs at Wayfare Tavern in my opinion, they didn't disappoint. They were spiced up with jalapeño and bacon, and a sweet element that I couldn't quite put my finger on (but added a nice, unexpected twist). Upon future visits, I'd order these every single time.  In addition to the deviled eggs, I had to tackle a couple of their other standout bar bites: the brussels chips, and the demons on horseback. The latter features grilled shrimp wrapped in lardo and grilled in olive oil until the fat melts into the outer layer of the crustacean. It comes accompanied with slices of cucumber dotted with a black pepper buttermilk cream sauce that adds a nice visual touch to the smokey snack. It was fantastic (as I'd hope at a price point of $13 for four of them total). Regarding the brussels chips, there's not much I can say except you'd be a lunatic not to order these if you find yourself splurging on Stockton. The delicate leaves of the brussels sprouts are separated from the hearts, grilled, and doused in olive oil. For such a heavily-oiled appetizer, it's a light snack that packs an intensely flavorful punch. Perfect for sharing, or in my case, devouring every last piece until you're left with nothing but glistening fingertips, an empty wooden bowl, and a defeated soul.   It's worth mentioning that the cocktail program is as good as any in the city as well. They have a scaled down list of craft cocktails that concentrates on the classics, and they have a few Park Tavern originals as well. They also boast a nice-sized wine and beer list for folks looking to avoid the hard stuff.  It's about as far from my comfort zone as it gets, but Park Tavern rewards with a truly memorable epicurean experience. I've been an Anna Weinberg fan ever since I shared a symposium panel with her before SF Chefs in 2010, and while I'm not even close to the bullseye of their core demographic, Park Tavern will be on a short list of special occasion hangs for ol' Ruggeford H. Joesten III.

0rRrVbboHxzzAwmSHWxPeg.review_text: I visited this restaurant for a brunch tasting, and it was incredible. The menu is beyond creative--it redefines delicious. The environment is hip without being overbearing or snooty. A definite 5 star!

kAFphqKhO6ZkjxyVKXDngQ.review_text: I had the iron skillet farm eggs for brunch. Great ambience! The service and prices could have been a bit better :)

42PaKwZBqV1sgC5BCffWAg.review_text: Scallops with Cauliflower, nice presentation, fast serving, small portion. Cauliflower too salty.  Wine and Drinks nice and good selection.  Creme Brule, burnt to death.

mS-4O56dx6wt5fWxbbx-LQ.review_text: This review is for the brunch only.   Park Tavern is such a classy brunch spot tucked right into the quaint North Beach Washington Square park neighborhood (not the strip clubs part of NB). With a direct view of the park from both the ample outdoor and indoor seating options, Park Tavern boasts a creative take on traditional brunch entrees, great service and a somewhat upscale ambiance.   Here's what I recommend:  1. Crispy polenta cakes with truffles: It's basically like an eggs benedict but with poached eggs (not as runny as normal benedicts) on top of fried polenta served with a bed of mushrooms. This is seriously a one of a kind dish that you've got to try!  2. Marlowe Burger: Deliciously juicy - in the same realm as the NOPA and Maverick burgers. 3. Orange mimosas: freshly squeezed and absolutely traditional in concept. It's almost a rarity nowadays to have just a classic quality mimosa. Everyone always tries to make theirs unique with weird funky twists but Park Tavern stays authentic.   Seriously though, you really can't go wrong with anything on the menu. Go with what your taste buds desire but if you're trying to decide between two entrees, pick one of the above!  Happy Eating, Yelpers!

4eDXFIFF1_kpyozCbQSDEw.review_text: I like coming here a little before the crowd and hanging by the bar-Order a Washington Square while you wait for your bites.... Obviously try the deviled eggs and brussel sprouts.   Or-if you're a bruncher like myself-stop by early to get a table outside and overlook the beautiful park. The Crispy Polenta Cakes were great with a side of fruit and a mimosa with grapefruit juice.   Of all-the service, ambiance, food, drinks, nose level and overall feel-Park Tavern is by far one of my favorite restaurants in the city.

PHUi2nci1nPojmyV25rXtg.review_text: I have dined here twice and both visits have been stellar experiences.  My recent visit was for our six year anniversary.  For starters we had the deviled eggs and the lemon chips with burrata.   The deviled eggs are by far the best I have ever had. We ordered two and immediately ordered two more before we were finished swallowing the first two.  The lemon chips were on point. I was worried they might be slightly bitter, but the were bright crispy bites that paired well with the burrata. They are also served with some fresh fine herbs that take it to the next level.  Our second course was the Panissa with fresh peas/snap peas and mint. This was one of the best dishes I have ever had. It was bright fresh and cooked perfectly! I could have ordered several of these for dinner and been completely satiated.  For third course we had the Ribeye and the Wild Ling Cod. The Cod was out of this world. It was served with roasted sunchokes, sunchoke purée, & baby fennel. The fish was executed perfectly and the set was as well.  The ribeye was cooked to perfect medium, and was seasoned well. The set was pretty standard fair for a steak dish (i.e. blue lake beans & potato purée)  For dessert we had the strawberry shortcake on a biscuit. It was a pleasantly light finish to a large and indulgent meal.  To really take it to the top the service was completely seamless/flawless!  This is without a doubt my new favorite establishment.

rcdwXtvVVo_jI-VFdcUo1g.review_text: We had my daughters wedding dinner at The Park Tavern.  The food was excellent and different enough to be very new and exciting.   Everyone told us how much they enjoyed the food.  We booked their upper room and had outstanding staff helping us out!!!!!

14nzk-Yf6eVDdhB5A43c8g.review_text: Great casual place. It has valet parking and the service was great! Try the Brussels sprouts.

buhUgeRm7OpQtVE68Q2qZQ.review_text: Park Tavern is definitely in my top tier and several things - the burger, the Brussels sprout chips, the deviled eggs, the lemon chips - are all on my must order list.  However, last night something was just a bit off.  I wanted to impress my friend's husband as he runs a club on Cape Cod but, for some reason, everything was just okay.  Of course, Park Taverns' just okay is still about 10 notches above everyone else, but I just can't do that fifth star.  I'm sure it will be back, not giving up on my favorite space just yet.

Uxorpn2h2jDp_kl8172-FA.review_text: people must be drinkin' themselves some happy kool-aid, because i can't figure out where they're getting all these 4 and 5 star reviews...  now, to be fair, maybe we went on a bad night.  meaning, we went on a night when the kitchen ran out of almost everything, the server had something more important to do than you know...take our order or check in on us, and then said kitchen refused to accommodate a preparation request (just leaving an egg off of something - super difficult, right?).  and while the bill was given to us hastily BEFORE we finished dessert, the two, young blonde women sitting next to us had their drinks and dessert comped because (as I overheard the same server say), "We're so sorry that we ran out of the things you wanted to order and apologize for the slow service."  W.  T.  F.  this was supposed to be a special night out with the boy in celebration of his birthday, but there was no recognition of this (or us, for that matter) by staff and at the end of our experience here, we felt thoroughly ignored.  there was a point...somewhere within the 30 minutes it took for the server to take our order as we watched him attend to everyone else...when we very melodramatically thought, "if we left, would anyone even notice...or care?"    anyway, in a nutshell - we wanted to like park tavern, but the service was so piss-poor that i can't even tell you if the food was any good, nor can i remember what we ordered.

rw5k_Oc0mQKVJ7u_gcYd1g.review_text: This place is awesome, the food is amazing as well as the staff & service, it's a must go!!! It is definitely my favorite brunch place in the city.  I highly recommend: Banana coconut fritters, the crispy polenta cakes, dungeness crab (toast) and cast iron baked farm eggs.   Coffee lovers attention, they serve Blue bottle coffee!

oud0QXHjuWofUBEFs3cSgA.review_text: Excellent brunch. Great food and beautiful setting. I went with the baked eggs in a skillet with spinach and prosciutto and it was very tasty. Service was a bit slow - maybe that was due to the fact that their seemed to be multiple people assigned to our table (which was only a 4-top).

3G9Jkn7hKc8fmbdK8_lC8g.review_text: I truly want to give Park Tavern four stars because the ambiance is pleasant, the service is great and I could imagine how fantastic the food could taste....if it weren't so damn salty!!!  Now, I love salt. In fact I can sit and eat a bowl of rice sprinkled with just salt and be a happy camper. But the intense amount of sodium I experienced at Park Tavern last night was unbearable. We started with the duck liver mousse, which was very good, however we noticed it was quite salty. We moved on to the persimmon, buratta and coppa salad which was excellently balanced and quite refreshing. At this point the food seemed quite promising. Then came the lobster bisque and the steak tartare and both dishes were insanely over seasoned. By the time we were done eating I felt as though I'd been licking a salt block like a farm animal might. I'm not over exaggerating when I say that I could actually feel my blood pressure rising by the end of our meal! It was pretty unbearable. I was even fearful that dessert might be salty and we agreed that we wouldn't order any dessert described having "sea salt" or "fleur de sel." We ended up just skipping dessert due to our fear and left the restaurant with disappointment. Had the food not made me want to immediately drown myself with a gallon of water, I would have recommended it, absolutely. But I can't see myself returning if the food remains a salt bomb.

-7phVSG11fkcxn50PFiaig.review_text: The food here is extremely salty.  Also BEWARE when you eat here and pay with credit cards... I wrote in a tip amount and they added more to my final bill... good thing I double check my receipts with my credit card statements!!  -THEY TRY TO RIP YOU OFF!!!

EpGxL2yK0VFXLHFOBV6JuQ.review_text: Excellent food, cocktails, service and atmosphere. My friend and I had a wonderful meal. Everything arrived promptly but we didn't feel rushed. We had the mussels, Marlowe burger, brussel sprout chips and twice baked potato. All were delicious.   (my only suggestion: perhaps a sheer window treatment for the glass front door. At about 6pm, I was keeping an eye on the door for my friend from a seat at the bar and the glare through the window off the floor was ridiculous. Your hostesses might go blind.)

ayMdAflKmCx-j04SHEpexw.review_text: A somewhat fancy place for brunch or dinner. We were able to get a reservation through Yelp the day before, which was important, because most other popular brunch places have long weekend waits.  Deviled eggs = great Salmon benedict = just alright, would try something else next time  There's not a wide selection of savory brunch items. Didn't particularly stand out, but would come back to check out their dinner menu.  Very spacious. Not very loud, good for conversations. No pressure to leave right after eating.

k-9MThphu0QEvAeuSnCdrw.review_text: We went here to celebrate a birthday. Let's start with the hostess or the person who takes the reservations. This lady could give a class on customer service in the hospitality industry. We changed the reservation times twice (flight delay) and she didn't bat an eyelid, she was cool about the whole thing.  Secondly, we had people in our party who have major food intolerances, the hostess relayed this information to the kitchen - the waitress had this information on her docket when she brought our menus. This level of caring for one's customers is special. For this reason alone, I'd dine there again.  Overall, the service from the barman, to the waitress to the waterboy was excellent. I like my food on time, my waterglass filled without asking, and unobtrusive service. I don't need to be asked more than once if the food is to my liking. I don't need to know my waitress's name , and I hate fawning. All of my requirements were filled. Service was great!  The food was good too. From the brussels sprout chips, the deviled eggs, the pate, the squash blossom salad.... I'm getting hungry just writing these things again.   My most favorite thing was the polenta side dish with  orange & red cabbage relish on top. 5 stars right there! Delicious, creamy, smooth not gritty. Yum. Yum. Yum.  My dining companions had mixed seafood, filet mignon, halibut, and the pork chop. They were happy diners. The only disappointment was the burger - the meat patty was tiny and flat, the fries uninteresting.  The restaurant itself is on Washington Square. It has a great buzz to it - it's not fancy, just a nice place to hang out with good people.

05Tfytmuv36sglEJkYJFOA.review_text: Why would I ever leave my neighborhood, and only to be disappointed, ahem the Marina.  Thank you Jake for your graciousness and making this an awesome neighborhood gem icon, with great cocktails, superb food, and excellent service.

AT2rUlReN0mWRz7ShKES-w.review_text: Been here 4 times since it opened.  This place never fails us.  The food is always great, the ambiance is warm and the restaurant is well-staffed.  My favorite dishes are the deviled eggs and pork chop.

lX89A57ZsdTGx2BXaVLlYQ.review_text: I think that rating on the star spectrum has lost its luster for me because it doesn't fully encapsulate an experience. Thanks be to yelp for allowing me to pen a discursive narrative that subverts the stars.  MM and I ventured here this week after realizing that we'd both placemarked it. Made a quick reservation for 8:30pm but arrived an hour earlier hoping to sit at the bar or snag a table. Were the stars aligned for these aspirations? Yes and no.  We were seated at the communal table and told that we could either dine there or wait, but that we probably couldn't get an earlier seating. Hakuna matata. The place was packed and  it was a vibrant and kinetic scene. Laughter, cocktails en route, discourse, and all that makes a place worthy of your presence. Just after ordering we were told that we could be seated, as there was a last minute cancellation. Wunderbar. We had already ordered drinks but were told that they'd be able to catch our connecting flight to a real table. They failed to be rerouted, but we ordered them again with our waitress, and were soon delivered a gorgeous bourbon sidecar and a negroni for my classy companion that were perfect representations of the ideal.  MM wanted the Mendocino uni with chili served on butter lettuce because I'm from Mendo County. Actually because we both love uni, but the former reason sounds cooler. We soon ordered entrees, mimicking each other and choosing medium-rare Marlowe burgers. The uni came quickly, and was delicious, though didn't need to be served on lettuce as it detracted from the uni. The burgers took over an hour to arrive, because the order was misplaced! It was nice to have time to catch up, but wow, that was a long time. Once the misdeed was realized, several beautiful people dropped by to express their apologies, and the drinks and entrees were graciously compensated. The burgers were perfect as perfect. They've got this TCHO chocolate creme brulee with chili that purged any misgivings I might have been having about this restaurant, and when paired with a glass of Mary Etta's bubbles, I was a forgiving bubbles.  I might have been initially bruised by the frenzied service and misplaced orders, but the gallant gesture to waive most of the bill, and the bill of fare itself turned my scars to stars.

lFdcgrMkHCmvTjMEw4CVDQ.review_text: Finally made it to Park Tavern. Whew.   I had brussel sprouts to start and the porkchop and halibut were the entrees we ordered. Brussel Sprout chips were salty, bitter and lemony and as bad as that may sound, it was incredibly yummy. Crunchy and salty, they were definitely hard to stop eating. The porkchop itself was okay but the potatoes that it was served with were a buttery and creamy goodness. The halibut was served with the skin (which was crispy) and I absolutely loved it..because I love crispy fish skin. Teehee. We also ordered the twice baked potatoes as a side dish and the amount of food was perfect for two.   The cocktail list is filled with unique concoctions so definitely try one out! I don't drink much but the Dolores drink was my fave. Bartenders, servers and floor managers were so hospitable too.   Coming back! :)

5Bljk1tVq8RKSEUxsWBQ7Q.review_text: Since I'm a fan of Marlowe and I happened to be hungry and in North Beach the other night, I tried Park Tavern.  I was alone, so I only managed to eat 3 dishes, and 2 of them weren't very good. But the 3rd was so good that I'll reserve judgement until I explore more of their menu.  I started with the raw Alaskan halibut, a "flavor-decorated sashimi" type dish, 5 small pieces of the fish sprinkled with flavor add-ons. Rather uninvolving I thought, compare this to the Hamachi shots at Alexander's. Simple sashimi either needs to be the highest quality fish such that adornment is unnecessary, or throw so much flavor at it that it's an explosion. This is somewhere inbetween, and reminded me of the pathetic "look at me I'm fancy food but really I have no taste because nobody actually put effort into this dish" hors d'oeuvres they often serve at upscale catered parties.  I downed that with a glass of the Laurent-Perrier Brut, lovely and toasty.  I next had the Manila Clam Chowder, which imnsho completely missed the target. There's not much need or way to re-invent creamy clam chowder; there are hundreds of recipes and variations, and the whole thing is a known quantity. Stick with traditional preparations and just use high quality ingredients.  Park Tavern seems to be trying to re-invent clam chowder, so the soup is not as creamy as traditional, and the clams are whole, not chopped. The problem is that the clams are very salty and well, clammy, so chopping them distributes both the flavor and the salt throughout the chowder. What you get at Park Tavern is instead a relatively weak base with occasional whole clams that commandeer all your taste buds in a salty, under the boardwalk kind of way. I give them a B for effort, but the end result should be scrapped.  But then we get to the pork chop, which was not only the best pork chop I've had in 15+ years, but was cooked perfectly, exactly the way I asked for it. Too many restaurants overcook pork because of old school fears of trichinosis, and even a brined chop can be very tough. I specifically asked the waiter how tender the chop was, and told him how much I hate dry pork. Well, there was no need for concern because it was buttery smooth, perfectly pink, and so good I was gnawing at the bones afterwards. I'd go back just for that chop.  I didn't try the desserts, but the very limited selection seemed perfunctory, as if they don't have a dessert chef.  I'll have to try the Marlowe burger to see how it compares.  Edit September 2013: I've now eaten at Park Tavern probably 5 times since my first review, and they keep getting better. I've raised my rating one star in appreciation, it's my go-to restaurant in NB. I've had so many good meals there now, I guess they keep vetting the menu to remove things that are not so good and keeping the things that are. The last time I was there 3 of my party had Marlowe Burgers, but I didn't, they all thought it delicious, and one of them had been to Marlowe and tried it there.

46g1PTpxcRkT9KFsrXLFhg.review_text: *****3.5*****  Had a reservation for Sunday lunch, and upon arrival, discovered we would be ordering off the brunch menu.  I was looking forward to trying some of their most talked about dishes on their regular menu, so a bit of a let-down.  Valet parking saved us from a potential parking nightmare.    Classy atmosphere and ambiance inside.  Got a table by the window.  John Daly cocktail was tasty, but very weak.  Didn't taste like a cocktail!  Here's what we ordered:  DEVILED EGGS - Tasty little appetizers.  You see them on every table. Not off the chart, but good!  AVOCADO TOAST - I make this at home.  Love me some simple, avocado toast, where the avocado is the star.  I would order this again.  So simple and good.  MARLOW BURGER - Overcooked, but a decent burger.  Won't be writing home about it though.  2 others at our table got the burger and liked it, but didn't *love* it.  POLENTA - My wife's order.  She liked it and said she would order again.  Another at our table tasted it and said they regretted ordering the burger and wished they would have ordered the Polenta.  FRENCH FRIES - Read about the TRUFFLE fries in a lot of the Yelp reviews, but when I asked if the fries were Truffle Fries, she said they were just plain. I asked if they could make them "truffled" and she said she could for an extra $5.00.  So I got them, but it wasn't much different from the regular fries that were sitting on our table.  Couldn't really taste or see a difference in the fries except for an ever so slight dust of parmesan cheese.  Had plans for dessert elsewhere, so we skipped dessert, but the fritters looked good.  I would like to come back and try the food off their regular dinner menu. The brunch menu food was definitely a three star experience, but I think the atmosphere and service is a four.

RY4ya5BePPpC14Fzchs1UQ.review_text: Location is great - right in the heart of town.  We came early in the day for some business and the smells in the restaurant were amazing.  Made me want to come back for dinner, which I did.  Place was packed and there were lots of energy in the room.  Met a bunch of nice people at the community table.  Wine list is very diversified.  Love it when I find wines I have not heard about before.    Started with the rabbit and lardo terrine which had great flavors and a nice presentation.  Continued with the pork chop which was very tasty - loved the turnips and bacon chuncks.  Service was very friendly as well.  Ill be back!

gn5vfWQa2hvAJM_E955mvA.review_text: AWESOME.  Really great brunch, great service, great atmosphere.  Everyone down to the runners take pride in their jobs and you can tell.  It is top notch.  Well done!

BZOf-RMFNcNsBnj4c17-cQ.review_text: Got chummy with the bar-back and bartender right off the bat.... which led to some heavily poured Jameson drinks and great conversation. Thanks, Park Tavern! I'm now a fan!  Really mixed crowd once the dining area closes and primetime nightlife kicks in.  VERY hard to find parking for all those rare drivers that decide not to cab (very close to Coit Tower).  Definitely worth checking out if you want something a little more up-scale.

05UqTkPt9nsP1IFhOD6r5w.review_text: this "update to my update" is long overdue. i'll keep it short and sweet. i've been back to PT about a half dozen times since my last review, for brunch and dinner. and... BOOM! we're back in business! across the board, everything has been excellent - the food, the cocktails, the service. so happy my favorite go-to spot is back and better than ever. thanks to the PT team!

FoEiTmCpRNvbsG20dCgSZA.review_text: Park Tavern is simply the kind of inviting restaurant that you just want to spend time in.  There are a lot of lengthy reviews so I'm just going to give my 2 cents: -Sat outside and being right next to the park there is a lot going on and fun things to watch. -The Dungeness crab & lobster bisque. Just get it and thank me later. -Great customer service, handled a valet issue very well and they get that extra 5th star as a result.  I don't care if the food is great--when the service is bad, that's a no go.  Thanks Park Tavern for being very diplomatic & accommodating! Going back at the end of the month and cannot WAIT.

MHpn5NUAqb93SVXdXxZ-Rw.review_text: WOW! I went here recently for the first time for dinner and was blown away. The decor is pretty upscale but the atmosphere is friendly and casual. I shared some plates with a friend and was completely happy with out entire order. We had a BLT-with a twist- which included a piece of raw tuna on butter lettuce... yum! We also had the crab dip with chips.   I visited this place on vacation and loved this place so much that I tell people who are visiting SF to make sure to go!

7-3hVAMj42uAyc3oiVIlQA.review_text: Tons of great reviews here already, so I'll just put in my succinct two cents.   Eating at the bar is a great experience - the bartenders are top notch.   The food is really, really delicious.  I order the pork chop medium rare, and it's divine.  The 'Demons on horseback' consist of perfectly grilled shrimp wrapped in lardo - fantastic, and amazing flavors in the sauce as well.  The creamed seasonal greens are pure comfort.  [And for those of you who ordered the pork belly bites and complained about the pork fat -- really?!!!!  :P ]  Really, really happy Park Tavern opened, as I am a local and have been missing the yumminess and classiness of Moose's.

Sz600UsLJJaw9XDBpa_4ZQ.review_text: I've been to Park Tavern three times now and I'm so pleased that it continues to impress. The atmosphere is always lively, but not too loud that you can't enjoy the group (or person) you're with.  Also the wait staff is immaculate and always caters to your every need.   The food though, that's the biggest wow.  Most everything I've ate has always been divine, and I think that this spot has the most high quality food in North Beach.    Details.... Deviled Egg = MUST.  Really unique flavors, and the little crunch of bacon on top is perfection. Brussel Sprout Chips - delightfully crunchy (brussel sprouts are so "in" these days - ha) Lemon Chips Burrata - I love the flavor of burrata, so I didn't necessarily enjoy the burrata ON the lemon chips, but thought it was nice to eat on the side.  PT Waldorf Salad - really fresh, tangy with a hint of sweetness (although my date said it was a little sweet) Carmelized Onion Mushroom Soup - this was perhaps my least favorite... just wasn't on the top of my list. Marlowe Burger (ordered medium)  - JUICY and delightful medley of flavors.  The horseradish aioli is such a great addition. I almost had to ask for a 2nd serving of aioli so I could dunk everything in it. It's not particularly large, but still one of my fav burgers.   Overall I LOVE park tavern.  From ambience, service and most importantly the food, this is the type of place I can count on.

zpT7HWE3o77YVfG4S07H9A.review_text: It was an annual holiday dinner with two of my great girlfriends and this year chose Park Tavern to be part of our holiday experience. Dinner was at 6 and though we arrived to an empty place, by the time our waitress came to take our order the floor was filled with diners.   After many recommendations from our waiter, we decided to share a few starters, a side and to each get a different entree so that we made get a taste of everything.  Starters: -Demons on horseback -Deviled eggs, bacon, pickled jalepeño & chives  -Brussels sprout chips  Our favorite starters for the night was the Demons on horseback- the melted bacon fat gave the prawns a pop of flavor. My second favorite was the famous brussels sprouts, and I don't usually eat brussels sprout. There is a rave about their deviled eggs but to us it was just mediocre.   Sides: -Anson Mills polenta  Finished before I had a chance to dig into my Petit "Poulet Rouge". Yup, it was that good!  Entrees: -Grilled pork chop -Seared local albacore -Petit "Poulet Rouge"  Out of the entrees, I would have to say that my favorite was the petite poulet rouge. First the dish came out cold, when we notified our waiter he quickly took it back to the kitchen and the manager later came out with a new and hot dish. It was wonderful! Moist, juicy and full of flavor of spices.  The seared albacore and the pork chop was good too but nothing compared to the hen.   Desserts: -Lemon cheesecake parfait  -Apple & red wine-caramel crisp   Lemon cheesecake parfait was creamy and rich. Can't really taste the "cheesecake" in this dessert but it was still good. The apple & red wine caramel crisp was a tad bitter, and it is probably because of the red wine. However, the bitterness balanced perfectly with the sweet and tart lemon ice cream that it was served with.   Overall, the dining experience was really delightful. I admire and respect restaurants who will own up to their mistakes and are willing to take that extra step to make their service more than exceptional. Their generosity in making up for their errors made my dining experience with them much memorable.

shCNdnP5NkQ1qp3Ogy2KBw.review_text: Talk about a 180 degree turn around..!    Yep, the girl who wrote a scathing review is eating her words.  : /      Why you might ask?     Because after giving Park Tavern a third chance, I was actually blown away by the experience.  I'm not too proud to admit it.    This time, everything was spot on!!! Woo hoo!!!    I walked in a bit on the defense. I was certain I would be let down again but course by course, interaction after interaction I found myself thinking, "wow, maybe I got it wrong last time..."  The martini...? Perfection. And the bartender who served it was pretty darn nice, genuine even. --[In my head (Fine we're off to a good start.)]  Appetizers, including the deviled eggs and the charcuterie plate were delicious. -- (Ok, Ok, so far 2 for 2.)  Our server; friendly and attentive without being over the top.  He was there when we needed him but wasn't obtrusive when we didn't. -- (Wow, he is so much better than the last guy.)  The wine.  Really REALLY good and,,, wait... Didn't cost a fortune? -- (Was that priced incorrectly on the menu? Humph. No, it wasn't!)  I got the lamb this time, my husband got the chicken.  Both were FANTASTIC.  -- (Is this happening!?!? Everything has been amazing tonight..!)  Apple Crisp and coffee?  Just what I needed to seal the deal.  -- (Holy cow, it happened, they changed my mind!)   Only one last thing to ask....  When are we going back and who wants to go back with me?

e331pQV1I-SSnWw_w0PfMA.review_text: My Review of Park Tavern, in Chat:  Me: I had 2 cocktails, a fernet float and a "Marlowe" burger Friend: Oh I see Friend: Marlowe burgers are good doe Me: it was ok Me: the meat was really good Friend: You gotta order it med rare Me: but i was mad at the meat vs bun ratio Me: i always do! Friend: Oh yeah Friend: good point Me: you think im a dope!

1DlL-BYuhPoKTvZ2hBcSUg.review_text: If you are in the area you HAVE to check this place out! for brunch! Service 5 stars Food 5 stars Drinks 6 stars  Try the boozy smoothie!!!! Don't get too excited as it comes in a small glass but holy mother of earth it was amazing!!!  You just might have to order 2!  I had the pan fried corned beef and hash and I can't stop dreaming about it, (hope that doesn't come across creepy) it was just that good!!  Might be one of the best places I have been for breakfast/brunch in a long time!  Price is a lot but worth every penny!!  I am excited to be in town again and try their dinner and see if it stands up!  Either way, check this place out as I think you will for sure like it!!!

inz8izVu0oSGeJJdY32zYA.review_text: One of my current favorite restaurants in the City now!  I can't get enough of their "Poulet" mini-bird (Cornish game hen, same difference) that's cooked and served on a cast iron skillet with a stick that goes up the Poulet's behind.  I normally don't order chicken because it can be overcooked and dry, but the Poulet at Park Tavern is a divine exception.  It is consistently tender, juicy, can't get into my mouth and tummy fast enough, delicious!  The bottom of the skillet is filled with some delicious herb stuffing.  The Poulet's flavors vary by season.  In the winter, it's called "Poulet Noir" flavored with truffles.  In the spring/summer, it's called "Poulet Rojo" flavored with chile and other red spices.    Other outstanding things I've ordered the various times I've dined at Park Tavern are: the deviled eggs, each topped with a decadent, crunch piece of bacon and the pickled jalepeno makes it one of the best deviled eggs, ever; brussel sprout chips (not to be confused with the side order of brown butter brussel sprouts, which aren't as good); and Demons on Horseback (lardo aka Italian bacon fat wrapped shrimp).  Just thinking about all the yummy goodness has got my mouth pooling with drool!

AGraTma9eEgsiJFDIy6tbg.review_text: Since I saw Park Tavern on "Check Please", it has been high on my list to try.  We made a reservation and had a nice table in the front room facing Washington Park in North Beach - nice!  We started with the brussel sprout chips, which were highly recommended - lightly fried, crispy and tasty, loved it!  We shared a dungeness crab salad which was just right, refreshing and light with good-sized pieces of dungeness crab - yum!  Also, recommended on Check Please was the poulet noir (allow 30 minutes) - tasty, juicy and tender and very dramatically displayed propped up on a stand so you can easily carve the meat from the bone.  I got full so I took half of it home, but there's always room of dessert!  We got the TCHO chocolate creme brullee - creamy chocolate-y, nice.  Service was very friendly, helpful in giving recommendations for wine and entree choices.  Great location in North Beach and very solid food and service.  I will be back!

XUNKH9hVS18f1XuhYPZVtQ.review_text: Many, many delicious things here!  The PT fries with the soft-boiled egg dipping sauce, the upright poulet rouge, the addictive brussel sprout chips, the birthday cake (we had gingerbread with cream cheese frosting!  Who doesn't like high-quality cream cheese frosting??), the chocolate creme brulee, the beautiful figs with burrata, and of course, the stellar drinks. The paloma and twin peaks were both quite unique and delicious.  Servers were friendly, relaxed (considering how much was going on around me, my head would be spinning if I were them!), and informative.  Why not 5 stars?  It was just a bit expensive for me.  Each drink, glass of wine, main course/appetizer, was, like a dollar to 3 dollars too expensive (except for the poulet rouge - that was a good price).  And that really all adds up.  I mean, 8 dollars for a french press of coffee that puts out one large mug of coffee?  Hmm.  6 bucks for a tiny plate of olives?  Hmm again. The bill for the 3 of us came out to $300 with tip.   So, I'd say this is a great place for a special occasion, because the food is delicious but the prices "know" the food is delicious.  Or, I'd go for the drinks and just have a few snacks like the brussel sprout chips on the side!

WYaH4nTgNXrydnHRKJxMYA.review_text: I went to Marlowe's awhile back and I enjoyed it so much I decided to try their sister restaurant, Park Tavern.   Just as I expected, there was not one disappointment.   The ambiance is sexy traditional American, the service -impeccable.   And don't even get me started on the food....AMAZING!  I am really into restaurants that offer snacks in addition to the usual appetizer/entree/dessert categories.  The cuisine is innovative and there are some traditional items on the menu like twice baked potatoes and deviled eggs but these are not your grandma's deviled eggs.   Well, let's just say don't even think about leaving Park Tavern without having one or two of these eggs and you will know what I'm talking about.

gnwV-j37Oi6589cKUUVwow.review_text: Very disappointed with the service and food.  Took colleagues from Denver and waited at least 10 minutes for anyone to came the table.  We were never offered a cocktail.  We ordered two appetizers after discussing the need to be gluten free, but they never showed up.  One of the four entres was halibut and it was raw.  When called over another waiter he responded "your right."  No apology, no reduction, no intention going back.

KonsF4GvUCmRCTTCyADyog.review_text: Came here for dinner (not brunch, like 50+% of the reviews seem to be).  The appetizers were great.  I'm usually pretty conservative with my ratings, so that's really saying something.  Brussel sprout chips had some lemon zest that really brightened up the normally greasy (in a good way) dish.  Well seasoned, tasty, and I could easily eat more of it than I should.  Smoked Deviled Eggs, I initially thought they were a tad pricey, but upon consuming, they were really really good.  I'm not a fan of jalapeno, but it worked well here.  The flavors were very well balanced, with the smokey salty crispy bacon, the creamy seasoned egg yolk, a tiny kick/bite from the thin slice of jalapeno, and tiny bit of chives to lighten it up, all coming together magnificently.  PT Fries were fried nice and crispy (but not burnt), and while dipped in the egg with caviar were good, I will never ever say no to truffle aioli.  Mains:  The burger is really good, and stands up to its well deserved reputation in local food blogs/rankings.  Again, it was very well balanced with discreet complementing flavors and textures.  A nicely toasted bun that held up well and didn't get soggy; crisp, with a fair bit of melted butter.  The right amount of cheese and grilled onions, so they don't all fall out on your first bite.  The actual patty, wasn't super awesome on it's own, but combined with everything else, worked really well together.     The chicken was really succulent and tender.  The seasoning isn't too heavy, allowing you to really taste the chicken.    Decor:  Upscale modern casual, but not overly so.  It wouldn't feel overly out of place taking your parents/family here.  Some tourists, but that's expected for the area.  Acoustics get a bit loud when it fills up.  Waitstaff were great.  Attentive, but not annoyingly so.  Water/drinks attended to swiftly.

kemEUTAsATc2DNHUQLMRBw.review_text: First time we dined at this place were couple years ago and they were good - both the food and the service. As we go to SF at least once a year, this time, we decided to dine there again as it's next door to our Bed and Breakfast, and we remembered the food was good. Unfortunately, we were disappointed this time - both the service AND the food.  For drinks, we opted to have cocktails in lieu of wine - hubby had Treasure Island (Barrel-aged gin, fennel syrup, Dolin Genepy des Alps & lemon); and I had Duboce (Bank Note scotch, yellow chartreuse, Benedictine & bitters) -- they were good and very strong - straight to your head strong.  We started our meals with Crispy Soft Shell Crab, it was good, it had very good crispy coating that's not oily at all - we were happy.  We also had Brussels Sprout Chip - pretty good but they were very oily. For dinner, I had The Bar Steak while hubby had Grass Fed Ribeye; ordered medium rare for both.  For mine, with description of grass fed bisto filet - I expected the filet to have nice flavor.  To my surprise, it came sliced and I already knew I would only going to have my first bite as the juicy bite as I saw the juice from the meat was on the bottom of my meat.  I'm sorry, but. . . I had better meat from regular market.  It was not taste good at all, overcooked (more like medium toward well done), and super dry due to the slicing - which they possibly not let the meat rest first as well.  Hubby's ribeye had better taste and cooked perfectly as medium rare; his was also served sliced, but his was not dry like mine - possibly because lots of fat on the meat.  To cap off the night, hubby had May's "Birthday" Cake while I had the TCHO Chocolate Creme Brûlée.  The "Birthday" Cake was plain yellow chiffon cake with plain cream cheese frosting - couldn't taste any of the brandied apricot coulis & peach cream cheese frosting as they detailed on their menu.  As for my Creme Brûlée, it was not as good as I remembered I had it couple years ago; plus the chocolate biscotti that came with it were soggy and old tasting.  As for the service, our waiter was pretty ignorant - she only came by to take our order after I gave her the look as we were sitting for 20 minutes or so waiting while she was too busy "entertaining" 2 other tables next to us that were bigger parties (6-people table).  The bus-boy was much more attentive as he asked if we wanted some bread and never failed to fill up our water glasses.  We definitely will skip this place on our future annual visit to SF.  There are so many other restaurants that offer much much better food and services - sorry Park Tavern, you definitely failed us.

EiwxlbR8fb68lMgEXhcWKA.review_text: I feel like this place deserves A+++++++ for the PT Fries.  I know this is sort of unfair. But OMG. I don't even like fries???  I came here with the bff and she was really enthusiastic about these fries, so I agreed. Frankly most fries are just ok to me. I think I like steak fries or that style ... but I would eat like maybe 2. I like fries that aren't fried to Kingdom come ... so I guess that limits me to a very few places that serve fries I like.  I love that these fries were very, very truffle-y. The sauce / dipping was fantastic even though I normally dislike aioli type sauces and the soft boiled egg was even better!  Did I mention there's caviar?   Seriously, this place is awesome. They have happy hour during the weekend as well so cheap but quality drinks! Totally recommended for a quick stop or an actual meal.

sLAHGpyJ6hmCNkaXuQIgKQ.review_text: Hype.... not worth the trip Our dinner was free and I can not recommend it ! There  was something amiss with every dish. They do not care.

DlwexC7z88ymAzu45skODw.review_text: I visited Park Tavern on a Saturday morning after finding the line at Mama's wrapped around the corner. It was an especially gorgeous, clear, and sunny day in SF, and there happened to be one table open outside, so we grabbed it. My partner and I grabbed a couple Hummingbird cocktails, and they were delicious (St. Germain, grapefruit, and bubbly). We ordered the cinnamon sugar challah, pork confit hash, and the burger. All items were very good, but the absolute star of the meal were the potatoes. The fries with the burger and the homefries with the hash were super SUPER CRISPY. Which is exactly how I like them. So between that (good fries can really make my day, you know?), nice weather, friendly service, and tasty cocktails, I had a great time.

GvCx4AXTbMtcIAX9BpMIcw.review_text: This was our second visit to Park Tavern and since we live in the neighborhood we thought we would try it again.  This time when we made our reservation we asked for a table by the window since we heard it was less noisy.  The very nice hostess said our table was still occupied and offered us two choices.  We took a booth for two in the center of the restaurant.  Big Mistake!   We were seated by two couples that either had way too much wine or were very giddy being in a restaurant.  They shrieked and laughed so loud and with that added to the already loud noise level in the restaurant it almost made sitting there unbearable.  We ordered our drinks and then the waiter took our order.  Within five minutes our entrees arrived.  McDonalds could not have been that fast.  My scallops were arranged like a small snake on the plate ranging in size from the size of a nickel to a fifty cent piece.  Fortunately I was not all that hungry.  My friend had the steak and fries.  I love salt but the french fires were so salty even I could not eat them.  Three different bus boys asked to clear our plates.  My friend literally had his fork in mid air and was chewing  and had food on his plate.  I know they want to turn the tables but that was ridiculous. There wasn't  anybody waiting for a table and there were even some open tables. Why we ordered dessert is a mystery but we did.  That took fifteen minutes to come.  They only had to slice the cake not make it from scratch. The carrot cake was not as good as the one Neiman Marcus used to have.  That one had shavings of carrots, walnuts and raisins in the moist cake and the frosting had wonderful cream cheese.  This was not even close.   The manager knew we were unhappy and took it upon himself to take care of the food charge and we paid for the drinks.  Between the very loud noise level, the feeling that we were being rushed with the entree and then delayed by the long wait for the dessert I can assure you we will not return.   There are far too many restaurants in San Francisco where you do not  have to put up with a loud noise level, inconsistent service and so so food. Too bad since Park Tavern is convenient for those that live in the neighborhood.

bTFZ-cepM91pdS2PFpvJiA.review_text: Deviled eggs - yes.  I'm not a fan of deviled eggs, but these .. 1 more please! WOW. Another 7x7 list success (there are many fails, unfortunately).  BRUSSEL SPROUT CHIPS - why is this not on the 7x7 list? Fail, 7x7.  Marlowe burger = good. Deliciously light fries.  The boy loved his pork chop!  Nice space in north beach across from the park.  Parking is a bit of a headache.  A great alternative if you is going to the sister restaurant Marlowe if this location isn't convenient for you.

uM6oNmSFISzji0mU081KjQ.review_text: Came here last night with a few friends and we couldn't have had a better experience. We ordered as follows:  - VENISON CARPACCIO - SMOKED PUMPKIN SOUP - BRUSSELS SPROUT CHIPS - SEARED SEA SCALLOPS - GRILLED NY STEAK - MARLOWE BURGER   Everything was absolutely excellent and I give each dish 5 stars. With our dessert we each ordered a port wine and our waiter brought over an expert to help us decide which. He was very knowledgable and explained each in detail. I was more than happy with what he recommended.   WIll definitely be back again!

nLOF2qXMJfTbbcVtDo8oZA.review_text: The atmosphere beats any restaurant in San Francisco. It's sexy, classy, lively, and well-designed. It's probably my latest favorite dinner spot in SF!   The food is good though I wouldn't RAVE about it, but I liked the devils on horseback, mussels, burger and five cheese potatoes. My most exciting discovery was a Montepulciano for under $30 that was divine and inexpensive.  Go here for a date, dinner with friends, celebrations, drinks....any occasion!

55P1DzMk1fMlJog_kXt_Ng.review_text: I love, love, love Marlowe, so when I heard that the Marlowe team was taking over the old space on Washington Square Park I was stoked!  Not only is Park Tavern about 6 times as big as Marlowe, but they have kept all the Marlowe classics that we love.    Being a huge Marlowe fan, I had to get the Marlowe burger - it is my favorite burger in the city after all.  I was kind of disappointed by the bread because some Yelp reviews had talked about a special hot roll and we were served simple Acme epi, which normally would be fine, but not when I was expecting something else.  My friend had the deviled eggs and raved about them.  He also had the burrata app with the fried lemons and loved the combo of the lemon, basil and creamy cheese.  The brussels sprout chips were as wonderful as ever.  My other friend had the whole hen over spinach and the presentation really was impressive.    Park Tavern's idea of serving a monthly birthday cake is really cute, but unfortunately the November cake is carrot cake - seriously?  Who likes carrot cake?  I'll have to come back to try a cake people actually like.  But Park Tavern is still a great place in a neighborhood full of mediocre tourist traps.  The restaurant is very homey and comforting and the service was great.

8XwZggy8l9x8lm6mCZFwGA.review_text: I was looking forward to the opening of Park Tavern for months and could not have been happier to finally go check it out last weekend. So glad there is finally a little variety in eateries lining Washington Square Park!  I love the ambiance; dim lighting, view of the park, seating arrangements with a long family style tall table by the bar. The staff were all attentive, friendly and offered great suggestions. I remember hearing complaints about the service when Joey and Eddie's occupied the space so it was great to find that was not the case.  Sat at the long table with two dinner guests; we were right in the thick of conversations, cocktails, and delicious food...it was perfect for a Saturday evening girls dinner.  Starters: 1.Deviled eggs  - Delicious! Served as singles so we ordered 1/each. Love the bacon on top and will go back for more :) 2. Burrata  - Pretty good...I am a big burrata fan and may just be being snotty but It was tasty and I would recommend it; just not the best I have had. 3. Prawns  - Very tasty...the sauce was a little spicy (how I like it!) and made for a good sauce to sop up with the table bread.  Entrees: 1. Pork Chop - Really liked the dish as a whole, well prepared and enjoyed it. We all 3 shared each of the starters and entree's.  2. Arugula Salad - The server mentioned this salad was popular and I can see why. It was flavorful and since none of the other dishes we got had much green it was refreshing to include a salad. 3. Mussels - Yum! I love mussels and thought these were really good. Loved using the broth to dip table bread in and the sausage was a nice touch.  Great first experience and can't wait to come back for more!

ifrL9DZ30ibOWX5KfXxFDA.review_text: Perfect brunch spot don't forget to order the avocado chili toast

EiIAnrHEeghCf0rXwju1gA.review_text: Thank you Food Overlords for Jennifer Puccini, executive Chef of PT. This place continues to amaze and impress me with their overture of impeccable food and reasonable prices. Big ups for being nominated for a James Beard award for best new joint as well.   Got here for our 10PM reservations on a saturday night, and let me tell you...it was popping...at 10PM. We are not talking kinda sorta busy, we are talking reservations only busy still at the late hour.   This place still has all the super whites that I saw last time i was here..in fact, I think some of them haven't even left since last time. So many striped Brooks Bros shirts and slacks and mink coats....where is the goddamn recession? Not here folks.   Fried Brussell sprout chips were as good as ever, the deviled eggs fantastic, and the pork chop as tender as JLO's ass. Wife had the mussels and whatever they put into that broth at the bottom of the bowl is so addicting, I want to swim in a pool of it.   I think I saw the owner Anna Weinberg somewhere shaking hands and thanking patrons left and right. Big ups to this place, and hopefully the super whites will let us lowly plebians get a table now and then.

HDq6BTg0b36rB9LSDTUi0Q.review_text: Brunch double date at Park Tavern. Food was beautifully presented and taste as good as it looks. Between the four of us, we ordered three different items (the walnut and raisin pancakes, two orders of the crispy polenta, and the smoked salmon benedict). The pancakes were huge and hearty, but I could have eaten another smoked salmon benedict as it wasn't very filling. Service was friendly and professional.

TMeQPK3HJ7giAbAUwl9AvQ.review_text: Ate here last month and I really had a good time. Great service, food was excellent. I had the scallops, which were great and my dinner date had the tuna, which was really amazing. I liked the atmosphere and I thought that the menu was priced just right and I honestly had a really great time there. Well done! Oh and P.S. the truffle fries are out of control!

zmyecPTIqeCBbKTEFnWc6w.review_text: I was a little disappointed, ordered the ribeye and it had great flavor, however I didn't like that they cut into chunks and it was tuff. The chairs are very uncomfortable and the tables are barely wide enough for two plates. I won't recommend this place. Two stars for the great flavor of the steak.

pdilmEaeXuntV4eTnc9KcQ.review_text: We really enjoyed our feast here.  Great service.  Great food. $100 a couple for appetizers, entree and dessert with a couple of beverages. Glad to see this space is doing it right. Cheers.

NgapNNErXajBp6Ro5I21Jg.review_text: I loved this place.  The food here is excellent. Everything that came out was so good. Tried the brussel spout chips which were yummy. My next favorite was the deviled eggs. It's topped with bacon, and who doesn't love bacon? My main course was the lamb, which was very flavorful. Others on the table had the pork, and I actually like that better than the lamb. The pork was so soft and juicy and full of smokey flavor. My favorite dessert for the night was the apple cheddar crumble. It didn't taste cheesy at all. Just buttery, apple goodness.  Service was excellent. Both the hostess and server were very gracious.

3gISGgHzS094Q9x1OeEOrg.review_text: My parents are a huge fan of this place. I finally went to dinner with them here after maybe a year of their nagging. Overall, some dishes were very good, some were less impressive.   In particular, the roast chicken is good, but not unique or interesting in terms of flavor. I was more interested in buying a Staub pan ($160 at William-Sonoma) afterward than coming back to eat that particular roast chicken again.   Everyone (including my parents) seem to rave about the deviled eggs -- I was disappointed. Maybe I prefer different things in my deviled eggs, but while the toppings were unique and flavorful, I found the egg yolk too yolk-y and not creamy enough.  All complaints aside, nothing was BAD. And the PT Fries were amazing (but it's hard to go wrong with fries and egg yolks...) as was the braised lamb tongue. Would come back, but will skip the deviled eggs and the chicken.

uHByAmOiKGVPBtaTGz46gg.review_text: Dined with five others and we all had a wonderful experience.  Loved the Brussel sprouts, lemon slices and shrimp appetizers.  Good combo of flavors. Main course was the pork chop.  Very tasty, but was luke warm when delivered.  For sides, enjoyed the twice baked potato and Brussel sprouts.  Finished off the meal by sharing the birthday cake and lemon cheesecake parfait.  Awesome.  Plus excellent wine selection.  Royalty was among us as Mr. Mayor (Willie) was at a nearby table.  Restaurant is loud so turn up the hearing aids!

aMBkcgtRHVu2AnRczmtmAg.review_text: I've only eaten brunch and had drinks here, so my review is based simply on that. The food is all delicious, but I think the menu could use a few more options on the savory side. I love my sweets, but about 70% of the menu is sweet brunch food. Adding a few more sandwiches and breakfast items that don't use sugar would be great. With that being said, the French toast was probably one of the best versions I've ever had.  If you like sweet items - you'll love the menu!   Drinks are also great - my only complaint is that the menu pricing seems to be off. Two separate occasions I've ordered a bottle of wine to be told later the price on the menu is incorrect. No big deal, but maybe change your menu price to reflect that or honor the price the customer already saw. :)

swocJWD8R1iH20-lveXh0Q.review_text: Love the contrasting decor of dark wood and white subway tiles.  Staff was nice although our server had an odd way of describing the food.  She used words like, "fun and interesting" which made me worry about how that translated over to food.    We shared the Tomato tart:  I really enjoyed this and it was easy to share among the 4 of us. French fries:  the fries themselves were good.  I didn't see the point of dipping it into the egg yoke though.  We bypassed this step and went straight into the aioli.     Demons on Horseback:  5 prawns wrapped in lardon.  You can't really say anything negative about that. Brussels sprouts chips:  yummy!  for entrees Bar Steak:  Fiance enjoyed this.  Simple go to item for him at most restaurants Scallops:  I had been craving scallops for a while now.  These were rather small but they gave me enough to fill me up.  There was also something unrecognizable and deep fried.  I ate it anyways but will probably check the menu later to figure out what it was.  Might have been a mushroom. Herb crusted sole:  both my friend and her boyfriend tried this dish and both did not like it.  They thought the crust was odd and thought the description  misrepresented it. CAB NY steak:  friend loves marrow and didn't like this dish.  She thought it tasted strange but it was the largest of all portions.  We also had two glasses of champagne and a red and a white.  No dessert since we were stuffed.

Tdsd6ojiId3tgJsBBQz4NA.review_text: Loved this place.  I had some friends in town, so wanted to have a nice dinner in a place that could accommodate a 16 month old.  From start to finish, this place delivered.  When I called to confirm that they had a highchair for my friend's kid, and inquired whether it was ok that someone in our party (the bf) would be running late, they didn't bat an eye, and basically said "we're here to serve you."  The excellent service continued throughout the night; our waitress was very accommodating of our little group.  The food was to die for.  My friend and I started with the crab and lobster bisque---yummy!!!  Not too creamy, had some bits of crab and lobster, and I loved the puff pastry that came with it.  For the main course, both she and I got the filet mignon.  OMG, so tender and juicy.  And the potatoes that came with it were heavenly.  My boyfriend scarfed down his mussels, and my friend's husband seemed to really enjoy his scallops.  The atmosphere was perfect.  Lively, sophisticated, great decor, all overlooking Washington Square Park.  I was amazed at all of the bustle, even for a 6 o'clock reservation.    Park Tavern lived up to and exceeded the hype.  My new favorite.

DI7mg1oQHeUApMm-9Y-BGw.review_text: I went to the Park Tavern to give it a second try. As before the staff is exceptional. This time however, the food was great as well. There was almost too much burrata cheese with the lemon chips and I didn't know that concept even existed, too much cheese pah! Then followed up by the salmon which melted in my mouth. The portions look like they are appropriately sized however I was struggling to get the last delicious bites into my mouth.  All in all, a great meal. Thank you!

zAFS5GwqdQH9ZlwgL5ywAQ.review_text: Park Tavern is a breath of elegant air in the heart of Washington Square.  Yes, it's a masculine tavern-esque space.  Yes, it draws a more upscale crowd than it's sister restaurant., Marlowe.  Yes, it's a change-up from the typical North Beach beat.  But rest assured (exhale), Park Tavern emits warm vibes from the moment you walk inside.  Anna Weinberg and her team have successfully executed a space not lacking any personal attention.  Anna glides through every corner of the restaurant greeting her guests, consulting her staff, and ensuring that everything runs smoothly.    Now let's get to the food....I had the pleasure of trying some small dishes and a dessert :)  Flavors are reminiscent of Marlowe--simple, a hint of bold, a lot delish!  Did you expect anything different?  Stars on the menu: **Fried Green Tomatoes * Buratta with fried lemon and basil (LOVED this dish) **Deviled eggs ***Just a note, they do have Brussel Sprout Chips a la Marlowe :)  The dessert menu is short and sweet.  The lemon cake cake sings :)  It's a birthday dessert that rotates each month, so get in and try it before it changes next month!  Park Tavern, thank you for bringing some well-needed style to the North Beach :)

PeSGdV9DHw5m7YGQXCCOQQ.review_text: Avocado toast and farm egg spinach were simply delicious. cool atmosphere and friendly staff. Awesome brunch spot!

8dzo1jjXZkveNIccPQ-WWw.review_text: Yum. Everything we ate (Brussels sprout chips, Grilled pork chop, Twice baked potato, and Apple/Fig Crisp) was delicious. The decor and presentation are all very well thought out.  We had no reservations and were sat at the bar. The bar staff were extremely attentive. Every few minutes someone was either checking in or filling something.

GABWrw5Et9jubriKwMUDbw.review_text: On a whim, Danielle M. and I decided to stop by Park Tavern for a few drinks which quickly turned into dinner (and me meeting her new BF!). No tables were available but we snagged 3 spots in the bar area. I think we were really lucky.  For drinks, I had a washington square which was a bit sweet for me before switching to their mclaren. They have decent wine selections as well.  Waldorf salad was not as filling as I hoped. They really skimped on the toppings.  Brussel sprout chips are a must try as everyone else has already said.  I also tried demons on horseback, steak crudo and veggie plate.   In general serving sizes were small. Next time I'm ordering a burger.

4GfceOQNwF9kkUGqWqrXmA.review_text: Food- 1/5 Overly salty. Never returning to eat  Value- 1/5  Ambiance- 4/5 Great ambiance with dim lighting and a good busy atmosphere.  Service- 5/5 Excellent service that attempted to help correct the food issues  DISHES TASTED  Smoked Deviled Eggs- 1/5 Overly salty  Pt Fries- 4/5 Edible, the best I could ask for here.  Cacciucco- 1/5 Had to send back twice. Totally inedible due to over salted.  Duo of Colorado Lamb- 1/5 Didn't bother sending back. Ate a few bites before I was overwhelmed with salt.

gGN0PBoBJufHzkAAGlmOZQ.review_text: Service excellent. Food excellent. Coconut cake excellent. Atmosphere excellent.

sHwBXS0trP0CC_f5K_11VA.review_text: On our way to Mama's one morning we walked right by Park Tavern. And even as we were standing in line for breakfast we received our reservation confirmation call. This place looks super cool, so I was excited.   The staff here was great. Everyone was super friendly and smiley. The hostess and I shared a laugh while I bounced around in my seat. CP had a glass of wine. The people watching here is great. We were seated adjacent to the bar area and there was some interesting happenings.  We had to, without a doubt, start with the deviled eggs. CP thought we should also give the fried mushrooms with french onion dip a go. The special for the evening was a sol fish with little potatoes and egg and veggies.   Even with the jalapeno, the deviled eggs weren't overwhelmingly hot. They had great flavor. I loved the touch of bacon. These are definitely a winner. Deviled eggs at restaurants can be a real joke but these lived up to the challenge and the fame. I almost bought more! Definitely delicious. As good as the eggs were, the mushrooms were very average. They were fried and they tasted fine but it was a very monotonous appetizer. Not much punch. Could have used a kick in their shroomy bottoms. Maybe some paprika? I was bored after a few bites.  Special sol was interesting. It probably wouldn't have been my go to for the meal but CP enjoyed it a lot. It was good and had many dynamic flavors, many of which I couldn't pinpoint. The egg was a brilliant touch.   Though the appetizers were both hit and miss and the entree was probably not my first choice I still enjoyed my time here. I loved the energy and the vibe, plus, there are many more exciting things I can try on the menu. SF dining success!

4c2RYnS2mdDSMwyY9xWBaQ.review_text: I was thinking that this would be an amazing place, maybe because of all the hype that built up. What I found was that it was just okay - it's not amazing but it's not like horrible either.  I came here with coworkers for an early dinner. They have unique drinks on the drink menu and the bar is packed with yuppies after work.  I will have to say the crispy lemon chips were unique and the seared scallops were good. The twice baked potato was not a baked potato but more of a casserole.  I definitely think this place was hot when it opened but I didn't find it that amazing. Worth a try though.

1jbnGoG6w7EIVcj3jPlBOw.review_text: Came here for Brunch- SOOO DELICIOUS.  I had the corn beef hash, and avocado toast.  Also really great mimosas!  Me and my friend had to wait a bit to get our order taken, and they ended giving us a discount on our bill.  I will definitely be back!

Wu9yVn0peO6P-Kb8ELH8_A.review_text: Goodbye 2011.    After a crappy Friday at work my friend and I decided we needed a treat (and dinner).  Park Tavern has been on the list, so we gave it a go.    The space is warm and inviting.  I liked the mixture of old and new decor with a grey and white color palate.  The Moose head and antlers on the wall by the bar pay homage to the original tenant, nice touch.    Our server Aura was great, she brought us a glass of wine in a quick minute to help erase our night at work.  Things were looking good.    We had deviled eggs, just the right amount of spice, the appetizer winner for us.  The fried Oyster Caesar was a little messy, but the flavors were all there.  For dinner we had the Creekstone NY Steak, red wine jus, Mangalitsa butter & french fries.  Steak cooked a perfect medium rare, tender and juicy, just what my friend was craving.  I had the grilled pork chop , Italian butter bean pistou, dinosaur kale, toasted garlic & chili flakes.  The chop was huge, double cut and cooked perfectly.  The veggies were a little on the salty side for me, but I liked the combination of flavors.  What night would be complete without dessert?  We shared the TCHO chocolate creme brulee with chocolate biscotti.  My friend is a creme brulee junkie, he totally loved this version.  The lemon zest shaved on top was really noticeable on the first bite.   The perfect end to our 2011 working life.  Cheers!

PtTZf3VF_JwSKf-rkhuvRA.review_text: SO good. Yummy food, great atmosphere and excellent service.   The goods: Brussel sprout chips, summer squashes w/egg and burrata, lobster bisque, black cod. Hubby got the pork chop, which was also quite good.   Highly reco making a reso - it's so much more comfy to sit in the dining room. Def a must-return spot.

7V_BRZYpPmTYfecdH2d4uA.review_text: Wanted to go some place special for my boo's birthday and we decided on Park Tavern.  Although the attire said "casual", one should've taken the restaurants location into consideration. To me, casual means jeans and a t-shirt. Casual for the edge of North Beach/Marina though, means all clothes should be bought at Ambience or similar and to wear 4in stiletto heels. So mind that, cover up your tattoos and you might save yourself some looks from snooty rich kids spending daddy's money.  Now, once you've gotten past the clientele, literally everything is amazing though.   Food; We started with the lemon crisps, served with burrata - it was so delicious. Never encountered deep fried, super thin slices of lemon, but it was delightfully tangy, well completed by the sweet and creamy cheese.  My fiancé had the bar steak for his entrée - it was cooked perfectly and the red wine buttered sauce--to die for. (It's wine and butter. Of course it's good.)   I had the roasted red snapper, and it was DIVINE. Served with creamy beans and the most flavourful bacon bits I've ever had. The nest of yam on top of the fish provided a nice texture.  Opted for the gingersnap ice cream sandwich for dessert and again - very good. Not overly spiced, and the ice cream super rich. Comes with chocolate ganache that's extremely decadent.   Service:  Immaculate. Nice, friendly and accommodating staff. Water-level consistently full.  Overall, highly recommend Park Tavern. It might not be your go-to-every-evening-place (as it's around $80-100/person) but it's definitely worth several visits.   PS. Once you're done with dinner, get away from this area asap. Like mentioned, money is all around and money loves to drink. A lot. Like, a looot. (I.e. I saw a man with his pants down, peeing on a car.) Seriously, get out of there.

KprhYnh_KVdsJXnR6ko2MQ.review_text: Being from out of town, I rely on Yelp, Open Table, and other review sites when choosing restaurants. So, upon reading an article on San Francisco's best new restaurants, I decided to give Park Tavern a try and was glad I did.  First off, I didn't make my 8:30pm reservation until 6:00pm that same evening and had no trouble at all, whereas all of the other SF go-to hot spots were completely booked days in advance (my own fault, I know). I'm assuming this is because Park Tavern is huge, and also it's still pretty new.  Upon arriving, the hostess was extremely friendly and helpful. Our table wasn't quite ready yet, but she made sure we were seated within a few minutes and even offered to take our drink orders while we waited. The place was insanely packed and loud, and I could definitely tell she was a pro at her job.  We started off with the deviled eggs which were INCREDIBLE. The lobster bisque was also amazing. Some of the other dishes we tried, however, weren't as great, like the arugula salad which was drowned in truffle oil and the filet mignon which was insanely salty (and I like my food over-seasoned, so you can probably imagine how much I felt like I was eating a block of salt). Overall the food was great, though, including dessert. I had the birthday cake which comes complete with a lit candle. Drinks were also amazing. In fact, their margarita is the best I've ever had-- seriously. And, the coffee comes in an adorable mini French press and is served with a cute bowl of sugar cubes.  Service and ambiance were great. I loved the Washington Square/North Beach location, the decor (love the wallpaper and tiles), and the bar area. Overall this is a great place and I hope to see it on even more "best of" lists next time I visit SF.

3IBoCe--upk24sxjM-xcxA.review_text: Had hear a lot of good things about Park Tavern.  I usually dig the New American style food.  I feel like it's the best type of menu to read my mind and present me with something that I want before I know what I want.  Also, this new place looked a bit out of the ordinary from the usual restaurants in North Beach.  So yes, I was sold, had to check it out, and finally ventured in with some friends this past weekend.     Now one item in particular that I had heard about: *Deviled eggs, bacon, pickled jalepeño & chives  $2 ea  This is supposedly a must order item.  Upon deciding to go here I immediately started thinking about them.  How good could they be?  Would they literally be the best deviled eggs I had ever had of all time?  Would I potentially eat 100?  They are only $2/each.  Would we all have a deviled egg eating contest with the winner getting 1 million dollars in Monopoly money?  Literally anything could happen...  That includes the plot twist of sitting down and upon opening my mouth to order them, the server said, "sorry to interrupt, but wanted to let you know we are out of deviled eggs."  He explained that they give these complimentary to tables that have a longer than normal wait.  I asked what they were going to send us complimentary for being out of the one item we were all desperately been wanting to try.  He stared at me blankly...Holy #$%&, the night was ruined...  But then life went on and the following was ordered among the various folks at the table...  *Kettle One/Soda with two orange slices $10 - It looked like they had a lot of good cocktails, and normally I would have gone for something like the PT Old Fashioned, but I was in a vodka/soda mood, so continued on with that simple order and made it just high maintenance enough by throwing in the two orange slices thing.  Cocktail next time. *Demons on horseback  $13 - Deliciously tasty prawns. *Housemade beef jerky  $7 - Really? Beef Jerky? Ok, whatever, it was damn good. *Lemon chips, dill pollen, burrata, & Shelley's pea tendrils  $13 - Not enough lemon chips to go with the burrata, but I guess that is ok, I managed to finish it off. *"Marlowe" burger, caramelized onion, cheddar, bacon, horseradish aioli & fries  $14 - I didn't order this, but of course I tried a bite.  This burger alone is worth a trip back.  It was delicious! *"Poulet Rouge" Bloomsdale spinach & Peewee potatoes  $25 - This was my epic order and this game hen rules.  I honestly enjoyed this more than the uninspired chicken at Zuni Cafe.  Throw in the delicious spinach and pewee potatoes and this was simply a homerun. Not to mention they serve it upright in this giant iron skillet type thing.  We were sitting in the middle of the dining room, so I'm assuming that anyone on the fence of what to order saw what I had and followed my lead.   This obviously most likely lead to soaring profits that night, which I'll take credit for.    So I wish I had room for dessert, but that game hen won.  I was stuffed.  Good times, and I plan to be back.  Hopefully they will deliver complimentary deviled eggs based on this incredibly sad story about being out the first time I visited.

tBDQQarnlqkPXVFGan9Iog.review_text: Was super busy on a Wednesday around 7:45pm. We talked with the hostess saying that a table would be about 45 minutes, but they gave us the option of dining at the bar or at the communal table. Decided to get a drink and put our name on the bar's dining list. The bartender was really nice and said that there was a party of two before my friend and I, and he got us started on drinks. About 15 minutes later, he came over and said that he had to unseat us because someone had to take the seat I was sitting on to dine. He felt really bad, so he comp'd our drinks (@ $12 each, I didn't mind that one bit). He then sent us back to the hostess and within 10 minutes she got us a seat. Granted, it was at the communal table, but I didn't care at this point. At least they were super nice and accommodating about it.   Now the review:  Bread: Eh, could have done without it, but I was starving.  Fries: Eh, standard. Not much to say about it. It came with parsley and horseradish aioli which made my face scrunch up. Weird combo, but I guess there's people who like it...  Roasted Halibut: Fish was cooked perfectly, but a little too salty for my taste.  Friend ordered the Pork Chop: Really good from my taste of it.  For drinks we both got the Greenpoint (Bulleit Rye, Yellow Chartreuse, vermouth & bitters). I love this drink; I've been here once before for drinks and I ordered this one then, with dinner this last time, and probably if I ever make it back out here.  Overall, the food was good, but I'm giving 4 stars mainly because of the service.

6V4QDJkw9guD4Em8YeUvtQ.review_text: Everything was delicious. Deviled egg blew my mind! Fried lemon slices with burrata cheese and fresh basil, divine. Carrots with pesto danced on my pallet. Would love to go back and just get drinks and apps. Yum!

npUTvnCyHBFS85y1V9Wm4A.review_text: We went there for brunch and got a great table outside.  The location and service were great, but the food was definitely over priced for breakfast. It would have been nice if they had at least one traditional item on the breakfast menu.

7Gd5Xgi2o7-a3zmwxosIQg.review_text: This is one of my new favorite places to eat in San Francisco.  It's big and comfortable, and I really appreciate how the staff is friendly and helpful.  Thoughts on Park Tavern:  1) The "Marlowe Burger" is better here than at Marlowe.  Strange, but convenient for me.  2) The service is much better at Park Tavern than at Marlowe.  Marlowe servers are somewhat unfriendly and sloppy.  3) Must eats:  -Poulet Rouge.  A whole game hen served standing on a cast iron pan.  People will stare.  I actually loved the accompanying spinach the first time, but last night the spinach was too salty!  -Pork Chop:  This is no Nopa pork chop, but the flavor is great and the texture is perfect (if you're ok with pink pork).  The first time we tried to order this, they ran out!  So go on a weeknight.  -Birthday cake: I'm not kidding, their layered cake is perfect.  I got chocolate; next time I want to try coconut.  Not too sweet.  When I ordered this, the bf didn't want dessert....but he ended up eating half of it in 10 seconds!
