 -NY Steak Crudo: This is the best raw beef I've had.  I like it better than tartare (although I do love Marlowe's spicy tartare!)  -Wild arugula, mushroom conserva, porcini & charred onion vinaigrette.  Yes, this is a salad.  The charred onion vinaigrette is delicious.  It's smoky and pungent and I tried to lick my plate clean.  It's a large portion and shareable.  We split this in 2 and each had a "dinner salad" at some other restaurants. **If I came alone, I would actually order the Steak Crudo and the Arugula salad as my dinner.  -Deviled egg: I thought this would taste too bacony (as in the bacon flavor overpowering everything else), but the bacon, pickle, and egg together are pretty awesome.  -Brussels Sprout Chips: I love these at Marlowe--they're fried perfectly and are lemony.  When we ordered these last night, they came out over-fried and burned-tasting.  Also they were greasier at Park Tavern.  Could just be an off batch.  :(  4) Things I'd Skip:  -Fried Pork Belly Bites: not for me.  You have to really like pork fat to eat these.  They're mostly fat, almost no meat.  And they're coated.  I prefer flash fried and braised pork belly.  -Creamed seasonal greens: When we ordered this, the sauce had a truffled goat cheese in it.  I had not expected this.  I don't like things to be truffled (overpowering taste) and I don't like goat cheese.  I couldn't eat it.  -Twice baked potato.  I also didn't like this one.  It was just OK.  Cheese was a little sharp for me for such a rich dish.  I would have liked some acidity and some more salt on this.

kkAFJLviQ_dp1nChCvi3-Q.review_text: Went here for my birthday din this past October.......awwwwwwwwwwesome! Deviled eggs were amazingness, brussel chips were chippy, and my pork chop was huge! I  had leftovers because the portions are great- go there hungry!  Bar is always packed- so if you are looking for a drink and a seat....better get there early.

FDMl5am0sisi1n7mR7hvzA.review_text: OK on fried brussel sprouts and salad.  My entree was supposed to be a pork chop, but tasted weird.   Very vinegary if that makes sense.  Not crazy about the change in decor from Mooses.   Everything is out in the open which makes the room seem too busy.    I will try again.

C0UknZBqI7DdYFu_nhgPuQ.review_text: The place is very pretty. The service is professional. The food is just ok.  We came on a Sunday night for dinner to meet out of town guests.  It has a large dining room area and an open kitchen so it was a good place for a group, albeit somewhat loud.  Entrees are priced between $20-35.  I had scallops, which were cooked really nicely, but sloppily thrown on a plate with prosciutto and spinach.  Also ordered at the table were the burger, red snapper, and the restaurant's version of cioppinno (can't recall what they call it).  No one was over-impressed with what they had, especially at that price-point.  Probably won't return- plenty of other great restaurants to try in this city.

yEF0YuRgBXIjYiIoKKoIXw.review_text: I would not consider myself a "fine diner" and the menu scared me because I didn't know what anything was! But the waiter was so helpful and knowledgeable about the menu. I ordered the Malowe Burger. IT WAS AMAZING!! The others I was with order pork chops, scallops, chicken and the filet. Everything was great! It's also a beautiful place inside with a cool bar on the other side. Highly recommend this place to try something different and delicious.

BFNVTFyGZZ_IzzWCRpPrbg.review_text: I said the same thing about Wayfare Tavern,  this place is just ok. Man oh man, what can you say about this place?  1.) it's trendy? 2.) the food is whatever (for the main courses, but the brussel sprout chips are to die for.).  Just nothing special about these places anymore, just trendy, i need something that excites me something that wows. This is not one of those places, it's just an ehhh, or wah wah. lol but yeah.  actually i wanted to update this. it's actually two stars, because my food came out cold not once but twice. BOO on that...

b8EnjL9DwA6rNDQ9yoIwWg.review_text: Can't speak for the food since I've never eaten here but a great place to sit at the bar and have a glass of whiskey or scotch near Washington Square Park. Bartenders are nice and quick. Not too crowded but never dead.

wT3KT-3jvLLXynC8ss8Whg.review_text: Came in for a dinner a couple of nights ago and loved the set-up! Our seat faced the large windows and provided us w/a great view of Washington Square Park.  Cocktails and service were great!  For starters we had the:  Infamous deviled eggs - definitely lived up to the hype! Next time, we're just gong to order 20 of these alone!  Rabbit, duck and foie gras terrain - didn't pair well w/the mustard and pickles. The dish itself was very acidic and the flavors weren't well balanced. The terrain was a little too salty for my liking.  Oysters Caesar - way too fishy! While the concept is nice, I'd rather have fresh raw oysters w/o the grit, slime and fry.  For our entree we shared the game hen. It came in a cast iron skillet and was extremely tender! The sauteed spinach, potatoes and butter stock sauce were perfect compliments to the dish!   The dishes ended up being 2/4 but I'd definitely come again.

dqxnx_vls8X_PVEAYQChHA.review_text: Came here for easter brunch and it didn't disappoint. As someone who used to be a North Beach local, I'm really happy to see that they've completely turned this space around. The rustic woods and blue-grey walls made this place masculine and warm.   We started off our meal with the warm baguette with goat milk butter and a variety of jams. It was delicious. Everyone in our party agreed we could eat this as our entire meal.   Then we also tried the following items: Raspberry & Blueberry Dutch Baby - This was delicious and we saved this for our 'desert' item. The berries were a good combination of sweet and tart.   Butter Lettuce & Maine Lobster salad - This left little to be desired. It had a nice flavor but we couldn't find much lobster on it. Not worth the $17.   Crispy Polenta Cakes with Wild Mushrooms - The flavor of this plate was amazing, especially if you are a mushroom/truffle lover. I'm usually not a fan of grit-like texture and runny eggs, but the combination of ingredients on this plate were great.   I enjoyed the entire experience - the decor, the meal, the company.   The next time I'm in town I'll be back for lunch and/or dinner.

dKMeLjR5--noz5MYXNygFQ.review_text: My favorite restaurant from my trip to SF this June. We came here for brunch and it was probably better than any brunch I've had in NYC!  We ordered a feast and tried a ton of things. Must haves:  - Avocado toast  (it is THE BOMB) - Nut butters - Deviled egg sandwich - Pancakes (if you want to splurge)  I tried the duck hash and didn't love it, but my friends did.  Service: Very friendly and attentive.

QppL8xnnNt4IjXaK5Si3hw.review_text: Ten yips for the crowd! Before entering the restaurant  a line of good looking people seated outside under heating lamps can be taken in. The space inside is vast but not cold. The menu has  a diverse enough range of items that anyone could be happy, yet it's a small menu. Out of 7 dishes 5 were excellent, one good and one whatever. I loved the atmosphere and the crowd. Anna, one of the owners, hand delivered a special drink to us. It was packed (definitely need a reservation) yet not noisy. Great experience- especially for the eye candy! Deviled eggs are so good!

sgiF4xmzbq__evyAevKApQ.review_text: Update- two words for your mouth: CAULIFLOWER SALAD. I. cant.get.enough.  Oh, but I saw stars during the consumption of their brussels sprout chips.

RscoPhnfz9HFXN7X8czFlg.review_text: Amazing brunch!!!!! Smoked Salmon Benedict is out of this world!!! We also had an avocado toast and coconut fritters with orange and chocolate sauce as starters. The place has nice decor and excellent service. Yummy cocktails and selection of wines too!

Kw-5I9azSEEUe7RTq1MG-Q.review_text: A group of friends and I had dinner at Park Tavern this past weekend and I was pleasantly surprised.  If you watched that chick flick with Reese Witherspoon and Mark Ruffalo featured in SF, part of it was filmed here.  I love the open air ambiance outside and tall ceilings and abundant amount of space between tables which made our dining experience even better.  Food: Pork Belly Bites (delicious!) Burrata Cheese with lemon and basil (Very innovative and something I never had and would definitely order again) Uni on butter Lettuce (Interesting combination, I've never had uni on lettuce, but they give you a generous portion of uni) Fries with Garlic Aioli Seared Scallops  Chocolate Creme Brulee (the biscotti was burnt, would probably opt for the Apple/Fig Crisp)  I would definitely come back again to try their other dishes as well.  The service at Park Tavern was stellar and they also had a great cocktail menu that is worth checking out.

lLfcbYGTeVxQN5Ig0ompJg.review_text: Met up Rodney H, Bobby L & Peter L this past Tues. Started at the bar. Drinks are good. Nice and stiff just the way I like them! For drinks, we tried:  Mclaren: Hendrick's gin, cucumber, lemon & ginger beer ($13) This was kind of like alcoholic spa water. Not my fav since it was so light, but it had a refreshing quality to it.  PT old fashioned: Old overholt rye, cherry, bitters ($12) My favorite cocktail of the night! It was dark and strong.  Country lawyer: Knob creek bourbon, zucca amaro, vermouth & bitters ($13) Even though it was dark and boozy it was just a touch too sweet for me.  Duboce: Bank note scotch, yellow chartreuse, benedictine & bitters ($12) A very pretty cocktail.   Now onto the food! Between the four of us, it took us a while to pinpoint what we wanted. We finally settled on the following.   Smoked deviled eggs: bacon, pickled jalapeno & chive ($2 ea) Best deviled eggs ever! The bacon, jalapeno and chive just elevated the eggs. If I were coming back for a snack at the bar, I'd come back for this! Sooo good!  PT fries: truffle, soft cooked egg, caviar ($14) Omg! These were amazing! Probably one of the best versions of truffle fries that I've had. The fries were crispy but soft in the center. And dipped in the egg and caviar or truffle dip?! I was in heaven!  Wagyu beef jerky ($7) I didn't care for this. I typically like my beef jerky softer, so this wasn't my fav.  Braised lamb tongue: french fingerling potatoes, mustard greens, soft cooked hen egg & horseradish ($14) I picked this dish since I love tongue! The tongue was soft but I wanted something crunchy on the dish to give it texture. Everything on the plate had a rather mushy texture.  Grass fed ribeye: potato puree, baby carrots, cipollinis, blue lake beans, arugula & chimichurri ($38) The steak was cooked perfectly!  Poulet vert: fines herbs, french fingerlings, thumbelina carrots, baby leeks & mustard jus ($29) This was as beautiful as it was delicious! The hen was super moist and juicy! I was actually expecting the hen to be larger, but it's a good size for one or for sharing.   Venison carpaccio: classic angus beef tartare, capers & crispy bone marrow ($18) The tartare was excellent! We got this a little later so I only took a bite. I didn't realize there was crispy bone marrow until after dinner when I was looking over the menu! So bummed since I didn't try the fried marrow!   The rest of the dishes I don't recall too well. A few drinks and lots of coursed plates can do that to me from time to time, but we also got: -Grilled pork chop: cranberry bean & sweet pepper ragout, preserved tomato, red mustard & peppadew ($27) -Wood oven roasted beets: agrodolce goat cheese & breadcrumbs ($8) -Brown butter brussels sprouts: parmesan & chili flakes ($8)  Since it was Bobby's birthday and we were celebrating, our server gave us a free dessert! We got the birthday cake since it was fitting and also ordered the creme brulee. The July's birthday cake ($9) with James vanilla & strawberry creme cake, mixed berry compote & cream cheese frosting was light and fluffy and not too sweet. The Tcho chocolate creme brulee ($8) with chocolate biscotti, chili, lemon zest & sea salt wasn't really my cup of tea since it mixed sweet and salty, but everyone else loved it!  After the meal, we were all talking about how great the Deviled eggs and PT fries were. Everyone loved them! I'd definitely come back just for those dishes! Add the Poulet vert and that may just be the perfect meal!

hvjhcPOG8zuqqLOohDKBmA.review_text: We have always walked pass Park Tavern many times since my boyfriend use to live in the neighborhood. Finally, we decided to stop by since it has always been on our to-try list.     The crowd ranges from mainly 30's to 50's.   Generally, the establishment is modern and chic. After getting seated, we knew immediately that we wanted to try the brussel sprout chips, the pork chop, and the Poulet Rouge which is a whole chicken. Be warned that the Poulet Rouge may take awhile to cook.    The brussel sprout chips were delicious. Perfectly salted and crispy. They were fun to eat!   The pork chop was moist, I thoroughly enjoyed the taste with the sweet apple pairing with polenta. Halfway through my meal, it started to feel a bit heavy.     The Poulet Rouge looked intense as it is served on a platter sitting upwards. Overall, my boyfriend thought it was okay as it started to taste heavy as he ate further into the dish.     Our waitress was splendid. She constantly came back to check on us to make sure everything was tasting okay and that our water was filled.    3.5 stars. Park Tavern. Check.

KXNpk_cGjtWO241sTyPQwA.review_text: Large restaurant for SF. The cocktails were okay, the deviled eggs were the best thing we had. Our charcuterie board (our waiter's favorite thing on the menu) was mediocre at best. The bone marrow, which I didn't know could be anything be succulent and delicious food of the gods, was undercooked and just not cooked right somehow. The foie gras was lacking in the rich buttery flavor it should have and had a texture more like the gelatinous bone marrow fat.  The only other thing I actually enjoyed were the Shrimp with avocado and lardo (the name was something horseman, I dunno) but that's just because I fucking love shrimp. The avocado was so unripe it was literally crunchy. I don't know how they cut the thing into slices.  Obviously, I would be judging the place much less harsh if my bill was under $175 for two people, but it wasn't. I would consider myself ripped off for mediocre food I could have easily made better.

G2PlwBajzyIYAr9JfAFfeg.review_text: Absolutely delicious! A bit on the pricey side, but if you don't mind spending the money, it's well worth it! Be sure to make a reservation as it's always busy. If you go for brunch, don't forget to order a Hummingbird! Yum.

tj2GPWuaJsTbR2YwP6Yd7Q.review_text: My friends and I came to Park Tavern to celebrate a couple of birthdays (and yes, one of them was mine).  We had a 5:30 pm reservation on a Saturday night and expected to walk into a half empty restaurant but the place was packed and bustling at that early hour.  I would describe this restaurant as a place that serves comfort food with great service in a brasserie setting.  Seated at a table along the wall, we had a great view of the restaurant, kitchen and bar area.  While waiting for the rest of the party to arrive, three of us started off with some of PT's house cocktails.  I tried the Washington Square and really enjoyed the various flavors of the drink - hints of bitterness with citrus and ginger.  One friend ordered the Country Lawyer and although that drink smells like it could put hair on ones chest, it was actually quite pleasant and went down rather smoothly.  No hairy chests to be found on all those that took a sip!  To whet our appetites we ordered the Demons on Horseback (shrimp wrapped in lardo), burrata with lemon and basil and the charcuterie platter.  Personally the housemade charcuterie platter was my favorite, as the salami and pate were delicious.  The shrimp was okay, but nothing special.  The burrata seemed to be a hit with one friend.  The fried lemon slices are really, really good and I would pop them like chips if I could.  For the entree I ordered the Poulet Rouge with spinach and peewee potatoes (they were really cute).  The chicken is roasted on a vertical rack, with the spinach and potatoes recipients of the juices that drip down from the chicken.  The dish is so simple, yet so good.  The chicken, aside from being a sight to behold, was moist and tender and full of flavor.  The meat was pretty much falling off the bone, and a knife isn't really needed.  Make sure you ask for extra bread to sop up all those chicken juices.  For dessert, we ordered the birthday cake (with two candles), Arnold Palmer boozy float, the cheese plate and the apple crisp.  They ended up delivering two very generous slices of birthday cake (chocolate with chocolate buttercream frosting), each with a candle (trick candles too!) and both were on the house!  That was so incredibly nice of them.  And who doesn't love a well made birthday cake (sorry, but supermarket cake frosting icks me out)!  The person that created the Arnold Palmer float is a genius.  There is no stopping after that first sip.  The apple crisp was good and full of the flavors of the fruit.  I'm not big on eating desserts but in this case that cake was so good I couldn't stop digging my fork into it.   I wish more places offered birthday cake for dessert.  Sometimes a simple dessert is the perfect ending to a meal of comfort food.  Our wait staff was on point and provided great service, answering all of our questions and making sure our needs were met.  Given how busy it was, we were really happy with the attention we received.  PT is a good place for dinner and/or drinks for large and small groups.   Would I come back?  Absolutely.  How does it compare to Marlowe?  PT is more like the big city cousin, a bit more formal than Marlowe, which is more laid back and casual.

OcFOBEDwGMdeTrJseGpcWA.review_text: Possibly my new favorite restaurant in San Francisco.  Great location near pre-dinner cocktail spots...or just drink at the bar inside.  Menu items to order:  Cocktail:  Country Lawyer Appetizers:  Deviled Eggs, Brussels Sprouts Chips, Demons on Horseback Entree:  Pork Chop Dessert:  Creme Brulee  Bo was our waiter and he recommended our entire dinner.  Looking forward to going back ASAP!

gBGJoOnWxfUHn4-A2Ei5Tg.review_text: Michael Mina, Gary Danko been there done that. But Park Tavern, now there's something special!  Saturday morning Brunch was AMAZING!!! Service was top notch. Staff was very attentive and intuitive. I stated in our reservation that we were celebrating our anniversary, when we arrived not only did we get one of the best seats in the house we also received two large glasses of champagne, compliments of the house.  Bravo Park Tavern!!!

saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q.review_text: Wow... (slowly nodding my head sideways). Expectations can be high after reading the numerous reviews about this rejuvenated North Beach hot spot; especially, when hearing that I no longer needed to trek to Marlowe to try their famed burger or deviled eggs.  I called the restaurant about ten days earlier and scored a 5:30 pm reservation for a Friday night.  The dining room was barely half full, but the bar was already hopping.  We were seated at a window table, which probably sheltered us some from the noise level that progressively rose as diners arrived.  The menu offered a large selection of choices, but I already had some idea of what to order.  Our waiter was helpful in recommending the third appetizer and fulfilling my fruity nonalcoholic drink request.  Here's what we ate: Appetizers (all shared) 1) Deviled Eggs (yelp.com/biz_photos/4-pW…) - This signature dish lived up to the hype. 2) Lemon Chips (yelp.com/biz_photos/4-pW…) - Paper thin slices with pleasant zest, but, given the price, something we'd probably pass on next time. 3) Demons on  horseback (yelp.com/biz_photos/4-pW…) - Recommended by our waiter, the large spot prawns were clean flavored and the bacon gave a nice fatty, savory contrast. 4) Marlowe Burger (yelp.com/biz_photos/4-pW…) - Cut in quarters for sharing, the burger was good, but not quite to die for. Entree 5) Grilled Pork Chop (yelp.com/biz_photos/4-pW…) - Cooked to a perfect medium temperature, the pork had a pleasant combination of tenderness from the center meat and firm bounce from the grilled outer areas. Dessert (shared) - 6) Creamsicle (yelp.com/biz_photos/4-pW…) - Topped with a candle for the birthday guest, the visual surprisingly lived up to the namesake's flavors.  Hope this is on the menu next trip. As we relaxed while waiting for our food, we couldn't help but notice the variety of vehicles that pulled up to the valet stand; one could liken it to an auto show, testament to their customers' demographics.  Service was efficient and water/drink glasses were filled; empty plates were quickly cleared.   Overall, this was one of the finer meals I've experienced recently in the City.  Plus it left me wanting to return for MORE!

6Ybb_OZGa3LlxbuQBQ2URQ.review_text: Great place!  Love the wine and aperitif selection.  Awesome brunch selection - burger was great, the corn beef hash with red wine jus was awesome, baguette with various jam - great!  Was a nice place to visit after a run in the Marina.

9lXsiuafHP753IAUu4pzWQ.review_text: Jeff & Jack-Bartenders-adore. thank you for  satisfying our taste bud needs.   must haves: +Lemon Chips +deviled eggs +scallops  overall vibe: sheek & sexy. I love love the decor. especially the fresh cut flowers in the restroom. such a sweet touch.  Great date place, very intimate & a perfect music selection that sets the vibe. A classic & beautiful spot.   Thank you, Park Tavern.

PLgh5zMyL9TbR7eYJOWBBw.review_text: We went here for brunch on my wife's birthday and I have to say that other than the unfavorable food portion-to-price ratio, we were definitely pleased with the quality of the food and even more so the service.  We set reservations for 10am when the restaurant opened and when we got there, we were seated outside in front as it was a bright sunny day. We sat there fore a while without anyone coming to take our order. Right when I was about to speak up, the owner came out and explained that the main waiter was running late. So the owner who was extremely nice sparked up a conversation with us and apologized for making us wait. He ended up taking our order which was fine.   So we ordered the pan-fried corn beef hash, cast iron-baked farm eggs, and an order of  buttermilk pancakes. To top it off, I ordered the boozy smoothie cocktail. We thought the food was delicious. My only complaint is that the boozy smoothie, while really good, was definitely smaller than I expected for the price.   We didn't really experienced the ambience inside (since we sat in front) but the outside tables had comfortable chairs and the tables were nicely decorated with white flowers (my wife's favorite).   Overall, we enjoyed the experience and the food. We would definitely recommend that our friends check this place out at least for brunch. We hope to make it back sometime to check out their lunch and dinner menus.

dTS_EwGO103TaeyJ4U1IOg.review_text: The atmosphere is so warm, cozy & comfortable here.   For brunch: Love the avocado on wheat toast. It sounds so plain but it packs so much flavor. Spicy, tangy & salty all in one. We tried ordering it during dinner too but it's only served during brunch.  Brussels sprouts chips are a must here. Wherever I go & order brussels sprouts I always compare them to Park Tavern. None have ever compared to these.   I always tend to get the negroni here. Strong, bold & delicious.   Overall everything is consistently excellent here.

cD3EsTkWRDOyjaDCay72TA.review_text: I came to Park Tavern last night on an impromptu man date and was pleasantly surprised.  Gastropub meets restaurant in north beach, very spacious, nice ambiance and friendly service staff.  I want to give this place 5 stars based purely on their lobster bisque; it was DELICIOUS.  It came with a log of salted filo dough and crab.  What else is a man to ask for?  The rest of the meal, however, was on the 3-star level.  The fillet was just okay and the dessert, birthday cake, was very underwhelming.  We also had the beef tartar for a snack to start and while the first bite was tasty, it was too oily and heavy for my taste.  the price was right for me to come back, if only for another taste of that delicious bisque!

P5bUL3Engv-2z6kKohB6qQ.review_text: Having been a fan  of Anna Weinberg's South and its transition to Marlowe, I couldn't pass up the opening of Park Tavern. I enjoyed Moose's back in the day, that gave way to Joey and Eddie's and has since shuttered. Now the Marlowe team with Dave Stanton of Tres Agaves has taken the Marlowe concept and multiplied it in a singularly large space. They've darkened the interior and given it a nice brasserie classic look. After having a business meeting across the square, we made our way over for dinner.  Some Marlowe classics and some new ones to be sure read across the menu, all sounding very good. With four people you can do a lot of damage so our order storm looked like:  -NY Steak crudo, horseradish, arugula & parmesan -Brussels sprout chips -Sea salt & vinegar pork rinds -Pork belly bites, horseradish aioli -House made beef jerky -Fried oysters "Caesar" salad -Yellow Doll watermelon & Mangalitsa prosciutto, truffle & mustard greens -Creamed seasonal greens -Roasted farmers market peppers -Twice baked potato, crème fraiche, cheddar & scallions -Anson Mills polenta, roasted nectarines & balsamic glaze -Park Tavern "Poulet Rouge", Bloomsdale spinach & Peewee potatoes -Lamb chops, Merguez sausage, greens -Fernet milkshake -Seasonal Fruit crumble  Did I say we were having a feast? As to Marlowe's excellence everything was delicious. We finished just about everything. A fantastic meal. Even their cocktail program is excellent. I had a drink I'd never seen before, the County Lawyer,which is a classic throwback to the days of yore. Our server took great care of us and made quite a few great recommendations. I think one of the highest praises you can give a restaurant is that if you can't tell that they just opened, they're doing something right. It flowed like they'd been open for a while. Definitely worth a trip back if you're on this side of town and not already at Marlowe.

qR33aCiEU2hbq5fBC-dFOw.review_text: I will probably receive some backlash for this one, but I digress...  I am currently attempting to go to a new restaurant every week during the calendar year of 2012.  Park Tavern is restaurant number 3 for me.  Ambiance:  This place is sleek.  Like really sleek.  It has a very sophisticated, 1920s decor.  I was personally absorbed with the vantage point from the front door; to the right you see a very classic bar that has both standing and tall tables, while to the left you have the main dining area.  You may catch yourself being absorbed with the modernly metallic, yet classically appealing lighting, same as you may come to appreciate the intricacies of the tiled floor.  The bathroom is also quite impressive.  Service:  Ack, the sticking point.  We ordered about 5 things - two entrees plus three items from the small plates/appetizer menu.  The food came out in a disjointed series of some together, some later on, and some being forgotten.  We sat for a good 15 minutes before our order was taken, and we spent another 10 minutes before our drinks arrived.  Mind you, this was on a Sunday night, but it was the Sunday before MLK Jr. Day, so it was unusually busy.  The bright spot is that when we asked for our Deviled Eggs (the item that never came and had been forgotten), the waiter was kind enough to comp us for it on our bill.  Food:  We came here specifically because of a review that I saw in the San Francisco Chronicle.  We were prepared to be wow-ed if not amazed.  In the end, it was good, but nothing was amazing great.  One item in particular that we REALLY wanted was the Brussel Sprout chips.  They were out (grin).  So we got the Deep Fried Oysters...  They were okay.  We also got the deviled eggs... which were tasty.  We split a burger, and they were kind enough to double up on the fries that came with it, but... nothing about this burger was remarkable.  Maybe next time we'll try different items.  I give this place a 3.5 - 3.75.  I'll try it again someday, but hopefully I'll have a better time.

eLV697jJLboCJzX2pE6GYg.review_text: The cheese plate was pretty good. The soft Harbison cheese was my favorite. Excellent pork chop: juicy, tender, succulent... I could go on. The deviled egg is necessary. The chocolate creme brulee with chili flakes and sea salt was quite mouth watering.   Interior design: Nice open layout with various configurations for seating. The bench is  a lot lower than the chair which was a little awkward. Ambiance is great. Our server was very knowledgeable and friendly. Also for the sober people out there they have a great cocktail called the Mclaren that they can make non-alcoholic: cucumber, lemon and ginger beer.   Highly recommend.

8lOracR1RGUyNaWB8-6wTw.review_text: I am giving this place 3 stars based on service and entrees. I have been here twice and each time, i had wished that I just ordered an assortment of appetizers instead of my $30 entree that I didn't love. This past visit I ordered the halibut(one of the two pescatarian items on the menu. No vegetarian item entrees and the other fish entree had bacon in it) the portion was extremely small and my favorite part ended up being the corn that sat underneath the fish. It just didn't have much seasoning or any sauce.(on a side note, my friend ordered the pork and he loved it. and the portion was HUGE). I know their menu is seasonal so i may have better luck next time.  The hostess staff is excellent. I know they are always busy and you always need to have a reservation but when the 4 of us walked in, they were able to seat us immediately outside under a few heat-lamps and provided blankets. wonderful. :)  I was disappointed in our server. He seemed a little out of it. We ordered drinks and they took close to 20-25 minutes to get them. When we ordered our second round of drinks, again it took close to 20 minutes. Our bill was almost $300 and we couldn't get our drinks. IT was just weird. The whole meal process was very long....  On the upside, i love the appetizers. The brussel sprout chips, marinated olives and devilied eggs are yummy. I can't wait to try the crab dip and the cornmeal crusted oysters :)

NLIqrSQY_nN7beHg3Mb8ow.review_text: Park Tavern is a great venue if you're going for a fun social evening...but don't go there if you're looking for great food.  I went on a Sunday night with 3 other friends for an early 5:30 dinner reservation and were able to to enjoy the esthetics of the very chic, upscale bistro.  My party of 4 all started with Martini's and I was served my drink in a very chipped Martini Glass. When I showed it to my waiter, he took my drink away and I had to remind him 10 minutes later that I was waiting for the return of my cocktail. The Brussel Sprout Chips were ok...but I certainly don't understand all the chatter they're getting on these YELP pages!  The Poulet Noir which I saw on a YELP photo as a HUGE Rotisserie Chicken bursting with herbed stuffing was neither HUGE or BURSTING with stuffing...In fact, it was a sad little cornish game hen with no stuffing, served on a bed of burnt sauteed spinach.  A very sad looking dish...Brad had the Mussels which were served in a tomato garlic broth and was very tasty.  My other friend and I each ordered a C.A.B. NY Steak--which was 3 or 4 pieces of Steak served with fingerling potatoes and it was just ok...when I order a steak at a bistro, please serve it hot, sizzling and WHOLE...what's this piece meal crap?  Didn't want to chance a mediocre dessert as it certainly wouldn't be worth the calories if it was anything like the dishes we received up til then.   Prices seem very high for the quality of food--I'd rather spend the same amount of dough at House of Prime Rib when I'm in a carnivorous mood.  Probably better to go there for Cocktails before heading elsewhere in that fabulous North Beach Location.   What a disappointment...I really was hoping Park Tavern would be great.

lGNr8HxAbHfdHQr5Zs5GGA.review_text: Meh. Way too loud for anything other than a party. The food was ok but not memorable at all.   Marlowe has better atmosphere and food.

WvcjxSXG7PCSmWj9g4clSQ.review_text: Delicious brunch, the eggs with polenta and the cod cakes are solid. The challah bread is a must order. The ambiance is cool and rustic, especially for brunch.

giedJnthMXJXCkGrEvsH6g.review_text: Had an amazing Fathers Day brunch here. Brioche cinnamon toast for the kiddo, smoked cod cake, peach and avocado with cottage cheese, and avocado toast for the adults. Refreshing, creative and delicious!

DvcGLctH2BqT4tYsvscI0A.review_text: Two words: TRUFFLE. FRIES.  Because I ate this as an appetizer, this set the pallet for the rest of the night. Unfortunately, I was a little disappointed with my meal because it wasn't as great as the fries. I mean, I get it... Anything with truffle is amazing, I just thought the food would be just as good.  Service was good, but not the greatest.  Four stars are dedicated to the ambiance and truffle fries. I'll be back for those.

BtPJRmt_MR198EAmrDy2cg.review_text: This is as good as it gets in North Beach.  The PT fries, in house beef jerky, and other snack work perfect at the bar.  The crowds can get out of control, but the beauty of the restaurant, location, stellar food, and the drinks are amazing.    Jack and Brian are an insanely good team.  Order off menu and let them work their magic if you catch them at a slow late hour.

WOlfaz4vzUNvNxCScXeYrg.review_text: Love this place!  I have been there for a New Year's Pre Fixe dinner as well as dinner on regular nights and all of it is supperb.  Not only is the place nice aestehtically but the staff is top notch.  A must have are the deviled eggs and the bar steak as well as any of the salads they have.  I have also tried a pork chop they had on the menu and it was mouth watering good.  This place is perfect for a date, business dinner, casual dinner or special occassion dinner.  I cannot reommend it enough.

JvNMi2Oh6o6SfcIsq73KNA.review_text: Came here on opening night and this place has great potential.  I can really see the poulet vert becoming a signature dish.  Definitely worth trying.

S9a4Cn0tdBJDn3dYvh2NHg.review_text: Celebrating  New Year's Eve Eve! A friend had recommended this place as having some of the best food in SF right now, so we popped in shortly after they opened at 5 pm. Sitting at the bar, we were served right away by Mark. He was engaging and attentive, offering good tips and wine tastes. The bar filled in quickly as did the restaurant. We ordered the burgers and simple salad, both excellent. We will definitely be back--either early as we did that night or with a reservation--this place is happening and prepare to wait if you do neither.

4T2uVlRjkl0eogswfL2bTA.review_text: Food: High quality, unique combinations, and overall very delicious! I highly recommend trying the deviled eggs, they come with crispy bacon on top! Also ordered the carrot pesto salad, pork chop, and scallops.  Drinks: Sophisticated cocktail menu, I tried the Oaxacan Flower which  was very smokey. The coffee was really good as well and perfect close to a relaxing evening.   Service: Attentive, food and drink came out quickly!  Ambiance: It honestly feels like a large, modern and fancy tavern. It has a great bar when you walk in. The entire place is dimly lit. There were mostly couples and small groups dining.   I recommend this place for a special occasion, we came here for our anniversary! For a complete dining expereince you will sepnd well over $100, but totally worht it!

5gbkhlWANGVzQYi_0m3vOQ.review_text: Wow, I loved my meal at Park Tavern from the food, to the drinks, to the service. The atmosphere is trendy and spacious, perfect for a date or a small group. Must eats - deviled eggs, marlowe burger, short ribs. Must drink their cocktails, everything is amazing and reminds me of the mixology at Beretta or Locanda.   * BREAD: Tasted like Acme - always a good thing :)  * DEVILED EGGS ($2 / half egg): Topped with a crispy, thin slice of bacon, and made with pickled jalapeno and chives. Wow, I did not know deviled eggs could be so delicious!   * TRUFFLED FONDUE with torn bread ($14): This was an interesting dish, with a hint of truffle which you could smell more than taste. $14 for a small-ish bowl of cheese and a side of torn up bread seems steep.  * MARLOWE BURGER ($14): Wow, delicious and juicy I can see why people rave about it! It seems so simple - carmelized onion, cheddar and bacon, but it was so delicious. Comes with fries and horseradish sauce on the side.  * POULET NOIR ($28): This is a whole chicken, incredibly flavorful down to the core. I just wish it was a little more tender and that they used a bigger chicken. Still prefer Zuni, for overall flavor and juiciness, but this was really good.  * BRAISED BEEF SHORT RIBS ($24): Every component of this dish was so perfect, and tasted very soulful. I could eat this every day.  * SIDE BRUSSELS SPROUTS ($8): Too bitter on the inside, yet overcooked with too much butter. Pass.  * HARBISON CHEESE: Soft, white cows milk cheese. I never order the cheese course because it's too extravagant, but this was a winner and I'm glad I got it. The cheese was soft and paired perfectly with cab. Awesome cab.  * PANNA COTTA ($7): I'm picky with my panna cotta and like when it's uber thick and creamy. This was good, but more delicate like the type at Seven Hills, like it's made with more gelatin or low fat milk. Good but would not get again.  * APPLE CRANBERRY CRISP ($7): I was surprised by the large portion size, it was good and tasted exactly like I would have expected but don't plan to get it again.  * BLOOD AND SAND ($12): If you like scotch mixed with something sweet and tart, this is the perfect balance.   * OLD CUBAN ($12): I preferred the old cuban because it was more refreshing and felt less potent than the blood and sand.  * LADERA ($18): Amaaazing cab, but ouch it was expensive.

AForltW4oRNWxQPlN6AB_Q.review_text: My husband and I had a great "dining experience" last night at Park Tavern.  From the moment we sat down at the Bar and were warmly welcomed like old friends by Jack, Jeff and Brian throughout our entire meal served by Aura.  The deviled eggs were yummy, the pork chop was one of the best we have ever had and the brussels sprouts chips were to die for!!  We cannot wait to return in the near future.

lulGDc54S5xpZCM2gW0Nrg.review_text: My family and I visited Park Tavern after my fiancee graduated from a master's program. The decor is new and nice, with darker accents and a modern tavern feel, but I would say a bit soul-less. Our service wasn't great - our waitress was friendly but was  mia for most of the meal. Granted it's not a big deal, but the people at the table behind us had left, and the table wasn't cleared of a big pile of dirty plates for at least 20 minutes.   Unfortunately the food was also nothing to rave about. Two people ordered the pork chop, which was a huge piece of meat on top of veggies that basically amounted to pure mush. Another individual's fish stew was too salty to eat, and the cornish game hen, for all the hype, was unfortunately nothing special. Maybe we ordered the wrong thing? The appetizers - Jerusalem artichokes and salted fish on toast - were delicious, though.  Overall the experience was disappointing for the price class; I would recommend this restaurant for a drink and appetizers.

6jR5cK5retT748-qPMJBfg.review_text: I'm giving this place a 3.5 stars because this was likely the MOST expensive brunch I have ever had.  Dont go with the pitchers, thats where they get you!  Parking was a hassle so we valeted, but it was great with a view of Washington Square Park.  We started with orders of the toast with dungeness crab, and avocado toast. Both delicious.  We also ordered the ginger scones-- if you like ginger you'll love it--warm and moist.    I ordered the eggs with crispy polenta-so delicious!  The hubby had the Marlowe burger, which he loved as well.  Great place if someone else is buying :)

iSneApANkqRtZ_OGOYT1lQ.review_text: The service staff was pretty decent. The food was terrible. Some of it was removed from the check, which goes back to the service being decent. The PT fries were so salty they were inedible. I could taste the salt on my lips for over an hour afterward. The soup, by contrast, had almost no flavor at all. It obviously wasn't tasted after production. I was disappointed, to say the least.

KI7gPbRvdngGcgq3-RD7Gw.review_text: Food is Ok, but not amazing especially given the premium prices -- given the many AMAZING brunch places in SF, I would not put Park Tavern as a top.  I had every intention to show off SF brunch to our visiting family and took them here -- but I think all they will remember were the high prices..  We ordered: --Banana Coconut Fritters ($8) -- similar to donut holes but fried as fritters.  There are real coconut shreds inside the banana flavored batter.  Comes with a strawberry and chocolate dipping sauce.  A fun and tasty treat --Smoked Salmon Benedict ($17) -- Single faced benedict.  Lots of smoked salmon, but nothing particularly good about it.  I found the portion to be very small. --Cast Iron Farm Eggs ($15) -- really underwhelming.  Cast iron did not do much to the eggs flavor.  Just basically a tiny pan of spinach, cheese, and eggs.  My fiancé was not happy with his order and had to snack again soon after the meal given the tiny portion... --Chicken Sandwich ($14) -- probably the best thing we ordered.  Pile of fried chicken between a Kaiser roll with apple cider slaw.  Came with a fried pickle too, which was a nice touch :).  Nice to have tried it, but probably won't come back if I'm planning brunch.

5qgJTus1l35A6bqW2fFk0w.review_text: Update for the bar area:  came in with three visiting girlfriends to sit at the bar and hang out.  The bartenders are friendly & had great recommendations on drinks/wine when asked for them.  They noticed when glasses were getting low and made sure that we were taken care of!  I also noticed that they had a good number of regular customers that came in and joined into conversions/created a really great "classier" bar vibe that I loved!  Definitely will be back to hang out for drinks before dinner/after work.

2L-JHyZTYYoGgeYEDH50Jw.review_text: Had dinner with a girlfriend here, and I think it was pretty below average for the price and high reviews posted here. It was on a weekend night, so they were really busy and service was not stellar. We waited about 45 minutes, but that was okay considering we did not have reservations. I had the pork chop and she had the steak. Both of entrees were just okay. My chop was a little too undercooked and didn't have much of seasoning or sauce. It was a little too charred too. We also had the brussels sprout chips, which was a tad too oily for me.  It was an unique appetizer, but I wouldn't order it again. We had another appetizer too, but I can't remember what it was.  So evidently, it wasn't too memorable. The best part of my dinner was the two glasses of wine, but I would of enjoyed the wine a little more if my entree came a little sooner.

m-Kwjn_Ss5x4pz6Vxihl7Q.review_text: Ah' finally a place that offers delicious food with excellent service and valet parking is cheap. Love that. I think the name is a bit misleading the word Tavern generally doesn't appeal to me. We went here with a larger group about 10 of us for my sister in laws graduation. I had brought her a huge boutique of tropical flowers and they were even sweet enough to store them in their refrigerator for us while we ate. I was surprised how much I loved everything on the menu there isn't anything that isn't done really nicely with a lot of care to detail. We'll be back!

zHZd6aXSAUVMZ1PSzhxwvQ.review_text: Very inventive Sunday brunch menu! Great Mimosa's! Plenty of seating at bar or in bar area with full menu, in cases you don't have reservations on a very crowded Saturday or Sunday morning. We had the Crispy Polenta Cakes with Wild Mushrooms, the Smoked Cod Cake, and the Avocado Toast. All were delicious! The "Toasts" are a great spin on the usual "bread & butter" toast. This restaurant is a fine addition to the Washington Square Area, and we will definitely be back.

u53p-ZZtQbdhT52NSz50hA.review_text: Oh, Park Tavern.  Now you're courting us with brunch? Time for a little review update, and one helpful hint...  In one word?  Heaven.  Polenta cakes with truffled mushrooms and poached eggs?  Devine.  I don't even like mushrooms, but these were to die for.  My husband had veal schnitzel and fried eggs.  Washed down with a bourbon smoothie (booze, espresso, banana....hello, best milkshake EVER?) Shared the cinnamon sugar challah toast.  And of course the little guy had scrambled eggs and pancakes....which brings me to my only critique of the amazingly ridiculous Park Tavern.  Park Tavern, I know you're sexy.  I get it.  See and be seen, and all.  So evenings at Park Tavern are for lovers, and hot singles looking for other hot singles (with good taste in restaurants), and classy couples trying to keep their cool quotients high.  I get it.  But weekends, circa 11 am?  Weekend brunch is for families.  I was a little embarassed bringing my two year old to a restaurant that has been coined SF's new hot spot, but then I looked around, and the preschool set pretty much ruled the restaurant.  Because brunch is for families.  So Park Tavern, can you do us families a favor?  All we need is a single selection just for kids.  I'm not talking junky paper kid's menus with a cup of crayons.  I get it.  You're sexy and all.  I'm just saying a discreetly placed note on the side of the grown-up menu, maybe a "Little Combo" (one pancake, some scrambled eggs, a piece of cinnamon sugar toast....I mean, since you asked).  Because really, your food is rich and delicious and spectacular, but a little too out of this world for the 5 little girls that came for a "ladies lunch" with their moms one table over.  Brunch is for families.  Just sayin'

g9gSiGAdzCi6ceEXZ1VG6Q.review_text: We came to Park Tavern upon the recommendation of San Francisco's most famous hotelier. He warned us that it was loud inside, and it certainly was. But the food and service were the epitome of what any restaurant serving innovative American cuisine should strive for. We went for the amazing broccoli chips, the deviled eggs and truffle fries to start. All were great. The grilled pork chop was fantastic. Next time we're in town, I'll be back. This place is a winner. You won't go wrong here.

Omt3R9h3hj5JB9wt3_WXFg.review_text: Well to be honest this was our plan B for brunch but because the line outside of Mamas was so long.... Let me tell you this will not ever be a plan B again. I have a side of two eggs and the avocado toast... It was the perfect amount of food and cooked to perfection. They have a spice they put on top of the toast that makes it amazing. I will definitely be coming back!!!

-53qy8hpIJRRvsEg6DVVzg.review_text: Atmosphere - 4, with no AC, patio doors open, I thought the restaurant was uncomfortably warm.  However, decor, lighting, and music were spot on for a nice dinner in North Beach.  Service - 4, excellent service, we had a very attentive, and accommodating server.  More personable would have been better.  Entree - 4, all the food was on the salty side, which took a little away from the food. However, high quality ingredients, decent menu selection.  Unfortunately, they were out of duck.  Mussels were cooked perfectly and large portion, but the tomato broth was disappointingly bland.  Pork chops and salmon looked good.  Dessert - 4, apple crisp was delicious and generous portion with Fuji apples and ice cream.  Tcho chocolate Creme brûlée was bad.  Creme brûlée was never meant to have chocolate.  It was more like a mousse.  Don't call it something it's not.  Appetizers - 2, burnt Brussels sprout leaves as an appetizer, interesting concept.  Sliced lemon chips, interesting.  They get too fancy for their own good.  However, I will give them a 2 because the venison carpaccio was excellent.  Smooth, fresh, and tasty.  Location - 4, nice location at Washington Park in North Beach.  Price - 3, entrees were fair priced.  Appetizers were either overpriced or overrated.  Desserts were fair priced.  Overall, I would give it a 3.5.  Would I go again?  Only for the location since it is a block away from a relative.  Otherwise there are plenty of better restaurants in the area.

dxItbi3kz6KF8pj1TPo3lA.review_text: Park Tavern is my favorite weeknight restaurant in the city. The place is always busy, in a good way, but I've never actually made a reservation, and only sat down at a table a couple times (all outside). More than a dozen times I've walked in with a couple friends and found space at the huge communal table, or at the bar. The drinks are great, this gin drink called the Maclaren is my go to, and the food has never disappointed. It can be incredibly rich so I've learned to order a bit less than I'm tempted to get. The bday cake is a fun touch and the staff is always great. The bar and hostess staff in particular is good. The waiters/waitresses that service the communal table seem to rotate a lot. Despite going often I rarely recognize them. Park Tavern gets me to North Beach than anything else there.

EXKkKWAxWQAEmAWo-nL3Yg.review_text: We were not wowed, nothing stunningly bad (apart from late arriving alcohol) and nothing remarkably good.  In a food city like San Francisco it's easy to get bored with food and somehow the term New American makes me yawn in a similar way as the term Hipster does. Unless the former is exceptional of course.  This was, in my opinion nothing exceptional and the wine came out after the food not only once but twice...  Why not excite and surprise people with food and ambience, using creativity to find the right amount of both which will have guest curious for more rather then repeating and giving them what has becoming far to common, old and familiar.  Go if your expectations are an okay meal in comfortable surroundings.

ipiaTzhpPD5DaDrBa79CWg.review_text: Delicious food, great service!  I've been here four times now - twice with reservations and twice without.  The times I've come without reservations, the wait was long (over an hour each time), but the complimentary drinks they offered for our trouble and the delicious offerings made the wait worthwhile.  Try the deviled eggs - I do not like deviled eggs, but I LOVE these.  Brussel chips were light, crunchy, and perfectly salted.  The steak tartare special is ridiculously tasty, and the burger deserves a spot on the top-burgers-in-sf list for sure.  Will be coming back for a fifrh visit soon!

orOqqQP_FSI4-kUizewRQw.review_text: Came here Sunday around 1pm and ordered from their brunch menu.   Smoked trout on toast - 4/5. Was very pleasantly surprised with the smoked trout. Will definitely order this again.  Warm baguette with nut butter - 2/5. Basically just filler food. This is pretty identical to getting bread at a restaurant.  Crispy polenta cakes - 4/5. It was good, but portion was small. May consider ordering this again if I wanted something light.  Overall, I would come here again for brunch with friends. Food I tried wasn't particularly spectacular.

PnOtgdL8x7Mhy5VLaxO2tQ.review_text: I always have the good intention to "yelp" places but never really get around to it...Park Tavern is the first restaurant that has actually motivated me enough to take 5 minutes out of my day and write a review!  I LOVE this place!  Hippest, hottest restaurant in SF right now by far!  Not to mention the food and beverage selection is absolutely amazing- they stick to classics (with a twist) and are always adding new exciting dishes/drinks to the menu!  GREAT wine selection!  Priced well for fine dining in the city, too!  Service is excellent...not pretentious but still has a very VIP atmosphere- extremely accommodating!  Make a reservation if you don't want to wait (it's busy because they are doing something...or everything right)!   They recently opened a lounge area upstairs that I have been dying to pay a visit also!  My faves: Deviled eggs are literally the best I've ever had (bacon and truffle oil...duh?!)!  Brussell sprout chips are a must!  Fries with caviar, need I say more?  At brunch...POLENTA CAKES- to die!  On a nice weekend, the outside sidewalk seating is awesome.  If you are local or visiting, it is a must try!!

sP2FizCaN4qgP7-G9HQbSg.review_text: Went here one night with a group of girlfriends for after work drinks and snacks. I was way intimidated by the crowd when we first arrived but after huddling by the bar for a few minutes we were able to grab a spot. Customers and staff alike were so good-natured that the hubbub seemed more festive than chaotic. Phew!  We ordered the fried tomatoes, fried pork belly, deviled eggs, brussels chips, a salad and... ? It became a hazy, salty, greasy swirl as the wine flowed. We let their wine guy pick a couple bottles for us and we couldn't have been happier. Why don't I EVER write these recommendations down??  Can't wait to try their dinner and see how the menu develops  - I'm hoping my first impression holds up and it becomes a place I can take anyone. Down home food done upscale, woohoo!

I1_5n3j2veqOh9ILBDCcTA.review_text: Park Tavern is essentially Marlowe on steroids.  Compared to the much smaller Marlow, Park Tavern is an expansive restaurant with a fully vibrant bar scene.  I went on opening night and had a great experience.  Standouts include the Halibut, Steak Crudo and Deviled Eggs from the small bites section.  I would skip the Buratta because the lemon chips that come with them are over-seasoned and too overpowering.  The scallop entree was seared perfectly and delicious.  Drinks are great too, they have a great beer and wine selection.  Definitely a solid restaurant that warrants repeat visits.

rtTpEZSTIDSurdw12xZK1Q.review_text: Amazing food, and service... Seated promptly ... Food was very yummy..I tried my friends baked eggs.. You can probably skip that but every other dish was amazing and presentation was good too! They don't sell mimosas by the carafe but u can just get a bottle of proseco m a carafe of orang juice n it was plenty for the 6 of us!

H34S954LT8OZVLJVJB6bpg.review_text: Absolutely love this place. If I lived in the Bay, I would definitely frequent it.   Unfortunately my friends and I were only here for brunch, which of course, did not disappoint. Embracing my new obsession with polenta, I had to get the Crispy Polenta Cakes which was elegant and delicious. The eggs were poached perfectly and the wild mushrooms complimented the cakes very nicely. My friend ordered the Open-Faced Deviled Eggs Sandwich, which was definitely the most hearty of dishes but she enjoyed it.  Our waiter was extremely helpful and warm and provided excellent service. Love the open kitchen as well! Definitely a must try if you're in the area!

CFtCdyGi319TOBaSG8x4qg.review_text: Ordered some App's and cocktails while waiting for a table at Tony's...soft shell crab was decently fried but the shrimp app sort of in a Louie sauce was overcooked.  The bar was packed and it looked like the old Perry's on Union crowd...I'm dating myself but you know what I'm talking about....this place has fallen off a lot since Cavalier opened!

eIa4QJXp5ZNmuFORnuPvDA.review_text: Food was good - some dishes great. While I did enjoy my meal and the space is really nice, this didn't quite live up to all the hype.  Also: the prices were fairly steep. And the restaurant is LOUD. If you go with a group of 8 like I did, you could really only hear the people sitting immediately next to you. Not really an atmosphere for group conversation.   Not good for vegetarians. My friend couldn't see much on the menu for herself, and had several back & forths with the server about getting something especially made from the kitchen.  MUST-HAVE: oyster caesar.  * Local halibut, avocado, onion, tomato $11: 3 stars Not bad, but just didn't stand out in any way. The dish is exactly as described, nothing more.  * Brussels Sprout Chips $6: 2 stars Had this at Marlowe, where I thought the lemon flavor was overpowering. Gave it another shot here, but still felt there could be a greater sea salt to lemon ratio. The chips are just too small and really could use more crisp. I am being picky.. brussels sprouts are my thing.  * Chicken fried green tomato, remoulade $7: 3 stars Nicely done, thin but crisp breading. Not bad, not fantastic either.  * Pork belly bites, horseradish aioli $6: 2 stars Pork belly should be much more fatty & tender! I found the meat quite hard.  * Deviled eggs, Nueske's baken & chives $1.5 each: 1 star I found this to be really plain in flavor. The yolk filling was just too egg-y if that makes any sense - I could barely taste the bacon & chives, which should've balanced out its flavor mroe.  * Fried oysters "Caesar" $12: 5 stars Amazing! The oysters were absolutely delicious. When you took a bite and the soup-y insides poured into your mouth, it was savory and had an amazing rich flavor. The lettuce leaves with caesar dressing balanced out what would've been an overly intense rich flavor in the fried breading and the oyster.   * Yellow doll watermelon & Mangalitsa prosciutto, truffle & mustard greens $12: 4.5 stars Surprisingly wonderful! Loved the interplay of flavors, temperatures, and textures. Who would've thought that juicy/sweet watermelon would go so well with salty/dry prosciutto? Each time I chewed, my taste buds burst with more new flavor combinations.  * Lamb chops & merguez sausage, broccoli rabe with garlic & chili $28: 4 stars I didn't get to try this but a couple friends got the dish and it looked wonderful. The lamb was cooked rare to medium-rare and looked incredibly rich & tender.  * Herb marinated whole cornish game hen, Bloomsdale spinach, carrots & baby turnips $22: 4 stars Really delicious, juicy, tender, and well seasoned meat. A nice dish to get for the "ooh's" and "aah's" - the whole hen is served standing up!  * Risotto: 4 stars My friend got this special ordered as she's vegetarian. I had a bite & it was creamy and had amazing texture. It had a tart sauce on top, which gave it a little too much of a sour flavor. Otherwise really good.  * Apple & fig dessert with ice cream: 4 stars Loved it. Warm, soft slices of apple & fig under a wonderfully crunchy yet subtle crust. The ice cream was a great contrast - we forgot what the menu said the flavor was, but we all agreed it had hints of lemon. It was light with a very smooth texture.

_jooCMbtNISAbAQ7oZAfug.review_text: Ok... super salty food!  Deviled Eggs were good, but my burger and fries were way too salty... and this comes from a person who likes salt.  Others at the table seemed to like the mussels.  Lobster & Corn Chowder Soup was good.

VeDcipSOeGKtdR7SZh9gcg.review_text: Went for a business dinner and loved it. The brussel sprout chips are addicting and their dinner options live up to expectations.  A little pricey but worth it.  Will come back.

Xd_2uetx9LxA2hQassydJA.review_text: I'd been here a couple of times when it first opened, and the food was ok, but not as solid or consistent from dish to dish. Glad to see this time around that they have graduated to being a great restaurant.  Amazing fries, demons on horseback, flounder for main course. Really amazing. The dessert made of chocolate and coconut that we had tasted like a bounty bar, so it was indifferent -- they gave us some small desserts on the house that were not on the menu and were much much better.  Only downside, the side chanterelles with sunchokes. It was not good. It was hard to believe that they came out of the same kitchen. Why do this to chanterelles, they are such a great ingredient?!  Oh, and I like the ambience: on the nice side, but modern, stylish and laid-back, not stuffy -- good for both the younger and older crowd.  Park tavern has become a truly wonderful restaurant, and correcting perhaps a few small things on the menu (see above) would make it one of SF's very finest, I think.

nF-UM092NAxzdGqERXGZLw.review_text: Went there for brunch. The food and drinks were good, but a little pricey compared to some similar places. We ordered the baked eggs over spinach and the chorizo and eggs and then had the chocolate crime brûlée for dessert. No complaints other than it was hard to get the attention of the servers, but they were setting up for a private event hat afternoon, so I think that was an anomaly.

FocjwNt9GbOSln9iFCFwtQ.review_text: Ridiculous how good Park Tavern is. First time? You must try the pork chop, burger and deviled eggs. Tasty cocktails. Gorgeous space. There's a full bar and they offer communal tables if you dig that style.  Make a reservation or come as soon as they open. This place is H-O-T.

qZKiJCW-iD27LD-nq1xd7A.review_text: I've been here many times before and I like that it's a neighborhood place. If you come in early enough, you can order cocktails and meals in the communal table by the bar, I've also been able to get seated reservations but had to do it a couple of weeks in advance.  I crave for the following: crispy brussels sprout chips (I can eat an entire order myself), smoked deviled eggs and the truffle fries! It's time to go back.

O2p5cv6oN-nV8mJ_7DiUkw.review_text: I came here with my family and it was a pretty good experience. The food is very tasty, not trying to be too fancy, but taking fresh ingredients and making them taste good. Sounds easier than it is. I really like the high high high ceilings, it makes the environment not so claustrophobic when you come on a weekend, and it gets very crowded and warm inside. I made my own entree so to speak by ordering everything a la carte, so I had shrimp covered in bacon, deviled eggs, brussel spouts, and mushroom pate. I would have to say the mushroom pate was the only thing I didn't care for. Not especially tasty. But everything else was to die for. Everyone around had dishes that looked delicious too. As far as the service, I did think our waiter was had a bit of a snooty attitude, but I guess that is what you would expect in a place like this. (He's not there to make friends)  I did like how he explained how everything was cooked to give you an idea of how the texture of your fish would turn out, for example. I like that since it shows he knows the menu and has tasted everything.   I would come back again, maybe on a weeknight when it's not so crowded.

-B-QEUESGWHPE_889WJaeg.review_text: I want to like you more than I do so more visits are in order for your good food, mediocre service and beautiful people watching.   Fried Sunchokes $9 Venison Carpaccio, fantastic at $15 The Braised Lamb Tongue with cracked egg was good at $14 and surprised my friends with it's delicate taste. Great to try new things. $9 Brussels Sprout Chips have serious potential but WAY too salty. I'll make these at home and experiment.  My biggest disappointment, or more pet peeve was the Smoked Deviled Egg for $2 each. What you get is 1/2 an egg for for the price. Good but not after learning the verbiage double charges me. Bummer dude. The Scallops @ $29 melted in my mouth and were cooked perfectly. Loved the pea tendrils. Great flavor pairing.  Our server was good spirited but busy. At times he popped off without letting us finish our sentence. The food did come out quickly and as ordered but something rubbed me wrong. In the end, I will be back but I'm not rushing to make my OpenTable just yet.

fgH2vvy9tG1mm39-fsUwhA.review_text: Really really good service and I love the unique menu options! We came for brunch and had the kiwi/orange/berry fruit plate, cast iron baked spinach and poached egg, blueberry French toast and a Bloody Mary. Everything was very good, I especially enjoyed the Bloody Mary and the fruit plate--it came with a shot glass of juice that we poured over the fruit and it was so good. The French toast was very very sweet and the cast iron bake was good, but pretty simple and had a lot of spinach. I look forward to going back and trying their twist on toast as well as other options on the menu.

Q0C_ZLsqpItBBtauq_EDWg.review_text: We were staying next door to this restaurant and it was recommended by one of the people staying there.  We tried a walk-in the first night, but found out the reservations fill up a couple of nights in advance  This is the first place I would label as "Hipster Trendy" on Yelp. Super packed, loud ambiance,  The tables are very close together, and things are even closer at the communal bar table.  We heard some very interesting conversations our neighbors were having that night.  We started with the PT fries, which were served with a spicy remoulade sauce, and a soft boiled egg with a little caviar. The fries were double dropped, so they were very crispy.  They were a little expensive at $20, so I probably would try something different next time.  I had the Poulet Rouge. It was a very juicy small chicken, server upright on a cast iron dish, with spinach and baby potatoes server in the bottom.  My wife had the scallops, which were cooked perfectly.  For dessert I had the "Birthday Cake" which was a chocolate pecan cake.  It was actually very good.  My wife had the TCHO creme brulee, which was also very good.  It was my wife's birthday, but all they did was put a candle in her dessert (actually mine by mistake).  The food was very good.  The service, not by fault of the servers, was a little thin.  Our empty wine glasses sat on the table after we finished the wine at dinner, and  I had to ask for water refills.  If the food hadn't been good, and the waiter's attitude good, I may have given a rating of a three because of this.  At least for me, service is very important, especially at a nicer restaurant such as this.  We'll go back next time we are in San Francisco.

hlxH2uBmB217ftMMWaLroQ.review_text: I've been three times in a short period of time - it hasn't disappointed. I love this place for a few reasons:  1. The drinks are delish and the bartenders are top-notch. They are attentive, even with a bar packed with people. Wine selections are great and I like that they offer carafes for certain wines.  2. The way the menu is laid out. It makes it super easy to find something for exactly what you're craving.  3. The ambiance is great and it's excellent people watching. The overall crowd is skewed older (40+), but you get a nice smattering of young professionals as well.   4. The food is so good and perfect for sharing.   I've been twice with just one other person, and deviled eggs, brussel sprout chips, burratta and one entree were more than enough. With three people, we did the same, but added a side and we each had more than enough to eat.   My picks: deviled eggs (cut it in half though, since the flavor is so powerful that you'll need two bites to savor the full flavor. Stuffing the whole thing in your mouth is just tragic.), burratta with fried lemon and basil - yum!, polenta side, the steak and the burger!   I'd skip: the brussell sprout chips don't do it for me. Not because they're not yummy, but because they have a funky aftertaste to me. The scallops entree - they were fishy.    Pro tip - make a reservation on OpenTable. If you don't get the time you want when you make it, check back a few hours before. They usually have openings at the most desirable times.

fitXjNnwVB_HzqaBSrIGXQ.review_text: Park Tavern is a rare balance of sophistication, liveliness, and tastiness. The place is well designed and feels welcoming.  The bar is well staffed and a great place to get a meal if you don't want to wait for a table. The drink menu is quite extensive and they can make great cocktails.  In terms of small bites, I'd recommend the brussel sprout chips. They are basically leaves of brussel sprouts roasted with some salt and maybe oil. Very tasty.  The mushroom/khale soup with poached egg has a complex flavor that is quite good.  The kampachi dish is well presented (on a stone slate) but is otherwise unremarkable.  Service is attentive and stellar.

epEHgtHM6lFk4tnVKOVDaQ.review_text: Park Tavern may seem like some to the the pinnacle of good eating, but to me, a native Manhattanite, it seemed typical of a good restaurant.  I was happy to eat here and was happy to sit at the bar and speak with the barkeep, who was experienced, knowledgeable, and friendly.  I'm envisioning you, dear reader, as one of several possible archetypes:  1. The guy looking for the top-rated place to take his girlfriend, irregardless of cuisine or neighborhood  2. The tourist (like I was) looking for a place to eat that is good and not filled with non San Franciscans.   3. The Yelper  If you're a number 1, you better make sure the girl is a number 1 equivalent because otherwise she'll be bored with the place, thinking you have no imagination although the food is good.  If you're number 2, there's two subsets: you're a tourist but not an idiot:  if that's you, end up here only if your restaurant of choice is closed (like mine was).  iif you're an idiot tourist: how did you find Yelp? I didn't know you could read! Yes, come here, you can tell all your friends how fancy you are.  Finally, if you're a number 3, if you're around Park Tavern and have exhausted other more creative and whimsical options, head here--the food and drink are good and the service is good, but you'll feel as if you've been here before.

4GBCiPjdfpj46O_zQRr8sQ.review_text: Great food,great drinks,great service.A little pricey but I don't mind when everything is good.I'll go back.A bit of a New York feel which is a nice change after 100's of times eating in the area.

41z61QvAhfIhHSBigLZ_jQ.review_text: Love the location, love the ambiance. Roomy restaurant. Solid in every way.  Deviled Eggs interesting and and worth a try. Everything else very good - professionally presented - yet all for me unspectacular.   That isn't to say you shouldn't try - it's very good and worth a visit.

UyhnjAlyMXtbR-qB5kkhlQ.review_text: Brunch at Park Tavern was easily the best brunch I've had in a while! Before the meal was over, I was already planning my next visit. I came back the next weekend and then for dinner a few days later. I am rarely this enthusiastic about restaurants.   I rate Park Tavern 4.5 stars, but I'll round up and give it a 5 since I had out 4s pretty often.  The toasts were delicious and visually appealing:  * Sourdough toast with Dungeness crab + green goddess - $9 * Seeded whole wheat toast with avocado, chili flake, lemon + sea salt - $7  * Buttermilk pancakes - $10 for 3 So so so fluffy!  * Cast iron-baked raspberry + blueberry Dutch baby - $12 Sweet and tasty but small and gone too soon.   * Butter lettuce + Maine lobster, cucumber, shaved market vegetables, + dill vinaigrette - $17 Generous portion. The salad contrasted well with the other heavy carby foods I ordered, but I got a bit tired of the salad at the end. I recommend sharing this with at least one other person rather than tackling it alone.  * Veal schnitzle with poached eggs, marinated Spanish anchovies, frisee with lardons - $18 Nicely plated. The meat was tender and well-seasoned.   * Deviled eggs with bacon, pickled jalapeno + chives - $2 per half Super creamy and yummy!!   * Grilled pork chop with sauteed baby turnips, caramelized apple, Neuske's bacon + mustard jus - $24 The pork chop was a bit fattier than I expected, but it was cooked nicely.   A few things I was not that impressed with:  * French toast with caramelized bananas and vanilla syrup - $12 Given how good all the other brunch items were, I was surprised that the French toast was actually bad. The toast was not soaked through in batter, and half of it was extremely dry.   * Bloody Mary, Bloody Maria (tomatillo, cilantro, jalapenos, Anaheim chiles), Bloody Mariko (wasabi, miso, dashi) - $10 each The Bloody Mary variations were interesting but not memorable. The Bloodys are served with too much ice and get watered down quickly. (Ever since experiencing the $5 Bloody Marys at Thieves Tavern, I've had trouble appreciating Bloodys elsewhere.)  * PT fries with shaved black truffle + parmesan, truffle aioli, soft boiled egg + Osetra caviar - $20 We all balked at the price but had to satisfy our curiosity. I don't think the PT fries were much better than regular truffle fries. I could barely detect the shaved black truffle. I enjoyed the fries dipped in soft boiled egg yolk, but I didn't think the caviar added much to the combination as it was also barely detectable.  Other bonuses: * Beautiful space * Relatively easy to get reservations for small parties the next day or same day * Trendy, Pinterest-worthy touches like cocktails served in jam jars and toast served on slate * Outdoor or window tables with a view of Washington Square Park * Sightglass coffee served as well. I'm not a coffee drinker, but I know this meant a lot to my highly caffeinated friends.

LRwv7vwEH6NWNSFLvHDPpQ.review_text: Seating is a bit cramped inside but the environment is clean and friendly. Service was good and attentive. The menu is pretty limited to just a handful of choices. I had the burger which was tasty. I can't say I would go back as the selection is too narrow and prices are a bit high for what you get. It's a popular brunch spot and if poached eggs are your thing this would do well.

Xj0O2l0bp633ebmG468aZw.review_text: A really fun place - love the decor (cozy, dark, rustic, modern at once) - hip young crowd - amazing deviled eggs. We sat at the common table and our waiter was lame. Took us asking three times and 30 minutes to get my stepdad a glass of chard, and the others of us all had our wine. Other than the waiter, this was a winner.

wWFAnno7Z3Qt4xRX3-J0wA.review_text: I'm not sure what has taken me so long to write a review for Park Tavern, but I can easily say that it is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco along with Gamine which is located in Cow Hollow. I love both of them for very different reasons.   I've been here for both brunch and dinner several times (both amazing), so bear with me while I walk through the menu.  Beer and cocktails- My boyfriend and I love craft beer, and if you have read any of my other reviews, you'd know that I love Sudwerk out of Davis, CA. The Sudwerk Pilsner is on draft and is also featured in the Michelada at Brunch. Holy Moly does the Michelada leave a fiery sensation in your mouth, but the combination of the pickled jalepeno and the beer make it an amazing combination. The other three cocktails i've had are the Kentucky Mule, Dirty Martini, and the Country Lawyer. All I can say, is that the bartenders are fantastic and poor some amazing drinks.  BRUNCH: Boyfriend and I usually like to order several things when we go out to eat, so I'll give a tidbit of our favorites.  I'm not an egg person, so I'll give his opinion second hand.  Avocado Toast: SO good. I've tried to recreate this at home several times. The combo of the avocado, chili, and lemon is nothing short of amazing.  Grapefruit Brulee: Carmelizing the grapefruit definitely cuts the tartness of the fruit, and the sugary goodness just melts in your mouth.  Pan Fried Corn Beef Hash: BF loved the poached egg, and I mean, you really cant go wrong with corn beef hash.   Banana Coconut Fritters: delicious, but they are a bit on the heavier side, so be aware of that when ordering a lot of food.  DINNNER: If you only get to make it here once, here is what I'd recommend trying.  Brussel Sprout chips: These are flash friend brussel sprout leaves? that are tossed in lemon and salt. I'm almost positive that every time I've been to Park Tavern, we've had to order more of these chips. They have them at Marlowe (their sister restaurant) as well. SO good.  The "Bar" Steak: It's the perfect amount of steak and salad without feeling like I overate and leaving me with enough room for dessert. (I opt for the salad over fries because I like to pretend that I am healthy.)   "Poulet Noir"- This is hands down the best item in my opinion on the menu. For a first timer, order the baby hen intact. It comes sitting up and literally falls off the bone and has an amazing truffle taste. DISCLAIMER:it IS a little annoying dismantling the chicken, but we later learned to order it already chopped up. It just looks so pretty when it is still intact.   I've never had the lamb or porkchop, but i've heard they are both amazing as well.   Long story short, food and drinks are awesome, atmosphere is great, servers were great---Park Tavern= great.

dKZbQAbOo7QBAZtgwxr4QQ.review_text: We had a birthday brunch reservation at 11:15am on Sunday.  When I arrived at 10:55am I was told "to find something to do."  When I returned at 11:10am, the hostess would not acknowledge me yet, she bent over backwards to accommodate 3 hipster men who came in, without reservations, and to set up the chef's table for them and seat them immediately.  She would not even look at me.  After we were seated, we had a good meal, the baked eggs were yummy and the shared avocado toast was delish!  If not for the hostess, I would have given 4 stars.

yidh1hp0uEubQMloQqrAhA.review_text: This has become one of our favorite SF restaurants.  The lemon chips are amazing.  They are so light and tasty, it is a good thing they are portioned.  Like Lays....you can't eat just one!  I had read about the deviled eggs and couldn't wait to see what all the fuss was about.  They are simply the best deviled eggs ever, very savory!  Since they are sold individually, you should try one, I promise you won't be disappointed.  Next we had Demons on Horseback, which are prawns wrapped in lard...a taste explosion in your mouth.  This last trip we shared the Marlowe burger which was extraordinary.  Can you tell we love this restaurant?  The drinks are also made with fresh juices and quite tasty.  And saving the best for last...the service is top notch.  Very friendly, knowledgeable about the menu and attentive.  This restaurant deserves 10 stars!!

KLPrlrcRaqbFWe4cFQNnMQ.review_text: Came here with a group of friends and had such a good time we ended up staying until way past my weeknight bedtime. We shared a variety of appetizers (brussel sprout chips and deviled eggs were amazing) with our cocktails (both Washington Square and the McKinley were perfect - not too sweet but fresh and different).   I had a pork belly and oyster special for dinner and tasted bites of a nice roasted chicken dish and indulgent steak. The waitstaff suggested some great wine (can't recall the name) to go with our mains. Don't miss the polenta side -- totally worth it even if there isn't really any more room in your stomach.  The restaurant space was gorgeous - warm, inviting and refined but still approachable. A good restaurant when you want to feel a little special but not too stuffy.

LOi1qbpl2hTP0cwSDDuyBQ.review_text: Must order - the poulet noir.  A small hen.  The hen is perched upright and served whole.  Comes on a cast iron plate.  It was the highlight of our dinner for five.  We ordered our own entrees and had the poulet family style.
