tQpcEk8JzVw2hpKQ_Mzh3A.review_text: atmosphere is awesome, the vibes of the place reminds me of NY.  They have great appetizers and fairly good cocktails.  we had brussels spout chip, devil eggs, and many other dishes.  How can u say no to a place that has beef jerky on the side.  Overall experience was very delightful.

Xh8i99BuDKldiP3MxaIaSQ.review_text: Absolutely sensational. Chicken worth the wait. Also the pork chop is a good choice

9IF2ZMnkrZlvxCHcO0h1EQ.review_text: The brussels sprouts chips are a must try, if you can get into this busy, popular spot. It was hard to get seated even with a reservation on a weekday night.  Good food, but really loud. Not a good place to go unless you know sign language to carry on a dinner conversation.

8FfjI-7L7lXYYL19mwV9IQ.review_text: Had a wonderful meal here with friends. Service was first-rate, and the food was mmm mmm tasty. It'd been awhile since I was really faced with too many choices of things I wanted to try at a restaurant. Seems like they have a great balance of classic dishes that stay on the menu awhile, and some great seasonal additions.   The smoked burrata and steak tartare dishes were nothing short of amazing, although be prepared for some kick-ass zestiness on the tartare (which I loved). The NY Strip (my favorite cut of steak) was also perfectly seasoned and delish. I opted for the twice-baked potatoes over the fries and couldn't get enough of them--carbtastically amazing.  Can't wait to go back!

HFECrzYDpgbS5EmTBtj2zQ.review_text: Good Times and Brussels Chips!  And so it was as Rene C., his wife Erica, Joanna M. and her friend MM gathered at Park Tavern after a Gogobot Party at Rosewood. It was a fine second choice as Tony's Pizza had a long wait on this Wednesday evening.   When we first walked in, the place was full and bustling with "beautiful people", including maybe even Mr. Joesten the 3rd. :)  Sometimes this much "buzz" means that both the clientele and restaurant are full of themselves, but in this case the Maitre D' was super accommodating in finding us an outside table. That sort of attentive and friendly service continued on with our waitress, the wine steward, and other support staff. We felt well taken care of during the entire evening, even though our total bill probably didn't come close to a few bar tabs still running inside.   Sitting outside also makes for better conversation and we had some good ones. The center of the conversation was MM's fascinating explanation of his new Marker App and tales of travel that have both experienced and wished that I could. The Yelp and Gogobot comparisons came up, as did OCD-fueled writing, and what how virtual social interaction is evolving. And all this engaging interaction timelessly continued while life on this side of Washington Square went walking or whizzing by on this comfortable evening. I knew I eventually had to get in the car and drive back to Pleasant Hill, but I was in no hurry for the evening to end.  But that did mean that I limited my alcohol intake to a glass of wine. That delicious red came from a shared and well priced bottle of Cabernet Franc. I passed on the great looking Templeton Rye (from Iowa!) Side Cars and was intrigued as talk then centered around similar specialty whiskeys such as Whistlepig.  The food was great too. Everyone else at the Table went for the Burger, which unfortunately I passed on as I had already filled up before and during the party. My Bad. However, I was just fine as I happily munched on the Brussels Sprout Chips and Brussels Sprout Hearts (sauteed with lemon and cheese).   So there you go. When you put together a nice venue, great conversation, and good food, it's an experience that bears repeating.

yOS1OJjmi5QvFzo_KbJuZA.review_text: Park Tavern is great. I went here with a group of 6 for a business dinner the other night and we had a great time. The food is fantastic, the service was on point and we all thoroughly enjoyed ourselves. We started with the deviled eggs, the brussel sprout chips, the burrata and pepper tart and the sunchokes. All were very good. I had the pork chop as my entree. It was very good as well. My only minor complaint there is that it was a little fatty. I would have liked a slightly leaner piece of meat. It was cooked very well though. We order one of each of the sides (twice cooked potato, brussel sprouts, spinach, broccolini and french fries). I could not stop eating the french fries. They were SO good. Extra crispy but still moist on the inside. Delicious! For dessert we had the smore and the birthday cake. The birthday cake was cute because they brought it out with a candle in it. The smore was good, but not the best I've ever had. This was a business dinner, so I didn't have to pay for it personally, but I can imagine it would get pricey for a date night. I think it's definitely worth the splurge every once in a while though. I would definitely come back.

JrIAxR7WU1G7ABPIUPC9XA.review_text: My first impression of this place: why the heck is it so freaking cold in here? It's a tavern, isn't it? Isn't a tavern the traditional place you go to shelter from the cold? I mean yikes, I never took off my jacket or scarf. I know restaurants make it colder because that makes you want to eat more, but I just felt sort of chilled the whole time I was there.   I really liked the way their menu was organized (smoked, fried, marinated, tomatoes, etc). And there were lots of choices, whatever your craving was. I especially loved the heirloom tomato and burratta dish, presented on a very cool piece of slate. I thought all the dishes were presented so beautifully, and came out at a great pace. Our server was lovely, and it seemed all the people around us were lovely, too (tables are kind of close together, it got hard not to eavesdrop). Everything was delicious, and I encourage anyone to try their chocolate creme brulee with chili and lime. Very unique, with great flavors.   Still, I'm not sure I was down with the atmosphere. In addition to being chilly in the front table section, the place was very loud and around 8pm, they dimmed the lights. This might have created a nicer vibe if we hadn't been ordering, as the print on their menu was seriously as small as they could possibly make it and the space was already kind of dark before the mandated dimming. Also, it seems like they went to a lot of trouble to fit their massive wine list on one page of paper, which made it extremely difficult to read (even for the folks at the table with perfect vision).  The location is prime, and it was nice to take a walk around the neighborhood after our meal, so I think I would rather come back here during the day. Maybe it wouldn't be so damn cold inside then, and I would be able to read the menu without the squinting.

hvs6lMxRLGcp2rc08QAAMg.review_text: Had a spontaneous dinner here on a Thurs night and was pleased with the pick.  We actually didnt have reservations but got seated outside (per request since my friend had her pup with her) within 45 minutes.   Service: Friendly and on point. Apps: Deviled eggs and brussell sprout chips were perfectly prepared. Entree: Marlowe burger and fries were AMAZING Crowd: On the hoity-toity side, but interesting none-the-less  I'll def be back soon, and want to check out the brunch on my next visit.

YLy6HF5gqPjDgoT9VO5ZeQ.review_text: I love the fact that there are finally some non-Italian, nice restaurant options in North Beach (I love my Italian food, I just can't eat it all the time, you know?).   The service was good, the food was great, definitely try the dessert called "birthday cake", I can only describe it as like eating a cloud :).   I give it 4 stars because everything between the appetizer, both our meals and the dessert, was made with lemon as a core flavoring. It is a lemon-themed menu it seems. Would love to see more diversity in the flavors, otherwise, it is very very good.

qjBuaL6LapSDKpV7MIhrPQ.review_text: Order the avocado toast. ZOMG.   Docked 1 star cause the bloody mary was terrible. Maybe it's just me but that shiet is too peppery. However, I do suggest you grab a drink and sit at a table outside on a nice day.

Hr5rzkiljte0oHrPw5P6Ow.review_text: Hot spot, but it's overated, by far. But some good things to go along with the poor or average items. Great menu, not alway executed well. We were a four top, and spent $240 on wine, 3 apps, and main courses for four. Hard to talk across the table with the noise. LOTS of looking going on, attractive people. Waiter acted like he was sure we knew he was good, but couldn't get bread on the table, candle lit, silverware didn't make sense, all done by rote, timing was very off, and no thought applied. But the food... must try the brussel sprout chips, fabulous. The "Demons on Horseback" are heavily sold, but honestly, shrimp with a little fat and veges, didn't impress me. Deviled eggs are hard NOT to like, these were actually good. Two of us had the pork chop, a disaster of odd misses. Oversalted, HIGHLY oversalted,  long leaf spinach, mixed in with turnips that were rubbery, (honestly, couldn't cut them with the knife), and chunks of bacon, square cut, but TOUGH, along with a butterflied pork chop, (really, the only reason to do that is to hurry up the cooking). But the meat WAS tasty, mostly due to the high level of fat on the chop,  in a delicious reduction. Rubbery scallops, (same word 2x), but in a nice sauce on as skewer. The other entree was the tuna, not memorable. Chef friend of mine, also said he had a terrible meal, accented by really lacking service.  When restaurants get hot, they just get frantic, and forget how to keep up the ideas and effort that all DO work, and they go for the turnover, and hope to be successful being formulaic without good management. This is one of those spots. You have to go to see the buzz, but PLEASE, rate it right, forget the hype!

vTugBdYg34rX4KvGpzBrNA.review_text: Yes please. Brussels Sprout Chips? Um, amazing and demolished in a heartbeat. Lemon & basil leaf, burrata also totally amazing. Seared scallops, roasted cauliflower, braised baby fennel & grapefruit, best dish I've had in a long time.  The atmosphere is also adorable and we loved our little outdoor table on their front patio, which helped me feel like I was dining in Europe again. Their cocktails are delectable and their October Birthday cake was really yummy. We also very much enjoyed people watching, as there were lots of Sugar Daddy's with their super young girlfriends. Haha awesome.

6aJNIB8yGHDiwrzyxlExRw.review_text: We went here for weekend brunch.  Decor is very attractive.  Service was good, everyones food was good, nice tasting creative plates.  They serve mixed brunch type drinks by the pitcher, the iced tea vodka one tasted like a bad Snapple drink :(  Prices were average for the city.

Bn8w45_LSwItWqDTm4RHwg.review_text: We went here for our annual holiday dinner with another couple. We enjoyed the food and atmosphere. My only complaint would be our server. She rushed us through the meal, even though there were open tables. She asked for our order within 3 minutes of sitting down and before we have even ordered drinks. If they are trying to compete with Wayfare, they are going to have to get better staff.   All in all, I still recommend Park Tavern. We will return and look forward to trying the cocktails.

9UMoH_L6TsrNWAkvxLeDYQ.review_text: I can't believe I've waited so long to come here.  This place is not only an amazing place to come to for a delicious dinner, but you can also enjoy some pretty fantastic drinks in a warm and inviting atmosphere with friendly and attentive service.  Brought my husband here for a celebratory birthday dinner, and we couldn't help but try out some of the dishes that my fellow Yelpers raved about.  Everything you've read about the deviled eggs, brussels sprout chips, and demons on horseback are absolutely true and even better than you can imagine.  For our entrees, I had the halibut and hubby had the steak frites - so well cooked, tender, and so well flavored.  For dessert, they surprised hubby with a huge slice of "birthday cake" on the house! Classy, Park Tavern, really classy.

RrfcgvnjsH58eOtfTbEJEA.review_text: I made a reservation for Brunch four days prior. I wanted to choose a nice / fancy-ish place for my best friend's birthday and we have been eyeballing Park Tavern for a long time.   First off, this place has a really nice and warm ambiance about it. The circular light fixtures with yellow bulbs, large sofa seating, large open windows, and exposed wooden structure is only part of the reason why I fell in love with the interior of this restaurant. Secondly, the service is on point. They are filling my water to the brim constantly as I am drinking it and our waiter was super funny and patient with us. (C'mon, we are three kids at a fancy-ish restaurant, you can only imagine).  So here we being with our "fancy-ish" meal: 1. Jam Jelly Baguette - The baguette was extremely crunchy and chewy. The variety of jams included: cranberry, blueberry, orange and butter. The orange one was my favorite. It was the first time I've had an orange jam where it wasn't too sour nor sweet, it was right in between and it was delicious.  2. Dungeonous Crab Toast - They packed a thick layer of crab on top of a lightly toasted white bread. The white bread was light and thin and crunchy on the outside, I actually didn't like how the crab overpowered the bread.  3. Farm Eggs - Nice presentation. Baked with 10% eggs on top of 90% spinach. Fair taste, not too salty but couldn't taste the eggs.  4. Smoked Salmon Benedict - Packed with a strong tasting salmon. Tasted like capers to me. The egg wasn't as runny as I had hoped.   5. Cod Sandwich - Perfectly cooked. Seasoned marvelously. Smelled amazing.  Amazing potato chunks. Delicious.   I would have to say that the food did not impress me. Everything somehow came out to be too salty or not salty enough. I felt like the food was way overpriced for what it is. But the service was amazing and the ambiance is beyond comfortable. Maybe the dinner option might have a better chance of winning me over.

lxOcZ1VZ58nSCFgcunecjw.review_text: I've wanted to check out Park Tavern since it opened as everyone I know that has eaten there has had really good things to say.  We didn't get to have dinner here (yet) so we opted for brunch.  We didn't have a reservation but were there when it opened and we got a table no problem.  We listened to our waiter and got most of his recommendations which were great.  I started off with a Bloody Maria which was good but definitely not the best Bloody Mary type drink I've ever had.  The meal was delicious though.  We had the butter cake which was so tasty and the grapefruit to start off.  Our group had the dutch baby, polenta cakes and country ham steak and everything was delicious.  Can't wait to come back for dinner now.

ck4oX0q1oGTj_flOHmA5zQ.review_text: I grabbed a quick dinner here with a friend before we had a meeting and was very pleased.  Everything from service to ambiance was great (a little on the loud side bit not too bad).  We only got entrees and I had the sea bass which was cooked to perfection--sauce was delectable.  I can see this being a great place for a date or drinks with friends--will definitely be back.

i0PLCv-R4rOT6xKf9mazcQ.review_text: Food was great! It was in a great spot and we had a good time until.....the valet service ruined my night. First it seems like they took my new Benz for a joy ride. Second I had a gps in my backseat and only when I got home do I realize it went missing. So I call the manager of that valet service and was only rude and incompetent. He told me that he couldn't do anything and basically to go F*** myself. So I lost a GPS and I had my car abused. Never going back there again.

l6Xp9x9Wt-t7yCqaMnuUJQ.review_text: Everything on the brunch menu is dope. Definitely recommend the avocado toast - just get it, you'll understand why once you taste it. And then you'll crave it often. The hash is another dish that sounds fair but is actually unbelievable. The hummingbird is my fave drink - a light and refreshing sparkling raspberry vodka cocktail, but the bloody Mary's are good too - spicy, filling, and garnished with beef jerky!

hKGpZbwH6LGCNiRgbNSyhA.review_text: Sticking out like a sore, very pink thumb, we coulda been kicked out.  Everyone else was classy, urban, and clean - just like the decor.  And in we burst, a bachelorette party with feather boas, tiaras, and discerning albeit high-pitched palettes.  But the only hard time they gave us was when they warned that only 6 could fit around their round tables.  Really, even with the angel wings, 7 of us fit just fine.  The food was compelling enough to distract us from bachelorette mayhem.  My faves:  - Crispy lemon chips with burrata: Just genius.  I thought a slice of lemon, dredged in rice flour, and fried in rice oil would still be bitter (given the pith) but it was uh-maaaaazing!  Someone get me a bag of those chips now! - Poulet noir: Others were not so impressed, but this was a creeper dish for me.  The more I ate, the more I realized how excellent it was.  The skin's truffle perfume matched divinely with the moist, tender meat. - Parisienne gnocchi: This dish made me swear and shake my fist.  Even after numerous attempts, my gnocchi cannot compare to those light, silky pillows.  Fucking bastards.  Cotogna's gnocchi has now been shoved into second place. - And while not as mind-blowing as the above, the brussel sprout chips, roasted chioggia beets, lamb croquettes, and variations of duck were solid and drool-worthy in their own right.  The beets were plated like a gorgeous, smattering of jewels. - Mary Etta's Bubbles and Washington Square were very refreshing.  - Finally, deviled eggs: everyone else's eyes rolled back in their heads.  But as an oenophobe, I can't comment.  I wasn't as impressed with the leafy salads, halibut, jerky (I don't think this is a worthy expression of Wagyu), the squash soup du jour, strawberry-rhubarb shortcake, nor banana split.  Service was impeccable (aside from the initial resistance to seating 7 people).  Valet at $12 was totally worth it.  And our waiter was terrific.   He comped us a scoop of chocolate ice cream with cocoa nibs.   And he was such a good sport with our bachelorette game of dares...poor guy is probably still trying to remove all the pink feathers.

QK3Qvnwc_RI_tughKL3oZA.review_text: Fantastic atmosphere!! Split some apps and a burger with my boyfriend to make the meal affordable, but everything was delicious! Next time I might splurge and get their signature chicken dish - it looked so good.

TQ3aV2cxI_nYlGZ4jCrBsA.review_text: The best thing about this restaurant is the outdoor seating facing Washington Square Park. The food is simple but good. I'd recommend the burger and the watermelon salad. The lobster salad was too salty and the small chunks of lobster were disappointing!

pct_kG_rWyCUNStt3ptssg.review_text: Great burger. Brussels sprout chips good too. Wine list OK. Service good. I don't like eggs but my friend said they were good. And they had bacon on top which is always a plus! Oh, not great acoustics - hard to hear when it's busy.

d0xsgwc-7H5GyIPXiUBnDQ.review_text: I visited Park Tavern for brunch. They have an interesting menu, which delivered for us on taste.  The wait (almost none) made it far superior to Mama's just across the way.  Plan to go again...

XmEywucVDyUP9VJ4SXGjzw.review_text: Park Tavern is new.  And it shows in some things that will get better with time.   Water was replenished with the liquid ending in my glass and the ice on the table.  Timing of some plates coming out of the kitchen was a bit off.  As I say, things like this work themselves out.  Likewise the menu.  A bit more trial and error.  One point of improvement would be the rolls served with dinner.  Unexceptional to the point of being what you find in the supermarket.  However, they don't need to do anything to perfect the deviled eggs with jalapeno and bacon.  Wonderful.  A Waldorf salad was also really good although more of the early autumn greens on the plate would have been welcome.  I ordered the caramelized onion and wild mushroom soup that came with a poached egg and brusselkraut knowing that I don't particularly care for onion soup. I was curious.  As expected, I didn't care for the onion soup but loved the mushrooms.  The egg added nothing to the soup and I couldn't taste the brusselkraut.    A main of grilled pork chop served medium came with butter bean pistou, dinosaur kale, toasted garlic & chili flakes.  The pork was tender but the stars of the plate were the beans and kale. These were just wonderful.  I felt that some of the spicing (perhaps the pistou) detracted from the taste of the perfectly tender pork.    All in all a very good addition to the food scene.

X9Owv6SwYonLcxZgRcT3aw.review_text: We came here on a Sunday evening during the holiday season.  Parking is difficult, but we found one on the street near the Washington park.  This is the old Moose's restaurant location, which was written about so much by columnist Herb Caen.  Sat at the bar at first and had beers and the brussel sprout chips, which were very good and innovative.  Good Ninnkasi IPA on draft.  We had the PT fries and crab salad for starters, which were both very good.  Kudos for creativity on the egg and caviar dipping sauce for the fries.  We went with the seafood for the entrees:  Atlantic cod with fennel and pearled onions was very good and the seared scallops with kale and ham were good.  We skipped dessert, and just had press pot decaf, which was good.  Service was very good, nice interior, and the atmosphere was lively and festive.  The menu had good gluten-free options.  I would consider going back and trying some of the meat entrees next time.

pOsSRzm0ZOXE9FcJ5pWxYg.review_text: What to Do When Your Divalicious Friend Swings Back Through Town: 1)  Ask what kind of food she would like to eat.   She says, "I will let you decide because as I recall you picked some pretty amazing places to eat the last time I was there."   yelp.com/biz/salt-house-… 2)  Make a reservation at PARK TAVERN. 3)  Breeze up to the valet stand ($12). 4)  Be warmly greeted and quickly ushered to your table in the middle of a large, chic, and bustling dining room. 5)  Order up a round of drinks. The fruity and bubbly Mary Etta's Bubbles with raspberry flavors was right up my alley and a nice homage to Mrs. Moose ($11).   6)  Order two bowls of the Brussels Sprout Chips. Because once you've tried these warm, crisp, salty, and lemony "chips," you will immediately want more!  ($7). 7)  Order the infamous Deviled Eggs.   At first, we didn't receive them for some reason but they were worth the wait.  Topped with bacon and minced jalapenos, these savory bites will convert even the most staunch deviled egg hater ($2 each).  (Plus they were graciously comped due to the mix up.)   8)  Next time order more appetizers and fewer entrees. The disappointingly gritty Mussels, Cockles, and Clams came in a too salty for me tomato broth ($21).  However, the Diva loved her Scallops dish with Butter Beans and Sausage ($28) and the Better Half liked his hefty Pork Chop ($27). 9)  Save room for desserts (note the plural). The May's Birthday Cake was a gorgeous cake layered with raspberry cream cheese and raspberry buttercream and topped with a lighted candle ($9).  Fun!  We were less enamored by the "It's It" as it was a scoop of chocolate covered mint ice cream and salty and sparse oatmeal cookie sprinkles ($8).  The rhubarb addicted Better Half scarfed down his Strawberry and Rhubarb Shortcake in short order ($8).   10)  When the Diva declares this the best meal of the trip, think "Mission Accomplished!"

FevFGnLcuFZum6i7w5I56g.review_text: Solid 4 star experience that met my expectations. Burger was very good but nowhere near NOPA's. They split it for me and my friend as an app. We also split the green goddess salad, which was just ok. (Fresh parsley was the only flavor that popped; chicharrones were soggy and one of them way too spicy compared to the rest.)    Then we split the poulet noir chicken. Cool presentation, moist & delicious. Beware: it comes whole and you carve it yourself. Gasp! I dig that, but imagine a lot of foofy people would balk it. Relax, the pieces come apart easily with a little knife work, and you can impress a date with your skillz.  Good wines by the glass. Hostess and servers had upbeat attitudes without being fake & annoying. Overall reasonably priced. Crowd seemed like mostly locals, which is refreshing in north beach. Packed on a Monday nite is a good sign that this place will last in a notoriously high turnover location.

VTOcmT_LCWn6arNWpFGJrg.review_text: Amazing customer service! The staff got us a great table for Friday lunch, chilled & served our champagne, and surprised us with a birthday dessert. An altogether classy dining experience that helped facilitate some important business discussions.

B4cJvWuf59j7XlTdexnVZw.review_text: Just like the original spot, the Marlow Burger is exceptional, but this spot has the added benefit of being a bit more professionally run.  The bartenders seem very seasoned.  I was given, without asking, a glass of water and as I went to cut my burger in half with a butter knife, was offered a steak knife.  Fries were perfectly done.  Burger is just the right size; not too messy.  Bun holds the juices and sauce well.  Beer was not quite cold enough and they could use better glasses for bottled beers (they just used a water glass), but those were minor and didn't bother me enough from enjoying the meal.  Not a cheap place, but classy burger and a beer will run you $24 all in.  Oh, and they did include that scam health care fee, which I hate, but again, not enough to lower a star.

V626eGyIil5fVpbN3c56lA.review_text: This restaurant is wonderful in all the important fronts - service, food and ambiance.  A large, spacious dining hall with good cocktails, a straightforward all-American menu and a fun scene. The restaurant is loud and busy but it's a great place to go out to with friends.  Our group ordered the following appetizers:  Deviled eggs - awesome smokey flavor, a must have! Brussel sprout chips - really taste. Takes a healthy food and makes it into a lovely snack that is sinfully crispy and salty. Smoked fish dip - a bit underwhelming, leave this to your Jewish deli Lemon & basil leaf burrata - the burrata is like any you've had before. The draw here are the awesome lemon chips for dipping! Charcuterie board: definitely underwhelming. Leave it to a charcuterie/salumeria  For dinner we ordered: The roasted chicken which is served on a cast iron sticking up in the air and very juicy. It was a delight. The creekstone steak. Buttery and soft, the sauce was lovely too but the steak lacked a deep meaty flavor.  Would go back - very fun restaurant with friends.

dqwk2Zv5aKKZFmirn8kkZQ.review_text: Very cool ambiance and a young professional crowd.  The food was very good but overall, didn't blow me away.   + Brussels sprout chips - Delicious but a little too oily. + Compressed watermelon salad with feta, olives, and mint - Wonderful, light and refreshing.  + Wild arugula, mushroom conserva, porcini & charred onion vinaigrette - Super simple but fantastic flavors + Seared Morro Bay black cod, sugar snap peas, baby leaks, red radish & Calabrian chile butter - Good flavors but could have been more tender.

wm5YW01-sTnkovAE2U5mdA.review_text: Two words: deviled eggs.  Just go. Its so worth it. Most nights, with a party less than 4, you don't need a reservation... but its always good to plan ahead. Drinks and wine selection are great too. Fun place.

FtZwnW4sMZC0kavor-ffSg.review_text: My family and I went to The Park Tavern for our very first time and had the most amazing experience ever. The appetizers were the best ever...deep fried brussel sprouts and deviled eggs. For my entree I had the sole..cooked perfectly with the sauce. Our waiter Christo was so attentive and helpful. He recommended a couple bottles of wine for us that we absolutely loved. Overall our experience was a 5 star from start to finish!!!

fDP3tzea_LP2sn464v6QJw.review_text: Everything that we had here was amazing--Wild arugula with mushroom conserva, porcini & charred onion vinaigrette, Demons on horseback, Brussels sprout chips. Everything was full of flavor. I'm a huge fan if SPQR's Brussels sprouts, but I must say Park Taverns are really good! Parking is a pain in north beach...glad they offer valet.

TFpnh7H3MzWSEqFj7QX8Sg.review_text: If you haven't been, Park Tavern is a must. Great food, great service, and a great time. If you can't get a table because of short notice, try the bar. They have a waiting list, but it only took us 15 minutes to get seated (the long public table is first come first serve). We returned within two weeks of our first visit - my girlfriends 30th Birthday. On that note, it is a great spot for a special occasion. I dropped by early to drop off a special bottle of wine that we love, and to make several small arraignments.  The hostess was extremely nice and very helpful.  The main courses are great, but my girlfriend and I also like to dine on a number of appetizers, which are all amazing: burrata w/lemon chips, carpaccio, salads, gnocchi, deviled eggs (I normally do not particularly care for these, however I love them here), etc. They also have a great wine, beer, and speciality cocktail list.  I will be returning in the very near future.

2HUQjb9aOyFdkJTe-yyCig.review_text: Great brunch with a unique menu.  Lived the (unsweetened) fruit dish and husband enjoyed his bruleed grapefruit.  Entrees were also good.  Top notch service.

bPOwZhbJ0goXsE_-EwJ4zQ.review_text: Wife and I visited this place instead of Mama's. We were quite happy. The food is super fresh, brought out promptly and absolutely delish.   We shared deviled eggs. Wife had the smoked salmon Benedict and I had the in house chorizo W eggs. Each of us had a hand crafted beverage recommended by the bartender and neither disappointed.   Bill ended up being around $70 w 20% tip.

ddT6pNEmdQOvc2LZvZ4-VA.review_text: I have been to park tavern multiple times and there is not one thing on the menu short of amazing - dishes and cocktails. Amazing service and the patio on the park is a brunch must on a beautiful sf day.

T9Pl1YcmBmIVW0L4PioUUg.review_text: good food, good wine, good service. definitely expensive, but worth it.

V7DdGl7r2Gi-yc5K2JFM6g.review_text: Awesome buttermilk pancakes. Can't remember any better. Carlos was a great waiter as well. Really great service.

zyLIp7DRFqeIE1Grrh3Zng.review_text: Pretty impressed with this new spot from the Marlowe team.  Nice space, well executed food.  We started with the deviled eggs, steak crudo, pork belly bites, and uni. The only miss was the uni, which we all agreed could do without the butter lettuce.  The fried oysters were okay, not my favorite prep.  For our mains we tried the NY steak, poulet rouge, and the burger. The chicken was fantastic, served whole, upright on a stand. It was moist and perfectly seasoned. Burger was just as good as Marlowe's, and the steak was cooked fine but nothing special.  Cocktail list featured some interesting drinks as well as classics.   Service was great, would definitely come back.

Qyw50bvFboMh9h6iS8CYRA.review_text: We think Marlow has the best burger in the city but they are closed on Sunday so the hostess sent us to Park Tavern.  Not to impressive...The bu was hard...the meat was well done and we requested medium rare..the fries were cold...and we had the deviled eggs for an app and there were 3 of us and we had 2 eggs..strange.  Staff and bartender were nice, but will not go back.  Marlow is so much better.  The friend we took loves burgers so we felt bad because it just was not to good, but we had a fun time any way.  Drinks were good.

hNzYBmZJEmcOGX_RnWnLEQ.review_text: I can't help but feel that Park Tavern is coasting. Kind of getting-away-with-it and laughing all the way to the bank.  Not that it's bad. It's not bad at all.. but it's a premium priced establishment which 'only' offers good food.  PT seems to have reached that critical mass of popularity at that price point of which restauranteurs must dream - it's always packed, and judging by the crowd it's a Destination eatery in the city at the weekend for bridges and tunnels folks.  What you get:  - Location: On Washington Square, so it looks kind of pretty but parking is a disaster unless you valet. - Great space (think classic NYC brasserie feel) - Without a reservation, probably 45mins-1 hour wait. Although there is bar seating and a first come, first served communal table which is a nice touch. - Menu: modern Californian, with a few nice twists. I like the brunch menu the best, and specifically the polenta cakes with mushrooms, avocado toasts and pastries. The famous 'Marlowe Burger' is also well thought of by the burger-eating community.  - The Bloodies are worth checking out. As a beer person, I'm always disappointed with the draft selection - but then, it's not really their thing. Wine list is fine.  My issue is one of price and consistency. If the service and food was consistently excellent, I would feel like PT was about 15% overpriced but I'd still come back once in a while especially if I lived nearby, or wanted a boozy brunch in a nice space - possibly for a birthday or something. But the fact is they have consistency issues - the service can get surprisingly sloppy when it gets really busy (which it often does), and for a premium price you do expect the food to be on-the-money every time (which it isn't) - soggy burger buns, overcooked eggs have been served up to my party more than once.  Exec Summary: You can do better for the money.

OqLlzIr6qW1U2gfdZNItrA.review_text: Love Park Tavern! The roasted chicken is amazing, as are the brussel sprouts!

uzdUXO3OPI2Czt14aUrDvg.review_text: After dining in this space years ago as Moose's and then seeing Joey & Eddy's short stint in Washington Square, I was certain that this spot was cursed! However, after dining at Park Tavern I'm convinced that they have the right formula to make the most of this awesome location!  I was most impressed with the overall aesthetic of the restaurant. It's one of the most beautiful restaurants in SF. It's classic, yet modern and although it's definitely fine dining, it's welcoming and not the least bit stuffy. Both old San Francisco and younger generations will appreciate this fabulous new hot spot.  Great drinks, tasty nibbles and impeccable service. What more could you ask for?!  I can't wait to come back!

Su3xgnVHAkieKfFU4l0q4g.review_text: THE BEST. I loved loved loved the tangy beef tartare with salty venison carpaccio and crispy-gooey fried marrow, and the tender lamb tongue with salty whole grain mustard sauce and oozy poached egg, and the addictive truffles caviar fries with a pleasant mix of crispies and soggies... what a f-ing great meal. OH, and they sell carafes of wine. Forever enamored.

kZbFJ9VTJTZaojxGfToVew.review_text: service was good but . . . that's about it food was mediocre, food was overpriced, ridiculous noise level for no purpose they should wall off the bar area and stop piping in pointless, loud music that only adds to the din that makes it impossible to converse with whomever you went with to have dinner would not return, as there's better food at better prices in better environment elsewhere

7EH9DdOyfe0Jbd4SydblVw.review_text: The hen was not my taste. The scallops were good, a bit too salty, over peas on mashed peas.  I took a star off bc it was a disappointing 2 piece of scallops. Usually it is 3 jumbo peice at other restaurants. I asked the waitress how many pieces before ordering and she said 3-4, depending on size. It was not!  Usually dessert can save the meal, but the bread pudding didn't do it. The bread itself was dense with a bounce to the texture which I like. However, since the bread was bland and wasn't too sweet, the taste is enhanced from the sauce. The sauce tasted bitter, perhaps they burnt the sugar too long.

vez63FREjQp-zsBWOgHwQQ.review_text: Deviled eggs are to die for

UW1zrBva6-e-MgRtVk8TLw.review_text: I had burger and grapefruit mimosa, husband had Bloody Mary. Everything was exceptipnally good. Wish we could have sat outside with the view of Washington Square, but the bartender kept us very entertained. This place deserves its great Yelp reviews. Even the hostesses were friendly and professional.

2GZwrITslHTP3e5GAF9fig.review_text: We arrive 10 mins early on a friday night for a 10pm reservation. Hostess told us to wait since there are no tables available even though when we looked around there were a couple of tables free. Went to the bar and grabbed couple of cocktails which sounded interesting. It came almost devoid of alcohol. 15 mins go by and no one has sat in any of the tables, so we went up to her and told her it's past 10pm. She then said "oh, I was actually looking for you". Surprising considering she was standing there the whole time clearly not looking for anyone and we were a foot away from her the entire time. Fine whatever.  Sat down. We were actually excited since we live in the neighborhood and finally someone has opened a decent looking place with what seems like a good bar scene.    We usually are price insensitive when going to restaurant's food and cocktails. But this restaurant takes the cake. The bread given to us albeit tasty was stale.  I ordered the uni for an appetizer which was a big mistake, it was more like lettuce with a taste of uni. A quarter of an uni was divided by six, so it looked more like dots on top of lettuce. Having worked with the restaurant industry in New York, this was really insulting.  My husband ordered the burger and his fries were fried to a crisp that it just tasted like oil. My scallops were good, but again for the price you'd think you're eating at french laundry except you will actually be full at french laundry. We skipped on dessert after that meal. When we looked around us, the table of 3 to our left is sharing one side dish. And to our right, a group of 6 girls, didn't order alcohol and had 2 burgers between them. That means the place is too pricey for the hood.   The only thing they really have going for them is the ambiance and the fact that they look over the park. After we got the bill, all alcohol we ordered had hidden charges on them so a cocktail really came out to $14-16. If you want to get robbed and lied to, go to this place!

Ve0LUwcrzxL7w0RYgY4Aaw.review_text: I can't BELIEVE the dinner I had here at Park Tavern last month. When my boyfriend and I spotted $20 fries on the menu we wanted to scoff and then as if we could read each other's mind we both said out loud, "If they charge this much, maybe they're just THAT good." And trust me. THEY WERE.  But that's not all. We had cocktails and variety of other appetizers and small plates. Everything was more than good, it was phenomenal. Definitely a place you have to visit if you're coming to San Francisco and want to leave knowing just how great the food is in this city. In fact, I noticed my mother (who lives in SF) wrote Park Tavern a 5 star Yelp review last year. Great minds must eat alike!

HUXgan4Zm5W_xyy27RiCEA.review_text: Across St. Peters is yet another great brunch spot in San Francisco.  An old school bar feel on the inside, with an eclectic selection of brunch items.  The Prawns and grits was delicious.  Large shrimp with creamy flavorful grits really got our morning started out right.  Pricey yes, but well worth it.

FLjrwZRr6wgZVtIm9dWYEA.review_text: The first time I went here I was amazed by the food so I took my sister and boyfriend here for brunch. The deviled eggs were still awesome but I had the corned beef hash and my sister had the cod cake. Both sounded so good on paper but way too salty. The pancake was nice and fluffy but still sad about my savory dish.

Ez-8XuUezU1kyWQenUMLZA.review_text: I don't think they do analogies on the SATs anymore but.....  Cafe Lulu: Web 1.0  as  Park Tavern: Web 2.0   perhaps Park Tavern will survive when Web 2.0 crashes.....   Ditto Chris L.   Underwhelmed.  I had been there a few times when it was Moose's, and hadn't been back in the neighborhood since... that's what a toddler will do to your social life.... in any case, we ended up in bar seating, which was fine by me, but wtf is up with people who continue to elbow you once, not twice, but multiple times during your meal? seriously dude in plaid shirt who probably works in some douchebaggy industry... NOT cool.   Anyhoo. Service was brisk and friendly, but I guess the idea of a bowl of Brussels Sprouts 'chips' is not that amazing to someone who makes kale chips on a regular basis....   scallops were decent, dessert (i think it was a creme brulee?) was decent but not amazing.

9GOk4F9pcO6Q8E2OTD5zrw.review_text: I came here with some people from my firm as a work dinner and I am so happy that my firm partner chose this restaurant.  Our 4+ hours there were so amazing and I cannot wait til I can come here again with the bf.  As soon as I sat down, I ordered the Moscow Mule.  It's a bit stronger here than I'm used to but still good.  Their drink menu looks very extensive though so I'll be sure to order something else next time.  We had the much raved-about Deviled Eggs, half with bacon and half without for the vegetarians on our table.  I don't know if it was the bacon but these were so damn delicious.  I loved that it had a little kick from the smoked jalapenos.  The Brussels Sprout Chips surprised the entire table - who knew that baked vegetables can be so darn good?  It has inspired me to turn every vegetable in my fridge into a chip with the use of olive oil, salt, pepper, and an oven.  The Lemon Chips with Burrata were okay.  They fried the lemon peel with it so you get a slight bitter taste but it was a refreshing dish.  I'd rather pick the sprout chips.  The table forced me to pick another appetizer so I asked our waiter what he recommended.  He responded PT Fries and he promised it would be amazing.  I have to say, I was very hesitant because how amazing can fries be?  Yeah well, they can be pretty amazing if you fry them in flavorful truffle oil.  I'm talking about truffle that you can taste, not like other restaurants that call their regular french fries "truffle fries."  On the side was a cracked soft boiled egg with caviar inside, which not only made the dish visually appealing but enhanced the flavor of the truffle oil.  There's also sauce on the side, which I think was some kind of aioli, most likely garlic.  In any event, you don't need it - the fries are perfect as they are.  The boss wanted the Butter Lettuce Wedge to take a break from all the fried and heavy foods.  The fennel vingaigrette made it a great refresher.  Some people at our table really liked the Cool Roasted Cauliflower but I did not, mainly because of the bellpepper sauce (romesco) the cauliflower laid on.  I'm not a fan of bellpepper so that's that for this dish.  The boss ordered the Scallops and she was very satisfied with it.  I had a taste and it was just okay for me. Someone else ordered the Sea Bass, which was really good.  The fish was so soft and juicy it melted in our mouths.  I, being a red meat fan, ordered the CAB NY Steak.  For all of you who are immediately captured by the words "bone marrow," just be aware that it's fried kobe beef stuffed back in the bone.  In other words, you're not going to get the creamy, full-flavored deliciousness that is bone marrow.  Trust me, I found out the hard way.  But that is not to say that it wasn't delicious.  It's creative and it was flavorful (though the flavor and texture reminded me a bit of corned beef) but it's kind of a waste to fry perfectly good bone marrow.  The NY steak was done perfectly to my liking - medium rare.  You get two pieces, though I did not need that much since I was popping out of my buttons by this point.  The broccolini and crispy potatoes were also done well.  Though dessert seemed ill-advised and impossible, we still manned up and ordered an Apple Cheddar Crisp and the Chocolate Creme Brulee.  The apple cheddar crisp is really the way to go.  You get ice cream on top of a warm apples with a hint, but not too noticeable, of cheddar.  The creme brulee was a little burnt on the top so we tasted some bitterness but even if it wasn't, I don't think it would've been anything amazing.  All in all, we had a great time.  We enjoyed our servers a lot (they were all very accommodating and didn't mind when we sat at the bar longer than we needed to) and the food was terrific.

A1mJ0kf_4UhFriEu0KkwNw.review_text: Reviews have raved about Park Tavern and 7x7 Magazine named it one of the four best new restaurants from last year.  All the hype is true.  Facing Washington Square, the restaurant is in a prime location.  The interior is hip and clean and I dig the white floor tiles.  You can see the entire kitchen and the waiting staff is friendly and helpful.  The must eats: deviled eggs (probably the best I have ever had AND they are topped with bacon), burrata with lemon chips, and the poulet rouge.  The chicken is somewhat disturbing in its presentation and is sitting upright, waiting for you to slice it and eat it.  It made me guilty to be a carnivore but it was so tasty.  The cocktails are good and strong, especially the Ed Negroni.  The deviled eggs take the cake though and I could have ate them all night.  I want some right now!  The lemon chips are innovative and I'm hoping they catch on as a great dried fruit that can be purchased in stores.

MLPGlFG75NNe4ufCC5_Caw.review_text: I still dream about the deviled eggs....We got drinks at the bar first.  I liked the vibe and layout of the bar.  We waited an hour for a table on Thursday night, and it was well worth it.  The food was scrumptious.

HWL3aKSFdDQLsxGWys2GBg.review_text: I sat in the bar. I ordered the NY steak with marrow and crispy potatoes. It was really good. I ordered it medium-rare, came out on the rare side (which was fine).

1mr1KGNshWHKVKUbnZda-A.review_text: This restaurant is soooo yummy and the staff is amazing.  My friend was visiting from out of town and his flight was delayed twice. Both times I called the hostess and she accommodated my new time and even asked my friend how his flight was when we finally arrived.   We got the deviled eggs (delicious and I don't usually like deviled eggs), beef jerky (YOU HAVE TO ORDER THIS- you will never be able to eat non-wagu beef jerky again), the marlow burger (even better than the original at Marlowe), and the whole chicken.  I will admit the chicken was kind of intimating being on a stand looking like it was going to start dancing at any moment, but it was so good.  Lastly we finished up with the almond joy dessert.  ARE YOU KIDDING ME?!?! I have been dreaming of it since.    Everything about this place was fantastic and I cannot wait to go back!

K0a_wuOCcjiNn2C6zz4DpA.review_text: Pretty bummed with the average bloody mary I received here. Was told they had a variety per another review. Apparently they only add beef jerky to their bloodies on Sundays. Full review at outforbloodies.com.

JUDK3oQCINsatzWjorVc9g.review_text: Dinner review is 3.5 stars so I'm being generous and rounding to 4. We came here for dinner on a Tuesday night (made the reservation about an hour before so they were really good about getting us in). We got there and were seated at a small 2-person table extremely close to the surrounding tables on either side of us; however, it wasn't awkward or too close for comfort. I don't know how they manage to pull that off, but they did. Props, Park Tavern.  We ordered: 1. Brussels sprout chips - 3 stars. They were good but extremely salty. 2. Devolved egg - 5 stars. BOMB! The pickled jalapeño made it. 3. Salad - 4 stars. I can't remember the exact name of it but it was a simple salad with avocado and a nice vinaigrette. 4. Burger - 3 stars. The meat was cooked well (we ordered medium rare) but there was way too much sauce/aioli on the burger. I like my meat plain and it sort of overpowered the burger. Ask for it on the side next time.  5. Porkchop - 5 stars. Dank. Rivals the pork chop from The House. This one is more traditional and served with Parmesan risotto and root vegetables.  No dessert so can't vouch for that but the ones that the table to the left of us ordered (approximately 5 inches away) looked great.  I'll be back but not for the infamous burger. It's better at Marlowe and I think there are much better burger options around the city.

oEvsA_IvL0yRyI7d4lT-IA.review_text: We came for brunch and shared the avocado toast, the bay shrimp toast, and the smoked salmon benedict. My favorites were the avocado and smoked salmon. The avocado toast was simple but super tasty (and definitely something I would like to try to recreate at home) and the smoked salmon had a good texture and smoky flavor. i would definitely recommend for brunch in the area, and outside weather-permitting.   Service was really attentive. We had to move twice (once our mistake, second theirs), and they were so gracious and sent over the avocado toast on the house. It's the little things like that that make people want to return again and again.

rCZXqeYyHNetLSivXJnyUQ.review_text: Wow, their brunch pallet is the best around. Five stars for about their whole brunch menu.  Tried dinner twice. I'm not sure how it's  possible, but it's like a polar opposite experience. The hen's awesome though. We'll stick to coming here for brunch.

-K2Tcgh2EKX6e6HqqIrBIQ.review_text: We had a nice dinner at Park Tavern a few weeks ago.  Nothing spectacular, simply good food and attentive service.  We had a visitor in town,   so I wanted to show her a good time, and figured I'd use my gift card on a splurgy dinner.    Things started off awkwardly when we arrived and the hostess ushured us through the nearly empty restaurant to a table right next to the bussing station.  Uh-uh, homie don't play that, so we moved to a different location.  Our waitress was really friendly, but a little bit pushy.  Stop coming over every few minutes to see if we are ready to order - we're not!  Once the food started coming out things got much better.  Between the three of us, we sampled the deviled eggs, the lemon chips with burrata and the beef jerky.  After overdosing on the burrata, we decided to simply take the jerky with us when we left.    I had the halibut, which was amazing, but as reviewer Gwynnie P mentions, everything is drenched in butter, including my piece of fish.  Not that I mind butter, but wow.  My hons of husband had the duck four ways,which was killer.  Duck confit, slices of breast, pate and crispy skin.  Sister ended up with the salmon, which was another fantastic piece of fish.  Again, a pleasant time, but I don't think I'll be back for a while, especially if I'm paying!

J1-B5TtWM5CCKlTL_NG7vw.review_text: The Setting:  Work dinner with team Wednesday evening, had a reservation for 5, seated after 10 minutes.  First half of meal - 4 stars Second half of meal - 3 stars  The GOOD: 1.  Brussel Sprout Chips - perfeclty flavored, crispy, melted in my mouth.  A group hit. 2.  Twin Peaks (Cocktail) - loved it, had a second.  Great for Bourbon drinkers. 3.  Lobster Bisque - one person thought it was too rich, two of us loved it!  Huge chunks of lobster meat and great bisque taste. 4.  Twice Baked potato - wow.  Standing "O" from the table, definitely get this if you only get one side dish.  The OK: 1.  Aarowfarms figs - one person loved it, three of us thought it was only ok.  The figs themselves were great, but the burrata and proscuitto were sub-par. 2.  Marlowe Burger - not the best bun, meat was decent.  Try Wayfare Tavern or NOPA for a better burger. 3.  Salmon - This was a safe option, pretty good fish.  Nothing stood out about it.  The BAD: 1.  Golden Gate (cocktail) - too sweet.  3 of us tasted it, none of us liked it, sent back.  The Bottom Line:  A meal that had great atmosphere and started great but had sub-par entrees.  My guess is that, had we stuck to appetizers, sides, and small plates, my rating would be much higher, possibly five stars...

7rAjfK9cJ0sOsvu1Pg_0yA.review_text: Not your typical North Beach joint, this is a classy eatery! Really nice bar with hand crafted cocktails, amazing deviled eggs and house made Wagu Beef Jerky.... I ordered two orders to go! Our dinner was just as expected, great. Very busy, hard to get in without reservations but worth the try!

Sxo8XMLve3vxsvqeC7zSZg.review_text: I have now eaten at Park Tavern twice, and both times it was equally as impressive.   Both visits I ordered the Brussels sprouts as an appetizer, great crispy and lemon taste! Plus, you get a fair amount!  I've had the pork and the burger, and I loved both! Beer and wine selection was awesome. Service was great. If you make a reservation, it seems that you get seated pretty much on time.

1qOm01uCaMlroc1g2V0jrQ.review_text: I love this place!  I went for the first time about a month ago with a friend spontaneously.  We did not have a reservation (it was a weekday night) but were seated at a nice table right away.  We started with the deviled eggs which were to die for!  Then we both had the burger and agreed that it was one of the best we had ever had. I went back this weekend with my mother who was visiting from out of town.  We did have a reservation but when I called to add a 3rd person that day I was told they would have to push back the reservation a half hour or seat us at a communal table.  I was not thrilled about this since neither option was appealing. If it was a Friday or Saturday night I would not have minded waiting a half hour but it was Sunday at 8pm.  I ended up calling back and they said to just come in and they would seat us as soon as they could.  Upon arrival we were seated within 10 minutes which I appreciated.  We had a fantastic server (I wish I could remember his name) and all 3 of us loved our dinners.  We started with the brussel sprout chips which I personally think are overrated but they certainly didn't taste bad.  Just greasy and overpriced.  I had the Poulet Noir which was very flavorful. My mother had the sole and my cousin had the scallops.  They were good but she only got 4 and was still hungry.  We shared the October birthday cake (coconut) to complete the night and I thought it was dry and boring. Overall, I love the decor and vibe of this place and think the service is fantastic.  But giving it 4 stars as opposed to 5 because of some of the food items (just not worth 5 stars) and for what you get for your money. I think I may go back and just sit at the bar and get the burger.  If I did that every time I'm pretty sure it would be a solid 5 stars!

aMxgZUaf1h_7Wv46G3amvg.review_text: Love love! Excellent and attentive service! Appetizer Demons on Horseback (tiger prawns) was magnificent! Roasted cauliflower was very tasty! Carrot salad hubby loved. Then I had the rib eye and hubby had pork chop, equally delicious! French fries is such a simple dish yet so perfectly done! It was my birthday celebration, got a slice of December Birthday cake on the house, perfect way to end an evening!!!!!! Will definitely go back

vNasIeIJzFQT3c2rleSJRA.review_text: I really can't say enough about this place. Some of the highlights:  1. The bar: I love the bar. Forget the great people watching and beautiful people; Jack the bartender rocks.   2. The burger: Try it. The burger here is top-5 in SF.

mAhty2OHDTtLm00quB5Xjw.review_text: Good, modern food and excellent, accommodating service in a spacious and (relatedly) uncrowded dining room.

0U2g8BBME4E4D3A0n2aDHQ.review_text: One of my SF mainstays. Food is always delicious, cocktails are inventive and fun (try the "Saturday Morning Cartoon" for brunch),  view is beautiful, and service is consistently great. I can always count on Park Tavern to be a good time all around!

S2qvRVfSD6sw6b4rtGFJ2Q.review_text: food is good, starters more than the entree's. but the main thing here is the atmosphere.   This place is where it's at right now. Seriously.  I almost felt not blonde enough to be there!   Their wine selection is amazing - prices are really fair - I strongly suggest you will give it a thorough look before ordering - there are some hidden gems in it.   Enjoy it while the buzz is still there.  Oh, and don't miss the chocolate creme brûlée   Notice: we had a reservation - and still we waited for 17 min. to be seated.  Also service can be more attentive - we had to ask twice for the bread (which was really good with good butter).

XqwYU6giiq7VRK-8OXVNhQ.review_text: I love their drinks here because the collections are not usual.  I love to take my meal from this place.  I love to have service from them for ling time.  Their bread is super and amazing.  Their egg is tasty and heavily prepared.  Their burger is wondering and well spicy.

JLGxVX3tCtm9B7ow6Fv_3A.review_text: I am so happy that we got a recommendation to come to Park Tavern for our first night in San Francisco! From the service, to the awesome cocktails, to the to die for food...this place was perfection to me.  We came on a Friday night around 8pm and they told us it would be about an hour wait for an outside table.  We thought it would be worth it so headed to the crowded but bearable bar.  Even though it was packed the bar tenders were still really attentive.  I only had to glance down at the menu and see a strawberry basil caipirinha to decide on my drink. It was really nice and  refreshing!  Once we sat down we ordered the brussel chips and devilled eggs.  My best friend and I have always said there should be brussel chips! They were awesome with a slight lemon zest taste and the perfect crunch.  My very picky boyfriend even loved them.  The devilled eggs were some of the best I've ever had.  They use almost the whole egg ether than just half and top it with a generous piece of crispy bacon...ah mazing!  Both of our entries were really good as well. We got a steak and the burger.  To top it off every single staff member at this restaurant was super nice and attentive.  I you find yourself in San Francisco make it a point to come here!

IgMo_FL5lHiuuBR6qtoxzw.review_text: Delicious food in a great atmosphere! This place is busy all the time! Make a reservation if you can - to avoid the wait! We sat at the bar, the last time, and the bartenders are nice/attentive, but not chatty.  Brunch is amazing...great Bloody Mary's!! The deviled eggs are delish!  Dinner is even better! And dessert - yum!! I believe the "birthday" cake changes each month?  This place is here to stay (I hope)!

byUZpVzun-vVMMCFMXvdXQ.review_text: One of my absolute favorite places not only in North Beach but in San Francisco!  The restaurant itself is a simple and rustic style of decor that draws me in and never gets old. I love the vibe of it. The staff is excellent. They're true professionals and there has never been a time that I've been in there that even one of them has disappointed. They great me with a warm welcome every time I go there.  The food has always been consistent and delicious. I'm a huge fan of their deviled eggs; simply a must-have virtually every time I go. The pork chop is one my favorite entrees for flavor and portion size. This thing could easily feed two people! Don't forget the classics that they've brought from their first restaurant, Marlowe, like the brussel sprout chips, the Marlowe burger, and the truffle fries.  If you're there for drinks only then sit at the bar or the community table which serves as an extension to the bar and allows visitors to eat too. You can eat at the bar too but the table allows you to sit face-to-face with your friends, etc.  This is and will always be one of my favorite go-to spots in town!

796OmGM6yE1BOm--y0M1gg.review_text: Disappointing.  Went with in a group of six, we had reservations.  The restaurant is beautiful, the cocktails were good, and some of the food we ordered was good.  But much of it was overpriced and poorly executed.    Our server was okay but bad about taking drink orders.  When we ordered our first round they took a long time to arrive, and this was true for every round we ordered.  The bar area is busy and the drinks are creative so I understand that it takes time to put them together, but it's important to get drinks on the table and keep them there when a party is seated for dinner.  Our server was not prompt about taking our drink orders when our drinks were empty or near-empty, and at one point took the drink orders of the rest of the table but not mine.  The drinks were so slow in arriving that there was a time between courses when the entire table of six had finished their cocktails, the empty glasses had been cleared, and we were without drinks (or food) for a good fifteen minutes.  It's very unusual to sit at an upscale restaurant mid-meal with nothing but water glasses on the table for so long.  We ordered a bunch of appetizers, some of which were okay, but when we asked the waiter for a recommendation for a vegetable appetizer he recommended the raw vegetable plate.  I expected something more creative than the unseasoned carrots, cucumber, radishes, and dip that arrived.  My first thought when it arrived was that it must be unbelievably cheap for the restaurant to prepare but very profitable.  I couldn't help but wonder if the waiter was instructed to recommend the dish because of the margin.  I'm still shocked it's actually on the menu (not to mention that it was recommended), because it was essentially the equivalent of veggies and spinach dip.    One other thing about the appetizers--they came out very quickly.  Too quickly.  As though they were all sitting somewhere pre-prepared and had just been loaded onto plates when the order came in, rather than made to order.  I should have learned my lesson about taking recommendations from our waiter, but I couldn't decide between entrees.  I asked the server whether I should order the tuna or the sturgeon and he recommended the sturgeon, so I went with it.  It was a huge mistake.  It arrived cold and bland, with an unpleasant chalky taste.  The accompaniment didn't add much, as it came with sad looking vegetables in the exact same sauce that had been on one of our appetizers.   Someone at my table ordered the scallops and offered me one when she noticed I wasn't eating my fish (although she noticed this, the waiter did not).  The scallop had sand in it.  Someone else ordered the burger, which was good but not spectacular.  The truffle fries were very good, the Brussels sprouts were good but not particularly unique, and a prawn appetizer we ordered was very good but mostly because it was cooked in bacon fat.  The deviled eggs were okay, but I've had better at Wayfare Tavern.  All in all I had the impression that the restaurant's mission is not to make excellent food and provide a high quality dining experience, but to do its best imitation of doing so to earn as much money as possible to pay for that enormous, beautiful space on Washington Square Park.  When I first walked in I was struck by it and commented on how they could have possibly afforded it.  I guess it's by recommending the veggies and dip.

CE4010mkXy25VayX-YIpAw.review_text: A Huge Thank You "Jennifer" for the BEST Filet Mignon I've had in the City, it was a  very nice portion with every piece melting in your mouth, and so tender that you could cut it with a fork!!!    The twice cooked potatoes were awesome and the mushrooms tied the whole meal together, just a Great memorable meal that won't be soon forgotten. Our server Ora (Sorry if I misspelled your name) was wonderful, she took her time and never once rushed us, and Thanks Mike for putting us at the table we mentioned on our first visit that we just loved, thanks for noting that, as it was a nice surprise. Brian and James, thank you for the awesome libations as always, you guys are the best, and with regards to the hostesses, you ladies topped everything off with your wonderful greetings coming and going!!!

L4nm4YlRoLRY8Fq0DYXV8A.review_text: Being a fan of Marlowe,  I couldn't wait to try Park Tavern with the besties and we thoroughly enjoyed our dinner!  We started with the deviled eggs which were delicious, but preferred Marlowe's version by a hair. The burrata served with lemon chips was another excellent starter, and I loved the pairing of the two. As for entrees, the braised short ribs were incredibly tender and seasoned just right, and the pork chop was surprisingly impressive! Perfectly cooked and juicy without being oversalted, what more could one ask for? I loved the upscale tavern ambiance, and the service was amazing to boot. Will definitely be back for a repeat visit.

T5n6X9XR4TcFFI5e8UC76w.review_text: Nice atmosphere, no wait when Mama's is an hours wait.  This is just as good brunch place.  will definitely come back for more menu items when we hang out here after a walking tour of the city.

dWe4qfWT_urGY8spxucAUg.review_text: Had plans to go to Mama's for breakfast but the line up the street was about a two hour wait in cold drizzly weather so we quickly changed destination and landed at Park Tavern, a stone throw from Mama's.  What a delicious surprise! Our  brunch food was extraordinary.  The pancakes with rosemary infused blueberry compote were delish.  The pancetta cakes topped with poached eggs out of this world and the wheat avocado chili and lemon oil was a hit with our vegan in the group.  Overall, this place offers amazing food, great service in a very beautiful, comfortable setting.  Don't miss it when in SF!

NI3K8WNfAwmUuHtT5lgN3A.review_text: Ate a casual dinner at the communal table last Friday night.  It was my third time at Park Tavern -- once previously for dinner and another time for brunch.  I've always had good food when I'm there, though it is definitely not a value dining destination.    We had the PT fries at this most recent visit.  OMG.  Unreal.  I've never dipped a french fry in to an egg before...but I plan to again :)

BuzxMxVrGBTsQyagoJHECQ.review_text: The food here is pretty great, especially their lemon chips. It's a nice, casual atmosphere inside and I had a great time. However, I do have two complaints about my experience, although they didn't really alter the enjoyability of my experience. First off, I have to recommend that the staff take down their "foodie" knowledge. I enjoy a waiter who knows what he's talking about, but ours came off as a bit snobby. Also, the 'birthday cake' dessert I ordered was very, very dry. It almost tasted as if it had been left out overnight. Other than those two blemishes, I enjoyed my dinner there.

YAG90mceVFQLdvl4wndvQg.review_text: wow this place is overrated.  + nice, attentive service + mussels - good, but not special  - waited a 20min despite having a reservation - HALF a deviled egg for $2...ummm overpriced. tasted like a hard boiled egg with bacon flavoring - lemon chips - too salty  this place would be a 3, but the food doesn't justify the price.

MzXPOK2_T5O8GF-4qUVmGA.review_text: The deviled egg renaissance of SF?  It all started here.  Jennifer Puccio is a true pioneer.  She took a mundane & pedestrian item & tweaked it a gourmet twist, & now they are on practically every menu in town.  This is no exaggeration.  Alta CA, Prospect, Bix, Fog City, The Brixton, Bocadillos, Hog & Rocks, and Sauce, just to name a few.  Chiarello offers his own version using quail eggs & Serrano ham @ Coqueta.  Even venues that are not full service restaurants like 20 Spot & Craftsman & Wolves sport them on their menus.  The point...the resurgence started right here overlooking Washington Square Park.  And, disclaimer: before some (well meaning, no doubt) smarty pants starts in; I'm not saying they've never been offered on another menu before.  Duh.  I'm saying that until Puccio's version, no one was thinking about them, talking about them, or waiting 6 weeks for a rezi or over an hour for a seat just to have them.  So if you're here, they're a must. The greatness doesn't end there.  The poulet noir is a must order.  Stunningly presented whole chicken...just do it.  Something I have every time I'm here?  The PT fries.  OMG.  BOOM!  Truffle fries that you dip into a creamy soft boiled egg w caviar.  Yeah.  They rock even more than it sounds.  A MUST order.  The brussels sprout chips, the gnocchi, the pork chop...basically PT just crushes it.  Real bartenders (instead of hipster mixologists that have to have their beards at least 3 inches long cuz it's allegedly a prerequisite to be a hipster), stellar cocktails that are classic, artisan, & contemporary, & now brunch, too?!  5 stars.

O7NPfQ6g2GsSjAf2blB_jw.review_text: HF:  In the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit. Amen.  ME:  Bless me Father, for I have sinned. My last confession was 11 months ago.  These are my sins.  I secretly hoped Joey & Eddie's would go out of business.  But since we both know the Big Guy is Italian, I'm sure He hated the tasteless food, wasteful portions, and gaudy decor as much as I did.  Do you think he'll hold it against me?  HF:  Say 10 Hail Mary's.  What else?  ME:  I started with a margarita and 6 deviled eggs.  6 Father!  6!!  HF:  Were they delicious?  ME:  Sinfully.  HF:  Say 10 more Hail Mary's, and next time eat 7 pork belly bites.  ME:  7?  HF:  7 my son.  Did you order an entree?  ME:  That's the worst part Father;  I ordered the Marlowe burger, medium-rare.  HF:  Blasphemy my son!  You realize he was an atheist?!  ME:  But I washed it down with a pint of the Monte Python Holy Grail Ale.  That should even things out shouldn't it?    HF:  Maybe.  Did the burger come with cheese?  ME:  Cheddar.  HF:  Say 1 Our Father and make an Act of Contrition; have dinner at Rose Pistola...or even worse, Bottle Cap.  ME:  Must I?  HF:  Free will my son, free will.  Now, let's hear it.  ME:  I am sorry for my sins with all my heart. In choosing to do wrong and failing to do good, I have sinned against you whom I should love above all things, even those eggs.  I firmly intend, with your help, to do penance, to sin no more, and to avoid whatever leads me to sin.  In your name, have mercy, please don't make me eat at Bottle Cap -- Amen.

Valva2MGzBW8ux3641YINA.review_text: I came for brunch and my Grapefruit Shandy was refreshing! I like dark rich coffee, a cup that gives you an orgasm feeling after the first sip, you know. I didn't like theirs, it was too light tasted a bit watered down and almost sour tasting( I even asked the waiter is your coffee sour? He said no). I ordered the polenta cakes with poached eggs and wild mushrooms. OMG so good! The polenta was very light and creamy perfection. I LOVED the mushrooms, they were perfectly cooked delicious. Poached eggs perfect too. I tried my friend's baked eggs, meh. Crab toast to start, not a fan. I would so go back for the polenta cakes.

a7dPjzrWpB-KZrFNZ5HWNg.review_text: Ever had a lemon chip? At Park Tavern, you really must.   While this place looks like the kind of dimly-lit bar your pa or grandpa might frequent (complete with soft-rock soundtrack, at least on the night we visited), the menu's all inventive and modern. Crispy, salty lemon chips pair up with fava been puree for an appetizer that's cooly creative. A seasonal seafood plate aims to boot charcuterie off your plate and and back to 2009. The corn soup is surprisingly creamy and flavorful, and perfect to go alongside something fresh and fishy. And the only thing stopping me from calling the deviled eggs "divine" at this point is my desire to avoid too much cloying alliteration in this paragraph.   It's the kind of place that makes you feel guilty for ordering a burger, but since I come from an amoral, bohemian-type background, I was able to move past these feelings and do it anyway. And it was good. So good that my dining partners found themselves straying from their fascinating entrees and stealing my fries.   The only thing I wouldn't order again was the squash blossoms (which may be off the menu now anyhow). Skimpy portions, not ideal for sharing, which you definitely want to do when the food's this tasty. I'd rather have like, 5 more bacon-topped deviled eggs. So good!

nNd1B29J81jXEpNs3qUtVg.review_text: Easily one of my absolute favorite restaurants in San Francisco. Never disappoints. Try the pork chop, deviled eggs and cocktails.

pZDQSy-tMqrl2rOKtAHNbw.review_text: The good: The food was amazing. Well executed with some not so me-too twists on familiar dishes (Yellow Doll Watermelon & prosciutto).  The bad: The restaurant could use to feel more quaint and intimate, maybe, um, like Marlowe.  The final thought: Compared to it's food/price/type contemporaries, would I return? Yes. Soon? Depends.  The P.S.: Shannon, our server, was knowledgeable, personable, and comfortably attentive.  ---  Mclaren Cocktail Pork Belly Bites Fish Dip Yellow Doll Watermelo & Prosciutto Seared Scallops

tK2saQemKNEto1ZqGWJAxA.review_text: Brunch was excellent. Oatmeal, walnut pancakes were excellent! Still craving those pancakes. :)  Open face, egg salad sandwich was okay. Would not order that again. Also tried the root beer float on the brunch libation menu and that was excellent. Very good brunch spot in North Beach.

rhROLqZmn8HiSJGUn8cB-A.review_text: Very impressed. I ate the following:   1. Avocado toast - Its toast , avocado and hot garlic sauce on top. Perfect melody of flavors.  2. Polenta with poached eggs and wild mushroom and arugula salad. Amazing again. Poached eggs were cooked just perfectly and the polenta was great too.  3. Tcho chocolate creme brulee. OMG !!! This reminds me of the tcho chocolate ice cream at smitten.  4. Cappucino - meh wouldn't recommend it.   Overall great food, great service. And oh they also have valet parking for $12. Make sure you have reservations though. This place gets busy !

eKUGKQRE-Ywi5dY55_zChg.review_text: A MUCH Anticipated Opening... As a huge fan of Marlowe, I was excited when I found out Park Tavern would be opening its doors on September 1st. As the sister restaurant to Marlowe, I have to say Park Tavern is definitely the "big" sister with its larger, sophisticated space and what I thought to be a more refined American bistro menu (there are some parallel items) complete with cocktails. On Sunday, 10.16.11, my friend and I came for an early dinner at 5:30 pm (with reservations) and were promptly seated. F O O D *BRUSSELS SPROUT CHIPS ($6) - 4.5 STARS yelp.com/biz_photos/4-pW… Aside from the Marlowe Burger, the Brussels Sprout Chips is what Marlowe is known for. It's crispy, salty and citrusy; simply ADDICTING! Just get it. *YELLOW DOLL WATERMELON, PROSCUITTO, TRUFFLE & MUSTARD GREENS ($12) - 4 STARS yelp.com/biz_photos/4-pW… A refreshing start to dinner, the sweet watermelon was a nice contrast to the salty prosciutto with the mustard greens adding a subtle bitterness. *PETIT "POULET ROUGE" w/ Bloomsdale Spinach & Peewee Potatoes ($23) - 4 STARS yelp.com/biz_photos/4-pW… Flawlessly cooked, the hen's skin was crisp and the meat was succulently moist and tender. Even the breast was moist and could easily be mistaken for the thigh meat. Well-seasoned, the hen was rich in flavor with a light kick. The condensed meaty flavor from the accompanying au jus gave it that extra oomph. The bloomsdale spinach was slightly charred which gave a smoky component while the fluffy as clouds peewee potatoes added a subtle sweetness. A perfectly balanced dish! Though I thoroughly enjoyed this dish, I would not recommend ordering it on a date unless you want to scare your date off with your lack of proper dining etiquette. The poulet rouge arrives whole and you have to carve it yourself, though it's much easier to eat it caveman style. I plead the 5th on what approach I took. So again, don't order this dish unless you're totally comfortable with your date or if your date is Fred Flintstone. S E R V I C E Professional, friendly, and attentive (different from my experiences at Marlowe). The hostesses were welcoming, our waitress always had a smile on her face and the busboys were on their game making sure our water glasses were always filled and plates were promptly taken away. My biggest gripe is that our entrees took a while to come out and the restaurant wasn't busy at the time. A M B I A N C E / D E C O R Vintage meets modern chic with grey tile and red brick walls, open kitchen, communal table, wooden drop candle chandelier, black/white photos and large mirrors. Park Tavern is a much larger space than Marlowe (~3 times larger) and more sophisticated with an older crowd. The sidewalk seating is perfect for people watching at Washington Square Park. Overall, it's a great place to bring out-of-towners. P A R K I N G Difficult street parking. Valet parking is $11.            OOO   OOOOOOO OOOOOYO     OYO     I      I         I      I              iLove Park Tavern's Logo

BCpUBhXnrpusZBGe5eibzw.review_text: Took my girlfriend here for her birthday, and we had a great time.  For starters, the service was amazing - super friendly and very helpful.  The waitress checked in a lot (but not in an annoying way) to make sure we were doing okay.  Also answered any all questions were had regarding anything on the menu.    And of course, the food was delicious.  We started off with the deviled eggs and sprout chips, followed by the "Poulet Rouge" (like a cornish hen) and Black Cod.  For dessert we had the chocolate creme brulee.    Atmosphere was dark/trendy and fairly loud - so if you're looking for a quiet place to sit there and chat, this is not the place.  But if you want a nice night out in the city with good food and service, Park Tavern is a perfect choice.

Mp9gZsob8Hp7qzTh0vA4aA.review_text: I love what they've done with this space. It's restored to an upscale place for dining. That said, I prefer dining at the bar, because I like the look of a large, well-done bustling dining room but the feel of a cozy bar dining experience.   The cocktails are fun and really well done, and the bartenders are professionals.   The menu has a lot of delicious options, and great items for sharing.  Some of the standouts I've tried include the crudo preparations, a sweet summer corn soup, the burger, the brussel sprout chips, and a spinach egg dish (which is part of an amazing, decadent weekend brunch menu).

tX_EaGrNp5tCxCJHi2B5vg.review_text: Had dinner there shortly after their opening.  OUTSTANDING!!!  Glad to see they revived the space from Mooses and whatever was there after that.  Great time and we'll definitely be back!

9le63xehT8pSThdP53boyg.review_text: Good service and atmoshpere. The food was delicious and not over priced. I came here because of the Thrillist best brunches and it is one of the best brunch of SF.   I will recommend it to my friends and probably come back again

EVaW-GGDEbYrYhgGUmO0DQ.review_text: After the super disappointing food at Radius, I had to make my tummy happy again.   Everything I had was so yummy!!! The quality is fresh and good portions.  Fried artichokes w/ lemon aioli and fried garlic-perfectly crispy and the fried garlic is what made the dish.  Brussel Sprout Chips-Super addicting.   $2 each for Deviled eggs-Now that is pricey, but so worth it. Very good and it comes with bacon and pickled jalapeno.
